Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have finished with you, my Son, this book which is the latest in the science of medicine, together with its completion, I have reached the end of it, having set out in it the exposition of its contents and their declaration. It seemed to me that I should complete it for you with this treatise which is a part of the art of surgery, that is, surgery with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since surgery with the hand is a work of great importance in our age and in our time, and since its secrets have been hidden away and are not to be found except in the slight descriptions of the ancient books which have been tampered with by the hands of men: and there has arisen from this both error and hesitation, until its intentions have been closed and its purpose has been extended: I have thought it good to set forth this treatise with reference to the arrangement of this work in its order, and its declarations, and its brevity: and that I may bring together the forms of instruments such as the Cautery and the like, with the rest of the instruments of the art. In this way it will be possible to understand its declarations and to prepare it in the way which is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why one does not find a good surgeon of this kind in our age is that the art of medicine is a long one, and the author must exercise himself beforehand in the science of anatomy as Galen has said, until he knows the functions of the limbs, their shapes, and their connections, and can distinguish between bones, nerves, and lacerations, and count them, and know their exits, and the pulsation of veins, and the quietness and positions of the exits of these
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And for this reason Hippocrates said, that the name is much with the name, and little with the work, especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have already spoken of this in the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	For he who is ignorant of the things which we have spoken of concerning anatomy, will not be excused; for he will fall into error, and will be the cause of the destruction of men. Just as I have seen many of them who form themselves on this science without knowledge or experience.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	Because I have seen many doctors who have followed blindly in the footsteps of their predecessors, neglecting the pulse of a scrophulous swelling in a woman’s neck, and who have thereby injured some arteries in the neck: causing the woman’s blood to flow until she died in their hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I have seen other doctors who have wrongly supposed that they could extract a stone from a bladder that was passing away, and that the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	So it came to pass that he extracted it with the bladder’s husk
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	And the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I myself was called to extract it: and I saw from the greatness of the stone and the condition of the patient that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I have seen another doctor who took a bribe from a certain Duke of our land concerning medicine: and it happened to a black slave who was with him, that he fractured his leg near the ankle: and the doctor, with his ignorance, bound the fracture with nails and string, and did not allow the wound to drain.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he dismissed him according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Afterwards he sent him away for a few days, and commanded him not to move his ligament: and he stood thus until the swelling of his leg and foot had passed away, and he himself perished
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	I was called to him again: and I treated him for his ligament: and there was peace and an end to his pains
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	Truly, corruption has been confirmed in the limb: and I am unable to restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	The corruption has ceased its wandering in the limb, until it passes over
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And behold, another physician who has pierced the cancerous swelling: and it has become ulcerated after days, until the malice of the latter has been increased with its lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	For when the cancer is pure from black bile, then it does not suffice to hold it back with all the iron, except in the limb that will tolerate it, that it be cut off entirely
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And therefore, my son, you must know that the operation is divided into two parts: that which is associated with health, and that which carries the peril in many arrangements
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	I am excited in every place of this book in which the operation is mentioned, in which there is fear and terror.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Therefore, you must be cautious of this, and be restrained: that they do not find folly in speaking, and be dishonest
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Accept therefore measure with humility and protection, and the sick with facility and firmness, and use the better way that brings glory to God to health and praiseworthy succession: and banish the grievous anxieties that make you fear, that there should be hesitation in your faith and comfort
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For there remains a greater glory for your faith, and a sublimation in this world, and finally for your souls.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galen has said in some of his admonitions.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not call evil a bad physician: do not blame the physician for the name of the disease.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I am therefore divided up this treatise into three Chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter One.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Concerning Cautery with fire, and Cautery with acute medicine, the Chapter, and arranged from the head to the feet, concerning the instruments and materials for Cautery: and everything which is necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter Two
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Concerning the section and perforation, phlebotomy and enucleation, and wounds: and the extraction of arrows, and things of that kind: and the whole Chapter, arranged concerning the forms of instruments
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter Three
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	Concerning restoration, and dislocation, and the treatment of torsion, and things of that kind: the whole Chapter, arranged from the head to the feet, concerning the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory be to God.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part I
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	Concerning the application and preparation of Cautery: and on what complexion it is suitable, and when: and if with iron or gold
Caput I.	Chapter I
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before we recall any operation which is to be performed, we must say what is the quality of the instruments and materials to be used: and in what complexion they should be shown
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I say therefore, that the discourse concerning the quality of the application of Cautery, and its preparation, is a long and subtle science, a secret which has been hidden away.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	And many wise men have spoken of this; and they have differed in their opinions: and indeed little is to be learned from their discourses, fearing that they are too long.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say therefore, that the Cauterium is universal for all compositions, which is with matter and without matter: except for two compositions which are the hot composition without matter and the dry composition without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	However, in the hot and dry composition with matter they are dispersed
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some indeed say that the Cauterium is suitable for these (compositions).
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	Others say the opposite, namely that the Cauterium is not suitable for inflammation, which is from heat and dryness: for the nature of fire is heat: and it is inappropriate to cure an inflammation from heat and dryness with heat and dry matter.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the opposite says that by the Cauterium an ointment is made in every heat and dry inflammation which occurs in the bodies of men: for when you compare the body of a man and moisten it, with regard to the fire, you find the body of a man chilled.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I myself have experienced this from experience several times.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	However, it does not suffice to believe this, unless one has been proven, has exercised in the last chapter of the Cauterium exercise, and has recognized the diversity of the compositions of men, and the disposition of inflammation in themselves, and the causes of these, and the accidents of these, and the time of these things.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	Except for these two compositions there is no fear in the rest: and especially in the cold and humid inflammations.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	Indeed all the physicians agree on this: and they do not dissent concerning the use of the Cauterium in these things.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	Note that the children know that the Cauterium with fire is more beneficial than the Cauterium with burning medicine: for fire is simple, whose action does not extend except to the part which is cauterized: and it does not harm any other connected part with it, except for a slight wound
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	The action of inflammation extends from the limb and often makes it difficult to heal wounds in the limb, and sometimes causes death.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	Fire, however, because of its slightness and the goodness of its substance, does not make this worse, except in excess
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	I have learned by experience, from the length of my service and from my studies with art, and from experience on things: and from this I am excused for the length of this sermon
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	If it were not forbidden for this book of mine, I would tell you a secret of fire, and the quality of its operation in the bodies of those expelled from it, which demonstrates the diseases in philosophical language, which agrees with the thoughts of the learned.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know ye, that even the wisest men differ in their time when it comes to the making of the cautery, and they put a better time upon the lesser wound.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	I say indeed that the cautery is always useful: for in every time the document which is to be cauterized is covered with moisture, which is attracted by the cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	Especially if the cautery is for severe and urgent pains, which cannot bear delay: for they fear from the fire that there may arise from it a greater mischief than from the small wound itself.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	Let no one think that because the physician has used cautery for a disease that it is a return: for this is not always the case. For indeed the cautery alters the complexion and dries up humors which are the causes of the disease itself
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	However, the cautery surpasses the physician in speed of action, in the excellence of its operation, and in its gentleness: and it is possible that the disease will return at some later time according to the complexion of the patient, the situation of the disease, and the excellence of the physician. And this is prepared in the body by the collection of superfluous matters in the body itself: and it comes to the same thing as if it were taken from the disease itself.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	Acute pain in a limb with few supernumerary and humid swellings, like a tooth burn, because of pain, and similar to it, is possible that it will not return in that place of pain.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But that is in few cases.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	Indeed, the term "cauterium" is the most recent of medicine; it is the correct term: not for that about which they think in this way: because they believe that there is no remedy which can confer the same as medicine, neither with any other after the event of cauterium.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	However, the thing is contrary to that: and the intention, that cauterium is the most recent of medicine, is not except when we administer modes of treatment in some disease, and these do not confer that medicine: then we administer in the end cauterium, and it confers: thus it falls out that cauterium is the most recent of medicine, not according to the intention which the vulgar and many doctors understand
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	The ancients said that cauterium is better with gold than with iron: and they did not say that except because of the equality of gold, and the fineness of its substance: and they said that it does not form pus at the place of cauterium.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	But it is not absolutely so: for I myself have proved that it does not cause it in some bodies without other things
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And cauterium with itself is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	But when you ignite the cauterium with fire from gold, you are not told when you ignite it according to the quantity that you wish, because of the redness of the gold: and when it approaches the cold, and if you add to it the fire above, it liquefies in the fire, and turns into leaves.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Why does the artificer depart from that to engage in this occupation? And thus Cauterium is made with iron among us more rapid and proximate to the operation, from its straightness towards the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	I have also arranged this Chapter on Cauterium, according to the chapters: and I have arranged these from head to foot: so that they may satisfy anyone who wishes to learn from this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	How to cauterize the head in the coronal suture.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Here the cauterization is performed in accordance with the lord of humidity and cold over the brain: which are the causes of swelling, and of the flow of humors from the head to the eyes and ears, and of the swelling of the brain, and of toothache, and throat pain: and in general of every ailment which arises from cold, such as paralysis, swelling, epilepsy, and apoplexy, and things like these.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is as follows: immediately before the operation, give the patient a solution of vinegar and salt to drink for three or four nights, according to the severity of the patient's condition, and his age, and his habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then order him to raise his head with a new nail.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands square, so that you can place your hands over his head
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your thumb over the root of his nose between his eyes
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	Wherever your middle finger reaches, that is the place where the cautery should be done with the flame.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then ignite the Cauterium with Olive Oil: thus it is formed into this shape
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place it over the marked spot with a burn, descending gradually, until your hand is clasped.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then grasp your hand quickly and touch the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see that the bone is fractured by the quantity of head of the tibia or the quantity of hemlock, then grasp your hand again.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat your grasp with the iron itself, or with something else that is cold: until the bone is seen to move, as I have told you
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt and dissolve it in water, and drink it in this way, and apply it over the spot: and keep it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then apply over it a butter-soaked cloth, and keep it over the spot until the eschar is consumed by fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents containing four herbs, until it is healed
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	It has been said that the greater the wound remains open, the more pus is emitted: which is better and more useful
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	Some people say that the skin should be cauterized until the bone is reached: and hold the cautery until something of the thickness of bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then remove what has been cauterized from the bone, and then care for it
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	Others say that it is necessary to continue cauterizing until the impression of a mark or tool like that which women use to burn initials is impressed in the bone: and that this should be done until steam escapes from this place, and the wound is closed for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Care for it until it is consolidated
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	However, in some individuals they do not issue from two species of Cauterii except in those where fear is great.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	It is better for me that you depart in peace than with fear of me
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	The head suffers from the weakening of continuity of its natural substance: as we have seen in the rest of the limbs: and especially when the head is weak from its natural constitution: the first kind of Cauterii is more safe and better for me, and is more useful. It is therefore to be used with it for the sake of health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	Concerning the cautery of the head in the case of general head-ache
Caput III.	(The text continues with the next section of the translation.)
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When in the whole head there occurs a chronic pain that lasts a long time, and that is accompanied by fever, and vomiting, and head-pounding, and oil, and similar things are used for its treatment.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And especially if it has been cauterized with one Cauterium, as we have mentioned, and nothing else is added to it: then consider it to be sufficient
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head is strong in its natural constitution and is not weak, and if there is intense cold: then cauterize with another Cauterium under the first one a little
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize the whole circumference of the head with the Cauterium, but do not pass through the skin, and uncover the quantity of bone as we have said.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And cauterize once in the occiput of the head in the place which is called the uas: and this is the place where the marrow is placed: elevate the head above this, and do not uncover the bone
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	For in this way the patient finds relief from the intense headache, and from the various pains of the other Cauteria of the head in general
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I say concerning this Cauterium that it must be placed in its proper location: and it is necessary that the Cauterium should burn the horns of the head and the back of the head more subtly than the middle of the head.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	Regarding the method of cautery in hemicrania, both with medicinal unguents and with iron.</start_of_turn>
Caput IIII.	Chapter III.</start_of_turn
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	When there is pain and swelling in a part of the head, and the pain extends up to the eye, and is evacuated with medicinal poultices of the head, and the rest of the treatment is administered, as I have said in the treatises on diseases, and it is not sufficient: then cautery is required in this case, according to two methods: either with acute burning medicine or with iron.</start_of_turn
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	But as for cautery with acute burning medicine, it is that you take a tooth of another and burn it, and excoriate it, and cut off its extremities from both sides.</start_of_turn
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	Then divide the place of the pain in time with a wide vein-cutting, until there is a bubble under the skin, where the tooth is caught.</start_of_turn
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Introduce it there under the skin until it is hidden: then string over it with a thread of constriction that is somewhat thick, and leave it for fifteen hours. Then remove the thread, and draw out the foreign body in two or three days. Then place over it a soft cushion soaked in butter, until the place has healed. Then care for it with an unguent until it is healed.</start_of_turn
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	And if you wish to do this with some burning medicine which I have written about in the twelfth treatise, on Medicinal Astringents.</start_of_turn
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	The cauterization of the bowels with iron is in this manner.
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The iron cautery, which is of this shape
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called Clavus: for its head is of the shape of a key, in which there is some curvature, and in the middle there is a small prominence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then place it upon the place and hold your hand: and move the iron gradually with a velocity: and let the amount which is to be cauterized from the thickness of the skin be as much as half of it
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And lift your hand, so that it does not cauterize the artery which is below, and to avoid the flow of blood
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then soak the wound in salt water, and place it upon the place, and leave it for three days: then place the wound with butter: afterwards care with unguent until it is healed
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if necessary, cauterize this half of the haemorrhoid with the second extremity of the cautery.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And burn from the incision of the artery in this half of the haemorrhoid, not from the old one directly.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	Thus cauterizing in the old haemorrhoid.
Caput V.	End of book V
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you have cured the haemorrhoid, with what we have said before concerning the treatment of diseases, and when the cure has not taken place: and if you perceive from the disease that it is not sufficient for it what we said of the initial cauterization with medicine, or of the cauterization with fire, then you must take the cautery with the knife, until the mark of pain appears on the place, which is as long as half of a finger, or as much as that: and then take your hand away gently, and tighten the area until you have cut the artery, and hold it until the bone is reached.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	It is necessary to tighten the jaw, lest the continuation of the mandible should move during mastication, and cause the edge to become dull, or the nerve which moves it, from which the spasm arises.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	Take great care to prevent any bleeding from the artery which has been severed
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in the cutting there is fear, and especially for him who is ignorant of what he is doing, and who is not skilled, and does not take sufficient care: and he abandons the operation immediately.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I shall come with a reminder of the regimen of the flow of blood which has happened from the artery according to its custom, and in its place in this book
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	If you are of the opinion that the cautery is not sufficient for the case, and that the body of the sick man can tolerate it in the middle of the head, as we have narrated, take care of the wound, until it is healed
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you wish, apply the cautery, which we mentioned in the chapter on the extraction of the artery with a cautery that has two blades
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For the cautery is better made with two blades than with one.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	Of the method of cauterizing in the pain of the ears.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When there is pain in the ear from cold, and it is treated with salves, and the rest of the treatment which we mentioned in the explanation, and the pain does not subside, then apply the cautery: and that is what is called the Punctum, which is shaped like this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then make the puncture around the whole ear, or around both, if the pain is in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And prolong thee with the Cauterium from the root of the ear downwards, after you have marked the place with the Cautery: and let the quantity of the Cautery be ten points in every aure, and as much as that.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	And then care for the place until it is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	So as to cauterize in the Torture
Caput VII.	Chapter VII
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	Torture which is cured by cautery is nothing else except for those kinds which arise from phlegmas, as we said in the discussions about the causes of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And you must cauterize the kind which arises from exiccation and spasm of the nerve
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you cure this kind of torture with hyeris, caputpurgiis, and gargarisms, and the cure does not suffice, then it is necessary to cauterize the patient with three Cauteries: one at the root of the ear, and the second a little lower from the temporal region, and the third at the junction of the two lips
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And place your Cautery opposite the lower part of the infirm.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For the softening does not take place except in the part which appears healthy
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of cautery is that you cauterize the Cautery itself in a direct line from the extremity of the upper ear under the earlobe a little: and the other in the temporal region: whose length should be according to the length of the thumb
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And put your hand with the Cautery until the quantity of half the thickness of the skin is consumed by the flame.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the Cautery, and it is like a knife, whose form is like that: truly it is not finer than that of urine: and it is necessary that the knife be of such a size as to be somewhat thick
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then care for the place, until it has healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	Until it has healed.
Caput VIII.	Chapter VIII.</start_of_turn>
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	When the old apoplexy has subsided, and you have cared for it as we have said, and the medicine does not suffice, and the patient does not have a fever, then cauterize him four times over every horn of his head, and cauterize in the middle of the head, as we have said, and cauterize at the back of the head, as it is proper. And the manner of cauterization should be as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	It is also cauterized with a cautery over the bone of the stomach: and this is the last method.</start_of_turn
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the place, until it has healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	Until it has healed.</start_of_turn
Caput IX.	Chapter IX.</start_of_turn
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary to give in the first instance in the sick person barley flour and nourishing pills for the brain.</start_of_turn
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then shave the head of the patient completely, and put upon his head a bandage of lint described in the treatise on bandages: and put some of it on him.</start_of_turn
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	And this is the manner of cautery: and do it as we have ordered.</start_of_turn
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	If it therefore heals by this, it is good.</start_of_turn
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	If not: then make for him three cauteries on the back of his head, which are descending from the upper part of the head down to the lower part of the eye: and put between every cautery the width of a finger.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for the Cauterium, when it has gone before.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	Then care for the Cauterium, when it has gone before. If however the patient is able to tolerate it: then make for him the Cauterium in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	Then care for the Cauterium, when it has gone before. If however the patient is able to tolerate it: then make for him the Cauterium over two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then care for itself, until it is healed: and let the Cauterium be applied according to its form, which has gone before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	In Paralysis, and in softening.
Caput X.	Chapter X
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary to proceed in the softening of the head with hyssop, and with that which we have mentioned before.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then take the head of the patient: afterwards make the Cauterium in the middle of the head, and the Cauterium over every horn of the head, and the Cauterium over the back of the head, and three over the joints of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	If however it does not agree in bodily mollification by these several means, and the patient is able to tolerate it, and the ailment is strong: then make for him four Cauteriums over the joints of the back, and the last one with the Cauterium, until it is consumed from its surface most of all, and raise your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for itself, until it is healed: and let the Cauterium be applied like oil
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	In Epilepsy
Caput XI.	Chapter XI
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	The epileptic patient is not Cauterized, except for one whose epilepsy is from phlegm
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	It is necessary therefore to soften the brain of him in the first place with hyssop, and with the rest of the cure which we have mentioned before: when the patient is great, or is tolerant in receiving medical treatment
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If, however, the boy does not tolerate medicines, then gargling and nourishing bites of food are administered to him for many days before the restoration of his nourishment.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then the head is bound, afterwards it is cauterized with one cautery in the middle of the head, as it has been said before in this manner: and with another cautery on the nape of the neck, and over all the horns of his head is cauterized
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If he is a strong man, and is tolerant, then cauterize with cauteries what I have said in a paralytic, and soften the body over the bones of the neck and the bones of the back: and let the cautery be olive oil according to the manner which has been said before.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	If he is a weak boy, then place the cautery delicately, according to this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	(The provided text does not contain any information regarding the method of cauterization in Melancholia, so I am unable to translate this portion.)
Caput XII.	(The provided text does not include any additional sections or chapters, so I am unable to translate anything further.)
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	When the cause of melancholy is corrupted humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize with the cautery which we mentioned in a paralytic state.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is excess of bodily humors tending towards melancholy, and the body of the patient is soft, then give him to drink something which will nourish his brain, according to what has been said before in the discourse: then bind the head of the patient, and make after a while a circle from linen, like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head: and the patient sitting square is to be held from all sides
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then apply liniment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	It is more worthy to be taken from an old butt than from a new wound.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	Warm it over a moderate fire, as the finger can tolerate it when it goes in.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then evacuate it in the middle of its head in a circle, and let it go until it is cold to the touch
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Do this every week to the patient, along with the rest of his treatment, until he is healed
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, cauterize it by making many small punctures, because by this means you will keep the hand firm with the cautery: even if it smells badly
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	For this kind of cautery is moist and has the quality of nourishing the brain with moisture
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then put over it a cushion soaked in butter, or fat from a hen.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	In descending water, cauterize the eye.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When the water in the eye is declared by the signs which I mentioned in the preceding discourse, then begin to bathe the patient, with the hand which will move his head
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep it away from all moisture, and make him sit in a bath for a few days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then command him to raise his head, and cauterize it in the middle of his head
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize it over two tempora with two cautery instruments, if there is an incipient descent of the water in both eyes simultaneously: or from one side only, if there is an incipient descent of the water in only one eye: and cut through all the veins and arteries which are under the skin: and let the cautery be long in the width of the tempora: and burn from the flow of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If anything is seen to be issuing from it, then immediately sever it with whatever medicine is available: and I shall come with wisdom in the extraction of arteries, and the severance of them, and the precautions against the flow of blood.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	When cauterized in the flesh under two bones, two cautery instruments must be used at the last moment.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	As to cauterization in the ancient eyes.</start_of_turn>
Caput XIIII.	Chapter 123.</start_of_turn>
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the tears of the eyes are ancient, adhering: and are over the veins which are in the exterior of the head, it is verified that this is from superabundance of cold humors, phlegmas: then cauterize with the same instrument which I mentioned in the commencement of the descending water, the cautery in the middle of the head, and with two cautery instruments over two temporal regions, and with two cautery instruments in the flesh under two bones.</start_of_turn
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if digestion does not suffice, then cauterize itself in every side of the eye cautiously over the eyebrow with a small cautery instrument.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	As to cauterization of the nose's cavity.</start_of_turn
Caput XV.	Chapter 15.</start_of_turn
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you are treating this, with what we said in the treatise, and the medicine does not suffice: then cleanse it, and give in the drinking water of the sick three nights: then cover its head, and cauterize it with the middle cautery, with an olive cautery.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with two claw-shaped cautery instruments over two eyebrows under the hair slightly.</start_of_turn
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	Beware lest you cut into the artery.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	This is the form of the cautery of Claudius.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	How to cauterize in the softening of the Palpebrae
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the Palpebra of the eye is softened by dryness or humidity: then cauterize the Palpebra with a single cautery, like the lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if you wish, cauterize it above two upper lashes by means of two cauteries in every part: and extend for two times: and let the length of every cautery be according to the length of the lashes: and do not touch your hand with the cautery, but according to the quantity which is to be cured of the third of the Palpebrae.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	This is the form of the cautery according to this method of the lunar cautery
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	How to cauterize the Palpebra when the hairs are set on fire in the eye
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	There are two methods of cautery: either with fire or with a burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	But in the cautery with fire, command the patient to expel his hair before that, if there are those which fall out, until they be prolonged and equal
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	If however they are burnt at the root: then hold the eyes closed with a bandage, so that they do not move, until they are healed
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they are healed and equal, then place the head of the patient in your hand: then sign over the Palpebra of the eye with ink, in the shape of the leaf of the Myrtle: and let the beginning of the sign be near the hairs
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then place the soaked cushion in albumin or: over the hair on the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then apply the cautery, which is shaped thus
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then burn over the figure which you have marked gradually in many places, until the surface of the skin is consumed, which is like the figure of a myrtle leaf, throughout its appearance
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of the completion of your work is: if you press the eyelid of the eye with your finger, and pluck the hair at the point of the eye
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then lift your hand up: and let go of it in three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then place upon it a cushion with butter, until the pus is eradicated
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguent until it is healed
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	If any hair remains after an hour, and you soften the eyelid: then burn the cautery once more over the same place as before
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	If however the hair is in the lower part: then burn the lower part only, until it rises to its natural place: and make sure that the hair does not prick the eye
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	In the same way as with the burning cautery with medicinal herbs in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	It is like the main rule for the sick person, that he should pluck the hair, until it becomes long and even
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make from parchment in the shape of a myrtle leaf
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from soap that has been pounded, and from dry mustard one pound or almost that: then mix these together with some lukewarm water, and make it into a thick paste, so that it does not freeze
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then take from the middle of it a piece like the shape of a myrtle leaf, and place it upon the lid of one or both eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye a piece soaked in albumin: and the head of the patient should be in your lap.</start_of_turn>
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your finger on the sign of the physician, and press it gently.</start_of_turn>
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And you shall move it whenever the patient feels the bite of the medicine: because its bite is like fire.</start_of_turn
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While you are doing this, you will have perceived its bite; then remove the medicine and move it with your finger.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the bite has ceased, then remove the medicine and wipe the eye with water.</start_of_turn
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And consider then, if the lid is raised by the elevation with the contraction like that which happens with fire, or with an incision, it is well done: and if not, then repeat the medicine upon the place where it did not stick, without denigrating it, until the operation is complete and the eyes are closed.</start_of_turn>
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then place upon it a piece of butter, until the wound of the skin is eradicated.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment of diaphanicon, or something else, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you at the operation, that you should keep watch until the last moment, that nothing of the medicine should fall into the eye.</start_of_turn
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	For if the eyelid becomes soft after a day, and there is something of the hair which has fallen out in the eye, then repeat the medicine upon the place where the eye is softened in its own way, as you did at the beginning.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for yourself until you are healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	This is the form of the myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	You know that the eyes of men differ in size and in shape
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore you must take this into consideration: and you must not be ashamed of the crookedness of your eye, for it is the study of this art
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	Concerning the cauterizing of the fistula of the tear duct
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you have cured the fistula, when you see that your treatment has not been successful: then you must cauterize it according to this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Command the patient to place his head in your lap, and keep his head between your hands in this way, so that it does not move or shake with his head
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then put the soaked sponge in the white of the eye, or in the mucus of the eyelashes over his eye: then apply the Cautery, which is of this shape
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Let it be concave, like the shape of a pentagon twig at its joint, as the Cautery is: and if you see that it is penetrating to the other extremity, or if you see that it is going upwards like this: do so too
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	But it is better to make it concave for your work
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then express the fistula, if it is open, and remove the pus from it, and dry it up: and if it is not open, then open it up, and remove the pus from it
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then put upon it again the Cautery, which is alight with a flame.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	Hold your hand close to the Cauterium from the eye to the part of the nose, so that your hand does not move, or disturb the patient: and place the Cauterium on the fat of the eye and consume it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If you linger at the beginning of the Cauterium until the bone, it will be good
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	If not: then repeat the Cauterium once, or twice, if you are unable to digest it: and let it go in three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then place the bandage with butter, and care for it with an exicator until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	If after forty days it does not heal: then place above it an acute corrosive medicine, until the bone is broken: and do it according to what is written in its chapter
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	There is another method of Cauterizing fistulas, which some of the first men have said
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Intend to the place of the fistula, and find it: then place under the small opening of the fistula a thin sliver of sliver of camphor, which is shaped like this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And mix with it the quantity of a drachma of liquid lead, and hold your hand with the cane firmly in place, and do not move the patient at all, so that it does not run or cause the liquid lead to reach the eye
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	And it is necessary to place above the eye of the patient a bandage soaked in albumin or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	Lead burns the place of the fistula, and heals it with a miraculous healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	When the fistula is healed, as we have said from the Cauterium and the care, it is good
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	If not, it is necessary to make a hole in the nose, and reduce the fistula to the course of the nose, according to what is written in its proper place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	On the method of cauterization in fissures of the Labiorum.
Caput XX.	On the method of cauterization in fissures of the Labiorum.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Many are the acids that occur in the Labium's fissures, which are called Pili, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you have cured the fissures, when you do what we said in the instruction of diseases, and it does not suffice for the cure, then you must make a small burn with the cautery, in this form
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let its depth be according to the sharpness of the knife
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then put the flame quickly on these fissures, until the cautery reaches the depth of the fissures
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the cautery until it heals
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	On the method of cauterization in the fistula of the Oris
Caput XXI.	On the method of cauterization in the fistula of the Oris
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When swelling appears in the root of the gingiva, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then pus forms, and it bursts: afterwards it heals, pus runs, and a fistula forms: then you must cure the fistula itself, and not in its cure, then it is necessary to make an incision with the cautery according to the quantity that is in the fistula
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then insert the flame into the cavity of the fistula, and hold your hand, until the iron of the flame reaches the depth of its bottom, and its end: do this once, or twice at most
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then care for it afterwards, as we said in the curing until it heals
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If therefore it breaks and heals, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, it is necessary to remove the place and lift out the corrupt bone according to what comes into his head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	In the treatment of gums and teeth, cauterization and softening are useful procedures.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gums are softened by moisture, the teeth are mobile, and care is taken with the physicians, and it does not happen: then put the patient's head in your lap
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then make cauterization, whose shape will come afterwards, so that you put the canula over the tooth: and introduce the burning cauterization into it quickly: and keep your hand away, until the patient feels the heat of the fire has reached the root of the tooth
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And lift your hand away: then repeat the cauterization a few times, according to what you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then let the patient rinse his mouth with salt water, and keep it for one hour: and then expel it.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	The tooth will henceforth be firm, and the gums will be softened and stretched, and the moisture will be dried up
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	In the treatment of toothache
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When toothache arises from cold, or if cold exists in the tooth itself, or worms, and no relief comes from physicians: then Cauterium is applied in two ways: either with butter or with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	Cauterium is applied with butter, thus take butter, mix it with wax, and apply it to the cavity or to the root of the tooth
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take charcoal and cover the end of the tooth with it.</start_of_turn>
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then put it in boiling butter: and put it on the aching tooth until it gets cold: then repeat it several times until the fire has reached the root of the tooth.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	Or if you wish, soak wool or charcoal in cold butter and put it on the aching tooth: and put on top of it a burning iron until the fire has reached the depth of the cavity of the tooth.</start_of_turn>
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	The latter method is with fire, as for the cannula of air or of iron.</start_of_turn>
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be something of size in the body of it, so that the fire does not reach the bone of the patient.</start_of_turn>
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then take the Cauterium, which has the desired shape: and put it on the tooth: and hold your hand until the Cauterium cools down.</start_of_turn
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this several times, for the pain will vanish either on the same day or the next day.</start_of_turn
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And let there be an imprint of the Cauterium in the impression, so that the patient may put butter on his own bone and keep it for an hour: then expel it.</start_of_turn>
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	This is the form of the Cauterium.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	And this is the shape of the Cauterium.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	So cauterize with whatever extremity you wish, according to what is possible: and this is the shape of the Cannula.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the Strata are affected by phlegm, and by cold humours, and do not obey digestion by medicines, and you wish to speed up their digestion: then ignite the Cauterium which is concave, and whose form is like this
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	Having two open extremities, so that the smoke of the Cauterium may escape from the other extremity: and place the burning instrument upon the boil once, and a second time if you fail to digest the first, until it reaches the depth of the boil
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	If the boil is small: then place the Cauterium according to the quantity of the boil
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then withdraw it for three days, and place above it a soaked bandage in butter, until the burnt part has healed
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for it with unguents until the shape of the Cannula is restored
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	¶ So cauterize in raucedine of voice, and constriction of the chest.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.
