When moisture accumulates on the channel of the lungs, and especially when it is accompanied by the coldness of the complexion, then it is necessary to evacuate the patient immediately with the help of medicinal solutions
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize at the neck in the pit below the root of the gullet: and take care not to bring the Cauterium too close to the gullet or to the skin, except for some reason
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then burn it with another cautery at the junction of the neck towards the end of the last rib: and let the cautery be closed in the manner that preceded it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then burn it with another burn until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	In the case of wounds of the lung or the chest, burn from the inside outwards.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.</start_of_turn>
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When the cough and the chest-ache of the lung are from cold humours, and the patient has neither fever nor phthisis, nor old disease: then burn it with two burnings above the rib in the hollow places, in the leni, in the uacu.</start_of_turn>
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And burn another one in the middle of the chest between the two nipples: and let the burn be closed in the manner that preceded it.</start_of_turn
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish to make a puncture with the burn, which is called Punctum, whose shape preceded the puncture of the pain of the ear: and let the punctures be from thirty punctures up to almost to the others.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then burn it with another burn until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And thus is the burn having three branches: in this shape.</start_of_turn
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Therefore the burn must be made with three burns when you do it with oil.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	In the case of a dislocation of the humerus or the titillum, burn from the outside inwards.</start_of_turn
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.</start_of_turn
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the ulna is dislocated by the cause of humours, and does not return to its place in the hour following its dislocation, until it has become accustomed to its return: then it must be reduced by a small movement, as we have often testified concerning this, and then it is necessary to reduce the dislocation from the first place.</start_of_turn
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the sickly person lies upon his back, or upon the side of the healthy one.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then raise the skin which is inside Tilliculus towards the upper parts with your left hand: and if the dislocation has gone inwards.</start_of_turn>
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then take Cauterium having two hairs.
Cuius forma est haec.	Whose form is this.</start_of_turn
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then burn the skin until it goes through to the other side, and the figure of the cauterization will be like four cauterizations.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And when the cauterization is made with a cauterium having three hairs, because of which the figure of the cauterization is then made of six cauterizations: and these are the hairs according to their slenderness.</start_of_turn
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the form of the cauterium having three hairs.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And when one is added over this way one more, because there are eight cauterizations.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place upon the cauterization soaked porros with salt.</start_of_turn
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make the sickly person adhere to tranquility, so that he does not move the limb for some time, until he is comfortable.</start_of_turn
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is towards the upper parts, and this is rare, then burn it above the humerus with the claw cauterium, or with many punctures.</start_of_turn
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the dislocation will be firm, and the moisture will be absorbed: and the sickly person will be healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	In this way the Stomach is cauterized.</start_of_turn
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.</start_of_turn
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When cold and moisture abound in the stomach, until they are extracted from its composition, and the humors are multiplied to it, and attentive methods of treatment are not conferred: then it is necessary that the patient rest upon his back, extend his limbs, and place his hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cautery instruments, a cautery under the pectoralis cartilage equal to the length of a single finger with a cautery of the nail, and two lower cauteries from two lateral sides of one cautery, until the triangle of the cauteries appears.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And lengthen between each [cautery] so that they do not join, when pus is formed.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And the depth of the cautery is equal to two-thirds of the thickness of the skin
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And the shape of the cauteries is as follows: without addition: and if you wish to cauterize a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this shape: let the cautery be as much as this single cautery according to the figure of the circle according to this shape
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	The stomach is cauterized by pricking that which returns from this cautery: and it is that the signs above the stomach prick according to quantity, as much as you wish with the incisions: then cauterize it with the puncture cautery: then care for it with the care which preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	In this manner cauterize the spleen when cold.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When cold or large winds exist in the spleen, until it naturally evacuates from its composition and superfluous humors are expelled: then it is necessary that the patient rest upon his chest, and signs with three cauteries according to this shape and this quantity should be placed below the hypocondria, where the elbow of a man rests: and let the space between every two cauteries be equal to the length of a finger. And let the cautery be equal to the length of the rectum of a man: and do not press your hand with the cautery much.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity of that which is to be drawn out from the roughness of the skin be equal to the middle quantity of it, neither more nor less: and let the patient be lying on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	If he is not standing, then let him be lying down, with his limbs extended and his arms uplifted
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of cauterization.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And it is also possible to cauterize these carbuncles with a cautery knife, when there is skill and prudence in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	Beware lest you proceed too far with the cautery, and that you cause the roughness of the whole skin to endure, whereby the whole body is scorched and the intestines are damaged: for the skin there is soft, as you know well
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	Concerning the cautery of the after-effects of the liver.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When the discharge comes out, and you wish to write, if the after-effect is in the liver itself, or in its membrane: if it is in the liver itself, there is dull pain and greatness without acute pain: and if it is in the membrane of the liver, with acute pain which is a heavy burden: and you must know that this fatigues the physicians who are caring for him
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	It is therefore necessary that the patient lies on his back on his bed of rest.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then the position of the after-effect with the cautery: then you burn with the cautery that absorbs the heat.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with one cautery until the whole skin is burnt through and the intestines are exposed, until the whole discharge has gone out: then care for the discharge itself until the patient is healed.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	Neither is it proper that every kind of cautery should be used, except for one whose study in the art of medicine has been prolonged: and by whose hand these diseases have already been encountered with experience. Then indeed may one dare to attempt such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	It is better for you to depart from me than to linger.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	Regarding cautery in Pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 1
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients say that cautery, when applied with the roots of Aristolochia to a cold Pleurisy, should be done in this manner
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is to be taken that from the dried roots of Aristolochia, one should take a long root, which comes from it, and let it be as thick as a digit
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then submerge the cautery in oil: and kindle it in the fire
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize the cautery once with the thumb between the continuation of the collarbone and the chin, and with two small cauteries under guidance slightly depressed at the part under the beard
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And with two cauteries also in that which is between the fifth and sixth ribs depressed downwards to the back part: and with another cautery in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three cauteries from behind: one in that which is between the two scapulae: and two cauteries from the two sides of the chest, the lower cautery which is between the two scapulae
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And it is not proper that you should press your hand with the cautery, but rather let it rest openly on the skin smelling faintly
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancient writers say that there are those among men who use a cautery like iron: they ignite it, and putting it inside them between the ribs, they hold it there until it is consumed with it at the end: and it comes out whole, and the patient is healed: as we said concerning the Apoplexy of the Liver
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this perforation with the cautery is from fear, for either the infirm dies immediately, or it happens that in the place of the fistula there is no healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	Regarding the cautery of the spleen and head of the pancreas thus.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you treat the ailment of the spleen, when what we said about the treatment of the ailments does not confer healing, then the cautery is in these three ways, all of which are right
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One of them is that you make three cauteries or four in line following the length of the spleen according to the shape of the cautery of the Liver, which precedes in figure
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And be between every cautery the amount of the breadth of a finger, or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And be the manner of cautery which we said concerning the cautery of the liver equal.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	Do not press your hand with the cautery: and let the infirm be lying on his back over his belly
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another manner of cautery is: that you make a cautery having two rings, as we said in the chapter on dislocation of the humerus: and lift the skin which is directly over the spleen, where the elbow of the infirm’s left arm lies: and lift your arm as much as you lift the skin according to the width of the body, so that the cautery should go according to the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert two rings of fire alight on the outside, until when the fire has penetrated the skin from the other side: then draw back the cautery: there will be four cauteries thus
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with another cautery having three rings.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then take care of the cautery after you have put it away to emit pus for several days: for this is better than all that has preceded from the treatment
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	On the method of cauterizing in Hydropsis.
Caput XXXIII.	In Hydropsis, on the method of cauterizing.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	In Hydropsis, cautery does not suffice without specific excisions.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you are treating Hydropsis with methods of treatment which we have mentioned in the preceding discourse, and the condition does not improve, then it is necessary to cauterize the four cauteries around the navel, one above the stomach, one above the spleen, and one above the kidneys, and two behind the ribs, and one in the middle of the chest, and one in the middle of the abdomen: and the degree of depth of the cautery should be proportionate to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then draw out the cautery cautiously, so that pus will discharge over a long period of time
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	Do not remove the diseased part after cautery, but leave it to heal: for two intentions will be gathered together with this: and it will soon heal with the help of God
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The form of the cautery which should be used for the uterus is the claw-like: and for the back, the olive-like form
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	On the method of cauterizing feet and limbs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When swelling occurs in Hydrops and the limb is filled with yellow fluid: it is necessary to cauterize above the ankle, between the heel and the toe: and hold your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then raise your hand: and do not move it at all
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	The yellow fluid will rise up, and the cautery should be used in this fashion
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make upon each foot two carbuncles in every foot, and bring the cautery to a close with the extremity of the knife of the cautery: and make the cautery according to the length of the leg, one under the knee and the other beneath the other, about the middle of the leg: and upon every heel make two carbuncles: and draw out the cautery without healing for a long time: that it may suffice from it something of the water; then care for the rest as we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	Then make upon each foot two carbuncles in every foot, and bring the cautery to a close with the tip of the knife of the cautery: and make the cautery according to the length of the leg, one under the knee and the other beneath the other, about the middle of the leg: and upon every heel make two carbuncles: and draw out the cautery without healing for a long time: that it may suffice from it something of the water; then care for the rest as we have said.
Caput XXXV.	Then make upon each foot two carbuncles in every foot, and bring the cautery to a close with the tip of the knife of the cautery: and make the cautery according to the length of the leg, one under the knee and the other beneath the other, about the middle of the leg: and upon every heel make two carbuncles: and draw out the cautery without healing for a long time: that it may suffice from it something of the water; then care for the rest as we have said.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the belly is in solution from the cold and moisture until the power of retention and digestion is weakened, which are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cured with the methods of treatment, and not healed: and the strong man tolerates the excessive power of the cautery; then make the great cautery upon his belly according to what has been said concerning the circular cautery upon the stomach with the cautery, and four cauteries around the navel downwards, with the cautery of the heel downwards; and the cautery above the navel above the ribs, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if the water makes the excess moist, and the patient tolerates it, then make the great cautery upon the loin, and the cautery upon every hip: and perhaps add two small cauteries upon the stomach near the great one.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	There exists indeed a proficient treatment whose application does not err.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	There exists indeed a proficient treatment whose application does not err.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter six.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When in the rectum there are numerous old haemorrhoids, either one or several, and they are of gross, cold, or moist humour, and are cured with that which we mentioned in the treatise, and not by other means: then burn with three burnings the lower part of the spinal column below the almond-shaped area triangularly, and burn beneath the navel as with two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that its stomach is hardened, and its food does not digest, and that its face is pale and moist: then burn it on the stomach with a large burn, as has been said before: and burn on the liver and on the spleen themselves, with the cautery hook: and remove the cautery when it is open at some time: then care for it until it is healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	Chapter six
Caput XXXVII.	When the belly button has been cut, and there is still some discharge from the wound: then burn the surrounding area with a cautery, as much as necessary.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you cut the belly button, then burn the cautery that absorbs the wound
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then insert the burning instrument into the cut belly button: and with your last hand, until the cautery reaches the opening of the vein from which blood flows: do this once or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If there are many belly buttons, then burn each one individually as we have said before
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then care for it, with that which helps to remove the discharge, until it is healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you burn it with a large cautery on the fat, that is the last thing to be done in the treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	How to cauterize a Fistula in the Anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	How to cauterize a Fistula in the Anus.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the patient does not yield to section and operative measures in its place, and recurs to the same, it may possibly be cured by cautery.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When such a thing happens to any Fistula, and it is closed, pus runs out of it, and the corrupted parts are moistened
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore it is necessary to make an incision with a fine needle
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then recognize the depth of its puncture with the needle
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then apply the cautery, which is like a rod
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then introduce the burning part of the cautery into the Fistula itself and the quantity in which the thread entered the fistula.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat the cautery over the place several times, until all the corrupted parts are consumed, once, or twice, or thrice, according to the necessity
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And be attentive to avoid the nerves, if there are any, or great veins: or if the Fistula comes to the wall of the rectum, or to the intestine, then take care to avoid these places
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	Do not do this unless the Fistula is in a fleshy place: and be aware that it does not penetrate
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the place until it is healed
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If, however, the place is sealed, and is separated from the surrounding matter, and remains so for a long time: then you know that it has been completely healed
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if it is not separated from the surrounding matter, then you know that it is penetrating, or that there is a broken bone in its depth, or as if this comes from these things: which memory will arise in its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	How to cauterize the kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	How to cauterize the kidneys.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When pain in the kidneys arises from cold or from large swelling, and it diminishes on account of that from which the patient suffers, then it is necessary to cauterize above the navel over the kidneys, with cautery over the whole kidney along with the cloul.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we must also cauterize below in the same cavity.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Because three lines come together there
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore there are two last things in the wound
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	How to cauterize the bladder.
Caput XL.	How to cauterize the bladder
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When in the bladder there is weakness, and softening from the stone and humidity, until the patient does not retain urine, then cauterize in the lower part of the belly over the bladder where the hair of the pubic bones begins, and cauterize from the right side of the belly and also from the left side of it: and let the length of that cautery be as much as the breadth of a thumb: and cauterize with a lower cautery or with two cauteries, as you please: and do so as much as the cautery claw demands
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	How to cauterize the matrix
Caput XLI.	How to cauterize the matrix
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When in the matrix there is cold and humidity, and it is prohibited by this from conception, and corrupts its menstruation, and delays the discharge of its seed, and there is pain in its vicinity, then it is necessary to cauterize with three cauteries around the navel, as we said concerning the cautery of the bladder, and cauterize over the lower belly below, or with two cauteries: and let the cautery claw be as much as the claw of the cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	How to cauterize the Ancham in dislocation.
Caput XLII.	How to cauterize the Ancham in dislocation.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When moisture of the mucous membrane spills over onto the head of the Ancham, and is the cause of its displacement from its place: and its sign is that the thigh is prolonged over the other thigh when compared with the limb that is not displaced: and the place of dislocation is found in that hollow space.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore it is necessary to cauterize the diseased area over the head of the Ancham with a cautery similar to a circle: after which you must mark the sign of encasement around the circumference of the head: and let the head itself fall into the middle of the circle
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cautery be of the form which preceded in the cautery of the stomach
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If this cautery is not present, then cauterize it three times with a large olive cautery: and make the depth of the cautery equal to the thickness of the entire skin
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	How to cauterize in Sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	How to cauterize in Sciatica
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When there is pain in the head of the Ancham, and the cause of it is cold and moisture: and the disease is cured by that which we mentioned in the explanation, and not by any other treatment, and it is old: then it is necessary to drain the disease from the thick humors with foul pills, or with artificial pills, and similar things
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the mode of cautery in these two ways: either with cautery alongside the physicians, or with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	The cauterium with fire is according to many methods.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of them is that it is cauterized over the mark of the ailment three times by a triangular cautery, according to this form.</start_of_turn>
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make the depth good, or bad.</start_of_turn>
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And there be space between every cautery of the size of the breadth of a finger: and let the cautery be olive-shaped.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	When, however, the cautery is in the middle over the head of the ailment.</start_of_turn
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Then are four cauteries.</start_of_turn
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you cauterize with a circle, whose shape precedes the form in the cautery of dislocation of the limb, one: so that it may contain the whole limb.</start_of_turn
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the whole skin.</start_of_turn
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of cautery in Sciatica, when the pain is adhering to the limb itself, and does not extend until the knee and thigh.</start_of_turn
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If, however, it extends until the knee and thigh, then cauterize with two cauteries over the knee, over the place to which it has been brought there in that part which is painful, and cauterize your thumb and four fingers up to the wrist on the outer side: and let the cautery be like a knife.</start_of_turn
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be according to the depth of the thickness of the skin.</start_of_turn
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	And if the patient says that the pain extends almost to the toes, then cauterize there where the pain is with the point, or with three, or four, or as many as are necessary for that.</start_of_turn
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if pain persists below the knee towards the heel, then cauterize it there with a single lancet.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And perform every cauterization cautiously, lest you burn nerves or a great artery, and cause thereby excessive pain or contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	I also know of some who have cauterized above the ankle, and have finished cauterization, and the limb has swollen, until the tumor has followed the limb down to the foot, and has burst, and all the limb has been corrupted: afterwards there followed solution of the belly, and pus after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If pain is in two parts simultaneously, cauterize both according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men say concerning the cauterization of an abscess that this is the method
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a mark like that of iron, whose diameter be half of the palm: and be at the orifice as much as the diameter of the kernel of the thumb, or less: and there be within it a third part like itself
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And be the space which is between every mark as much as the quantity of the thumb-node: and let the marks be opened from two parts: and let the height of them be like a node, or two nodes: and make a handle of iron aptated in the middle of the marks.
Et haec est forma eius.	This is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then it is ignited in the fire, until it turns red, and throws sparks: and then it is placed upon the abscess inflamed above the sound side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Cauterize thus three times with round lancets in one place
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then remove it on the third day.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	After applying the plaster with butter: and discharge the opened wound after many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says: in this kind of burn, or of a son, we use it little, because of the fear of its aspect: and therefore we find few who dare to expect more of it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	It is true that among good burns those that please it find their place.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	A burn, however, with physicians who are experienced, is like two hairs having a perforated arm, in which the wrist of the limb has descended from the air, or from iron, of the length of half the wall: whose height is that of two nodes, or as if it were one
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let there be the space which is between two quantities of the thickness of a finger, and let the lower and upper edges be open: and let the contents extend to the middle, following this shape.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place the burn over a cushion of wool, with the sick person resting over the healthy side
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And compress the hand over the cushion of wool much.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between two circles of lukewarm water, which is warmed with fire a little, and keep the burn immersed for the quantity of an hour: and the patient will tolerate the biting of his burn, and the heat of the burn, for he finds the biting like fire until it rests
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then lift the hand with the instrument, and wipe away the lukewarm water from the whole burn with sweet water: then discharge it on the third day.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put butter on it, until the black of the burn be removed: and discharge it in a few days, and it will go out from itself.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	The utmost is in healing.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends to the hip or thigh: make for it a posture in which water can be contained, as you did in the wider area.</start_of_turn>
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the way of warm water: and I have written about it in the treatise on the rectification of medicine.</start_of_turn
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali and unburnt lime of both together in equal parts: put each of them in a new vessel, and make a small hole in the bottom of each vessel with a single hole: put under the bottom of the vessel a vessel filled with water: and pour over it alkali and lime from sweet water, so that it submerges each by a finger: then close them with your hand and press them well: and let go of the vessel when the acute water has descended from the lower part of the treated vessel.</start_of_turn
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then gather up the whole water and pour it over the other lime: and close, until it recovers.</start_of_turn
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	The very thing itself is a strong antidote for acute pain, which is administered in many medical operations and in the cauterization of the remaining members.</start_of_turn
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	For it does the work of the fire operation itself.</start_of_turn
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And from the physicians, when they cauterize the wide areas, even like testicles, and mastic, and nutgall, and lime with soap, thus both are mixed together.</start_of_turn
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galen himself relates that a certain man from the ancient physicians, who cured the pain of sciatica and the pain of the heel: and praised its power.</start_of_turn
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said, "It is not necessary for other treatment, for he has been healed from one bath alone, since perhaps he himself may have entered the swollen bath and emerged from it whole.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is taken from the green herbs: if it is not found green, take dry, mix: and apply much with some fat, and put over the swelling, where is pain, or thigh, or in the hip: and bind, and let it go for the quantity of three hours, or for the quantity which the patient feels sedation of the pain.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then introduce him into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When the body is softened, introduce him into the tub
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain retreats, and he is healed
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And you know that it does not be necessary to use any other cauterization with these doctors, except after the evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides, who said this, says that the dung of goats, when it is cauterized with vinegar, gives relief for a sciatica: and it is cauterized in this way.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Take wool, and soak in old oil, and put on the deep place, which is between the thumb of the foot, and between the toes, and is closer to the toe
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take the dry dung of goats, and burn it in the fire, until it becomes charcoal
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then put it on the wool, and let it go, until it is extinguished
Deinde itera illud.	Do it again like this.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Do not cease to do this until the sense of pain has passed by sensation until the swelling has gone down, and the pain has ceased
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And thus this method of cautery is called cautery of the Vaccinum.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	Of the cautery of the pain of the back
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	When there is pain in the back from many causes, or from a wound, or from a blow, or from excessive evacuation, and similar things, from the infusion of cold and moist material: and the cautery is not useless, except in one kind only, which is from the infusion of cold material.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	It is necessary therefore after evacuation of the sick with foetid pills, and things like these, to make three lines upon the back, where the pain is, along the width of the palm of the hand, after having signed with the cautery in every line five burnings, or more according to the tolerance of the sick person or the severity of his illness: and let the cautery be made with the cautery-needle.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you will, burn three or four times with the middle cautery, according to this shape
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	Of the manner of cautering in the swelling of the knee.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	Many times this swelling happens to small children
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its swelling in children is: when there is a stricture in the ankle with elevation and movement: and you find it in the last vertebra of the back and the nodes of it, which begin to protrude over the rest of the vertebrae
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When you see this, and you wish to do the same, then burn it with the cautery which is in the shape of a circle according to this form
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And take the cautery over the whole part of the vertebra equally: and if you wish, burn around the vertebra with the needle two or three lines: and let the punctures be close to each other
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then care for the place, until it is healed with what we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	Do not apply cautery to a swelling, which occurs from a spasm of the nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	As for cautery in podagra, and in joined pains.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pains of the joints are from cold humours which flow upon every limb of the body, then when such pains happen in the feet, it is customary among physicians to call that Podagra
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When, therefore, Podagra is caused by cold humours, it is cured by means of cautery, not by removing the pain
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is necessary to cauterise after the evacuation around the joint of the foot with many cautery instruments: and let the cautery be of Olive Oil
Cuius haec est forma.	This is the form of it
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you do not like to make holes upon the face of the foot, then make holes with the cautery.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	When the pain ascends up to the knee, or if the other joints remain, and this happens frequently, then cauterise the whole knee with three cautery instruments, or four from all sides, with the same cautery as Clauili
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If, however, more is necessary of this cautery, then cauterise it
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	Do not immerse your hand with the cautery, but keep the thickness of the skin around it only
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	When the pain ascends up to the knee and the back: then administer what we have said concerning cautery in its chapter
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If pain is in the hands only, then points are made around the circumference of the fingers, like two lines that are reversed.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If, however, the pain remains in the digits, then points are made over every knot of the finger and over the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If the pain then ascends to the elbows or shoulders, then cauterize both from every part.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	Do not evacuate the patient from the treatment regimen or the care of physicians.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if a good regimen be made and phlegmas be evacuated, the patient will recover with the aid of God with this cautery
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	Concerning the cauterization of ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 42.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin and the intestines or the bladder descend to the testicle, and this is at the beginning near: then it is necessary for the physician to order the patient to vomit his food on the day of the injury
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And to give him laxatives, with which the stool will descend from his belly
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then let him sit between your hands on his back: and command him to hold his breath, until the bladder or the intestines appear
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce the digitum youris, and sign with the cautery under the rupture over the bone of the wrist, with the sign that its extremity is like the middle of a circle towards the upper parts of the body
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then make the cautery, which has this shape, until it becomes white, and throw away the smoke.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestines or the bladder to their place
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then he places his hand on the belly, so that the intestines do not escape: for you have already opened between the ribs of the sick man, and you have placed under it some powder, and another servant is above his ribs, and another above his chest which holds his hand.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then he places the cautery upon the very mark, your hand being fixed upright with the cautery
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	Hold it there until you reach the bone: or go again with it until you have reached something else, if you have not followed it with the first one until the bone
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And cautiously observe the escape of the intestine at the time of your cautery, lest you burn it, and let it pass over the patient or wound, or great malice.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And you know, when you do not follow with the cautery the bone, your operation is in vain.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cautery be slight of infants, according to their measure
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the remaining unguents until he is healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the patient lie upon his back for forty days, until the wound is healed
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary to give him nourishment throughout the time of his cure, which will soften his belly: so that the intestines do not escape through the wound and be evacuated.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wants to rise after forty days, then perform the ligature of the median ligament, and hold it for another forty days
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And let him abstain from work, and take nourishment of food and drink, and fresh air.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when you observe this regimen, the healing will be perfect
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	I say that I will speak of the cure of ruptures with incision in their chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When, however, ruptures happen in the rest of the belly, and are starting, and you wish not to add to them, then cauterize the rupture with a round cautery according to its quantity: and let that which is cauterized be as much as a third of it
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then cure it with that which we have said: and do not add to it.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And some have said: to cauterize the rupture with a triangular cautery, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	When it has been signed with charcoal and put on, and a line is drawn which is through the width at the upper side of the rupture, and a line to the lower side
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with the cautery of a claw
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the first cautery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	In the case of pains caused by swelling or percussion.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When in some limb there is swelling from a blow or percussion, and the pain persists for a long time, and does not subside with the aid of physicians: then it is necessary to cauterize with a needle cautery
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the cautery be of the same size as the limb, and its breadth, and its flexibility, and its strength, and the place of torsion, and the pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If therefore it is healed from the first cautery, it is good
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then repeat over the same cautery.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	Since custom is for these diseases that they should be transferred from one member to another that approaches them.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore it is necessary to follow them with the cautery until the patient is healed.</start_of_turn>
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	On how to cauterize in Lepra.</start_of_turn>
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLVIX.</start_of_turn
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	Leprosy, however, sometimes requires the greatest cautery.</start_of_turn
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially in the kind of Leprosy that is caused by putrefaction of phlegmas and melancholy: in such a case, one must consider the cautery itself.</start_of_turn
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If, however, the Leprosy is severe and does not yield to treatment, as we mentioned previously, and does not descend, neither does it remain: and when it extends over the entire face, including the corruption of the whole complexion: then cauterize the head five times: one in the middle of the head, and the second below it at the edge of the hair, and two on the two horns, and one behind the nape of the neck.</start_of_turn
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And lastly, touch your hand with the cautery nearby, until you make an imprint in the bone, and break from it the layers of cortex: so as to alleviate the emission of thick vapors from it, and cauterize the spleen also, as we have said before.</start_of_turn
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	If, however, the Leprosy is not very widespread over the patient and is evident: then it is necessary to cauterize with these same cauteries that we mentioned in the head, and a cautery on the tip of the nose, and two on the two cheeks, and two on the thyroid cartilage, and six on the vertebrae of the neck, and one large one on the flanks at the joints of the buttocks and one above the genitals: and two on the shoulders: namely one on each shoulder, and two on the elbows, and two on the wrists, and two on the chest. And cauterize the whole of the joints, from the joints of the fingers of the hands and feet, and the heel of the feet.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And take care of the nerves that are above the heel, so that you do not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	When cauterizing with the cautery above the ankle bone, and also above the rib cage, and also above the spleen.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	Know that the more you add the cautery, the greater the damage, and the greater the suffering.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the sick man does not feel pain in the cautery, just as he does not feel it in health: because his body is already stupefied
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	It is necessary that the cautery should be of suitable size, and fine according to the parts and the sutures: according to what precedes from the species of instruments
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the cautery with chaff of herbs with honey, and the rest of the treatment, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	In this way cauterize in the wound
Caput L.	The head of L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When some part is swollen and treated with physicians, and oils, and poultices, and does not heal, then cauterize the swollen part with the cautery, according to the magnitude of the limb or its thickness
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cautery not penetrate too deeply into the thickness of the skin
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguent until it is healed
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And when cauterizing causes any swelling of the hand, foot, in the vertebrae of the back near the outlet of the nerves that move that limb: and it will move the swelling away
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But do not be proud of this, except for one who is learned in the anatomy of the limbs and the course of the nerves moving the body
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	How to cauterize in Albaras.
Caput LI.	How to cauterize in Albaras.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When the Albaras has hardened, and no effect of any medicinal procedure is observed: then cauterize over the cautery itself, somewhat deep, according to the quantity of the thickness of the skin, until the white is restored and the color changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with meal of herbs, and lentils with rose oil, and arnica leaves, and columbic blood, and hyrundine blood: take a little of each: mix them together, and smear over the wound, and bind in place, until healed
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	How to cauterize in Cancer
Caput LII.	How to cauterize in Cancer
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When Cancer is beginning, and you wish to stop it: then cauterize it with the cautery in the circle of its circumference, as it turns over
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	The wise men say, however, that the cautery should be done finally in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	I, however, do not see that: because I fear that it will ulcerate: and I know that I have seen it happen many times
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	It is better to cauterize around it with a circle, as we said: or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	How to cauterize in Adubelati
Caput LIII.	How to cauterize in Adubelati
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When anyone has Adubelati, and it is delayed in maturation, or because of excess fat which makes it limp, or because of age which makes the blood weak, or because of time, and you wish to hasten the maturation of the Adubelati: then cauterize around its circumference with many small cauteries puncturing
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then let go of it.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	Then let go of it. For it will hasten with its growth.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If, however, you wish to perforate it with a cautery, then ignite the cautery, for this is its form
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of the Adubelati, until it pierces the skin: and let the cautery be from that which follows the diseased part, so that it may alleviate the course of the purulent matter.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	In the case of a corrosive ulcer.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 14.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A corrosive ulcer is not except for corruption in a movable limb, and it consumes it: just as fire consumes dry wood
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If, therefore, you wish to cauterize the corrosive one in a place where it tolerates it with fire, then ignite the cautery many times, with small and large claws, according to what will be convenient for the place where the corrosive one is
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from all sides until you have eradicated the whole corruption, and let nothing remain of it inside
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then let it go for three days, and place upon the cauterized place powdered sulphur with oil, until all the pus has been eradicated, and all corruption.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then care for it with nourishing poultices of flesh
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If, therefore, after three days flesh has been born anew in a healthy state, in which there is no corruption, this is good
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then repeat the cautery over that which remains from the corrupted places.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	The corrosive one is to be treated at the same time with acute medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	Indeed, it arises at the place of the cautery.
Caput LV.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	The very same thing arises at the place of the cautery
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then let go of it, for the cavity is erased with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do it like this with one after the other, until you reach above all that is in the body from it.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then take care of them after they are erased, when there is what generates flesh from the pus.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	In Tremore, cauterize in this way.</start_of_turn>
Caput LVI.	Chapter 66.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When it happens to anyone that they have a tremor from cold in a nerve, or from a quartan fever, or from something else: then it is necessary to cauterize it four times, or five over the vertebrae of the back, and between every vertebra cauterize, and in the belly of it cauterize, and over the stomach of it cauterize.</start_of_turn>
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	The tremor will cease with the cautery of oil, and rest will be restored to the health of the cold.</start_of_turn
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	Method of cauterization of Albathir.</start_of_turn
Caput LVII.	Chapter 67.</start_of_turn
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	When there are expelled from the body of Albathir pus, which are made from corrupt great material.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	It is necessary therefore in the first place when they appear to cauterize over every head of the pus with fine cautery with a twig of myrrh whose extremity is kindled with fire.</start_of_turn
