Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you wish to take hold of the limb, and cover it with the medicine, bind the limb with the medicine, and insert the thumb with the finger into the cannula above, until the limb is firmly bound over the wound.</start_of_turn
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this many times, until you follow that you wish for cautery of the limb.</start_of_turn>
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then withdraw the medicine: for it itself will dry and fall off in three days, or four.</start_of_turn
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	If you think it is necessary to repeat the medicine, repeat it: and after the cautery, remove the surrounding parts of the limb with the thumb and immerse them in butter, and anoint with oil what is around the wound: and cool with cold water.</start_of_turn
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And care for the outside with embroidery, and inside with gargles, until healed.</start_of_turn
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	Thus is this kind of treatment safer than an incision and more effective in the fear of complications.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And when the wound has healed even with the medicine which is finer than cautery and incision: it is healed by fumigation, according to this method.</start_of_turn
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	Take calamine, and hyssop, and origanum, and rue, and sassafras, and chamomile, and wormwood, and similar herbs: and mix them all together, or some of them in a pot, and immerse them in vinegar, and boil: and cover the pot with a lid: and there should be a hole in the middle of the pot, above which the instrument is placed in this way.</start_of_turn
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let air or silver issue forth: and let the extremity be introduced into that which contains the pomegranate, until the vapor rises up to the mouth of the cannula, until the mouth becomes very dark.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then proceed over the much, until it boils over.</start_of_turn>
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	Take heed, do not perform this treatment at the beginning of an attack of apoplexy.</start_of_turn>
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	Indeed let some of the powder be added to the apoplexy: and it is not fitting that you should do this except when the apoplexy is in a state of cooling down.</start_of_turn
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If, however, this instrument is not at hand, then take a tube and insert in its extremity a piece of resin or pitch: that it may not burn the bone of the patient: for the resin or pitch will prevent the vapor from burning the bone: and this is a good treatment with safety.</start_of_turn>
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	Concerning the extraction of thorns and bones from the gullet.</start_of_turn>
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.</start_of_turn
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	There adhere to the gut many bones, or fish-spines, or something of the kind.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	It is necessary therefore to extract that which appears to be upon that which falls down into the vomit, after having put the tongue with the instrument at the root of the tongue, and declaring that it is in the gut.</start_of_turn
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And that which does not appear to you and is hidden in the gut, you must make the patient vomit before the food is digested in the stomach.</start_of_turn
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps therefore also the thing annexed will go out with the vomit.</start_of_turn
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or the patient may swallow down a piece of poppyseed, or the root of licorice, or swallow down a dry breadcrumb: or take up a dry piece of sponge-wool and bind it up, then swallow it down.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When the bone or spine has been reached and is extracted, it then departs.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If it does not depart with the former as we said: then use a lead instrument according to this fashion.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than the Radius of a lesser diameter, and at its extremity let there be a curve which intrudes into its gut with ease: and let it itself have its head elevated upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	Beware of its touch to the epiglottis, so that it does not cause it to swell, and drive it forward with the bone, the spine, or let the physician introduce it himself with his hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	Truly that the patient intrudes it, this is better: because of his knowledge of the place of the annexed thing: and he drives downwards, or pulls his hand with the instrument upwards, all this according to the quantity which is prepared for him, until it departs
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	Of the extraction of the blood-sucker
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When the physician treats the blood-sucker with what I have said in the instruction for the cure alongside the physicians, and it does not suffice, then consider in the gut of the patient under the sole of the tongue, or beyond the tongue after having grasped its tongue with the instrument which I mentioned
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If your hand slips from the blood-sucker, extract it with a small hook, or with fine graspings from under.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If this is not possible with these instruments: then grasp a funnel with a wide neck, and introduce the bone into the gut of the patient up to the gut: then introduce a needle with fire at the end into the funnel
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this often: and let the patient abstain from all water throughout the day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then he shall take a full measure of cold water and open the mouth of the patient in it: and he shall join his jaw with it and not swallow anything from it: and he shall drink water an hour after the other with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	The bloodsucker will go away as soon as he feels the water falling.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If he does not go away when we tell him to, then we shall fumigate the patient with sponges, or with an instrument as I told you in the fumigation of the ulcer
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times, for it itself departs.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the manner of operation in fumigation is that you take oil in which there are dates with fire: and the vessel be covered with a cover, in the middle of which there is a hole: and make in that hole the extremity of the instrument.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then he throws the fumigation and places the patient's jaw at the extremity of the tube and closes the jaw, so that it does not escape the fumigation, until you know that the fumigation has passed to the bloodsucker
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the bloodsucker immediately departs.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not depart, then repeat the fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the patient will tolerate sitting and eating garlic and onions, and he will not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	It is necessary therefore that he depart with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the fashion of the instrument with which the bloodsucker is extracted from the gut when it falls over the vomit.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is like tweezers, as for example: except that it has this curvature which enters the gut
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity is like the wing of an ostrich which is called the ciconia, in which is the roughness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	And its extremity is like the wing of an ostrich which is called the ciconia, in which is the roughness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely.
Caput XL.	And its extremity is like the wing of an ostrich which is called the ciconia, in which is the roughness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	And its extremity is like the wing of an ostrich which is called the ciconia, in which is the roughness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	And its extremity is like the wing of an ostrich which is called the ciconia, in which is the roughness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And its extremity is like the wing of an ostrich which is called the ciconia, in which is the roughness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	And its extremity is like the wing of an ostrich which is called the ciconia, in which is the roughness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And its extremity is like the wing of an ostrich which is called the ciconia, in which is the roughness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	And its extremity is like the wing of an ostrich which is called the ciconia, in which is the roughness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	And its extremity is like the wing of an ostrich which is called the ciconia, in which is the roughness of the lime: when it grasps something, it does not relinquish it entirely
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	The abscess is near the main limb: for if you delay the perforation of the latter, until it matures, it will either burst itself or through that main limb.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	The abscess is near the limb: for if you delay the perforation of the latter until it matures, it will either burst itself or through that limb
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You must know the time of perforation of the abscess, for it has matured according to the completion of its complement: and it is in the cessation of pain, reduction of fever, and decrease of redness, and pulse, and intensity of the head of the abscess: and the rest of the signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	You must make the perforation in a lower place of the abscess, and of greater prominence: and let the perforation be wide in length throughout the body, if the abscesses are in the parts of the hands and feet, and places of laceration, and strings, and nerves, and arteries, and finally in all places equally, in which there is no reflection
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	But in those which reflect, proceed with the perforation according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When the abscess is in a place of carnis: then it is better to delay the perforation of the latter until its digestion is confirmed, as we said according to the complement
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you perforate the latter before that, the course of the disease is prolonged, and there is much pain and suffering, and perhaps it bursts through its lips, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And some abscesses are perforated throughout the body for necessity: or according to that which is needed of the limb.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And you must manage in small abscesses a moderate perforation, and in large abscesses a wide perforation: or multiple sections according to the similarity of the size of the abscess
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	There are also from apostematibus, in which it is necessary that the skin should be gathered: and it happens when it has been made like a cloth, and has been made at the end, when it has already died: as it happens with many things, as with wounds and boils.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And there are also those which are severed with a section having three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And there are also those which happen like the shape of a myrtle leaf
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like a heel wound
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And there are also those in which an round section and a lunar section are administered: and similar to these are sections in general.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	That which has no head, like are superficial lenient wounds, must be pierced through with a superficial perforation, or only planed
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it must be, when the wound is great and has collected much blood, that you perforate it, so that you do not leave it and draw out the whole pus at once: better to take out a part of it from it itself
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then anoint the wound until the next day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then draw out some of the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to the degree, until the patient is healed: especially if the patient is weak in spirit, or a pregnant woman, or a young child, or an old man who is decrepit: for the spirit of the animal is resolved with the evacuation of the pus: and perhaps the patient will die, and you will not know it
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore take heed of this chapter, for it gives great care
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have perforated the wound, which is what you do to the wounds, you must remove the clot: and be careful
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If there is a small fistula of the apostematis, either perform a plane section or administer lead from an old vessel.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	If the apostema is large and there are many holes in the perforation, it is necessary to insert lead into every hole until it reaches the bottom
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	If you have cut away a piece of skin from the apostema or have cauterized around its circumference: then you must apply an old vessel or as much lint as when lancets are removed, or you should smear it with lanolin without moisture: and keep it tight until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then remove it and care for it with what is necessary from the unguent until it heals
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If however blood flows at your operation in your hour: then administer cold water and vinegar, after it has been drunk on a piece of bread: and put it over the place of the blood flow many times over
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If the bleeding persists: then it is necessary to administer regimen, care and powders, which I have mentioned in many places of this book, and from experience.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If it is in the winter and the place of the apostema is full of nerves: then it is necessary to infuse sponges with wine and warm oil: and put them over the place.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in the summer and the place is fleshy: then it is necessary to put sponges soaked in water and oil, or in wine and oil, and all of this cold
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until then, as we have said, on the third day you must remove the apostema, drain it, and administer to it what is good for it until it heals
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is everything that is necessary for the knowledge of the treatment of apostemata in general
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the passage of the wound without distinction, as I have said concerning every apostemate, how is the way to its cure capitulated singly.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	According to the passage of the wound without distinction, as I have said concerning every apostemate, how is the way to its cure capitulated singly.
Caput XLI.	The head of the wound is at XLI.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small apostemata occur in the head of the wound and are of the kind of knots which contain tunics, which are like sacks: as if they were chickens' eggs
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	There are many kinds of them
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Some are fat: some contain moisture like mud: some contain moisture like blood clots and pus: some are like those, and some are like stones
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the section of all of them, and in their extraction, there is no fear, as long as during their section it does not make an artery hostile.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	The operation in the section of these is to learn them with the instrument which comes after this, which is called Intromissum, until you know what it contains
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it contains moisture, then dry it out with the superficial section: in this form
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with the section from line b to line g. When the moisture has been evacuated, then remove the knot which contains it, and do not leave anything behind
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	There are many of them which return if anything is left behind
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse the head in Egyptian unguent if it is present: and if not, in water and salt: and press it with a willow twig, and leave it until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	The wound eats away what remains of the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Repeat over the wound with the second and third fingers, and if you find that it does not yield, continue until you are confident that nothing remains of the cyst, and then indeed cure the wound with oil until it is healed
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If there is a fatty node remaining in the wound: then dry the wound according to this fashion, making a section in the shape of a cross: and bring out the nails between the two layers of the section, and cleanse the wound from all sides: and attempt your skill in extracting the membrane which contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If, however, there is resistance from an artery, then do that which I shall tell you afterwards.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And in the case of a stone in the wound, do the same by section and treatment as before
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	The section of a stone in the wound is easier: because there is little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are some wounds of this kind which are in the head of some people, in which there is no humidity.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is: because I dried over the wound in the head of a woman who was pregnant, and I found the wound like a solid and hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if I pierced it with anything, it would burst open
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other wounds of this kind which happen in the head, except for those which happen in the heads of children, and near the roots of the ears, the section of them is a superficial section
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or make the perforation of them always from the lower part upwards, so as to aid the flow of healing downwards.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for it with whatever is suitable for it from the care.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	Then care for it with whatever is suitable for it from the care of the throat
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	Many of these swellings occur in the throat, under the armpits, and in the groin: and sometimes in the rest of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And concerning those which occur in the throat, there is one kind, and many: and they are generated from a single cause: for every Strophula originates from its own tunic, as in the nodes and swellings of the head, as we have stated
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of these swellings
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from these things there are fat ones: and there are those which hold moisture: and there are malignant ones, which do not obey treatment
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In this way, if there are good-dispositioned liquids in the touch, whose mark is the proximity of the colour of the skin, and which move to every part, and are not connected with the nerves of the throat, neither with the gullet nor the arteries, nor is it deep: it is necessary to section it superficially from the upper part to the lower part of the body from the line A to line B, and to excise the skin from all sides: and to spread out two lips of the skin with one finger, or with many fingers, if necessary, as we have said concerning the swellings of the head, and to extract it slowly.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is necessary to be cautious not to damage the bone, or the nerve
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And the sponge should not be acutely pointed: so as not to add your hand to the incision, or to frighten the patient, and to cut what is not necessary
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If, however, you cut a vein, or an artery, or are hindered by the operation, then put in the wound a lump of charcoal, or some powders which bleed, and tighten the wound, and let it go, until the pain subsides after the operation, and the wound is softened: or else it will begin to putrefy.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	Or else blood will be shed too much for the operation, and will return to the operation before it is complete.</start_of_turn>
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then ask your finger again, if anything remains of the other trocars: if so, cut easily, and wash easily.</start_of_turn>
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If indeed there is in the root of the trocar a large vessel: then you must avoid cutting that vessel from its root: rather you must bind it with a doubled strong thread, and let it go until it drops by itself without any nourishment.</start_of_turn>
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound with oil of the elder, which you have immersed in Egyptian unguent.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then take care of yourself.</start_of_turn>
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the trocar is completely cut, then you must gather together the two lips of the wound: and hold them in place immediately, after you have washed because if you do not there will remain excess.</start_of_turn
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If indeed there remains excess blood because of the greatness of the trocar, then you must extend to the cutting of its root and extract it: and administer a suture as we have said.</start_of_turn
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And what remains of the trocars should be moistened, perforate it with a superficial perforation: so that you may see the seat of its maturity: and put the perforation from below what follows the body, as we have said.</start_of_turn
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the perforation lint with unguent, and like this, remove what remains of the corruption, until when blood has become softened: then take care of yourself with the unguent of generation of flesh, until it is healed.</start_of_turn
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the excision of the epiglottis from the apostemate within the guttur by chance.
Caput XLIII.	On the excision of the epiglottis from the apostemate within the guttur by chance.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	They say that the ancients performed this excision of the epiglottis, and none of them in our land have been able to do so: and this is the account of the elders.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	However, in acute cases of synanchiam, it is necessary to excise the epiglottis: because without it there is no remedy for the pain: for all the veins and the lung are diseased.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In these cases, where there is a hard apostemate in the mouth, or the guttur, or the two amygdales, when there is no inflammation in the canal, it is necessary to perform an excision of the epiglottis to escape from the destruction which is caused by the projection
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	It is necessary therefore, when we wish to do this, to excise the epiglottis under three or four circles of the epiglottis, with a small section through the thickness, at that place where there is a recess between two circles, because that is the most convenient place for the excision, because it is devoid of flesh, and the blood vessels from it are long
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the physician is timid, then it is necessary to extend the skin of the guttur with a finger
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then find the skin until you reach the canal: there will be blood vessels there, if there is anything there.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then cut the thickness as we have said: and it is signified over the section of the canal by the phlegm which comes out of it, when it is ruptured, and by the cutting of the vein.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And withdraw the wound open for a while at some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When the hour has passed in which the focus is complete, gather two lips of the wound together and sew them alone without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then apply medicines which cause the flesh to grow back until the wound is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Albucasis says.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	This is all that Albucasis says about the matter which we have mentioned: that when some part of the body has become gangrenous and the patient is still conscious, the physician should immediately cut through the swelling to prevent the patient from suffocating: for as long as the swelling persists, life hangs in the balance. Therefore they order the wound to be opened until the mischief of the disease has passed away, which mischief commonly lasts for three days and is like itself: then indeed do they order the wound to be sutured up again, and to care for it until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And this, which I have just seen myself, happened that a maidservant took a knife and put it into her mouth, and it went into a part of her windpipe.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	I was called to care for her, and I found her foaming at the mouth, just as one who is dead.</start_of_turn>
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I saw that from the wound blood had flowed out.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I am confident that if she had not been cut open she would have died, neither could I discover any wound: and the wind was coming out of the wound.</start_of_turn
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I treated her accordingly, and closed up the wound, and cared for her until she was healed: and the maidservant suffered no further harm, except for the wound in her mouth: and she recovered after three days to her former health.</start_of_turn
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Hence it is said: there is no fear in the section of the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	Hence it is said: there is no fear in the section of the epiglottis.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLIV.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This section is called the hernia gutturis, which is a large swelling, according to the colour of the body: and it is very common in women
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is according to two modes: either it is natural: or it is accidental
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	In the natural one there is certainly no malice.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	The accidental one, however, is according to two modes: one of which is like a swelling of fat nodules
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	The other mode is like a swelling from the bursting of an artery
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in this there is fear, and it is not right to assume that it is like that with the steel, except in that case where it is slight: and you must try it and investigate it with the intestines.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If you find it like a fat nodule, and there is no suspicion of any other vessel: then dry it out, just as you would cut away a nodule: and extract it with that which contains the swelling, if there is one: and if not, then to search all around it
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with that which is necessary for the cure, until it is healed
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	Hence it is said: there is no fear in the section of the epiglottis
Caput XLV.	Chapter XLV
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of nodules, and I have mentioned all of them in the enumeration: and it is necessary to know the difference between a node and an extrusion when there is doubt
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say therefore, when the evacuation is complete, warmth, fever, and pain cease until the superabundance of humours is dissipated, and decay is completed: then indeed fever and heat subside.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When the abscess is evacuated, neither warmth, nor fever, nor pain remain, until the humours are perfectly balanced, which is the natural state of the body: and this is the cause of the cicatrix and the bathes, which are greater and less.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	There are two kinds: either dry or moist
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	The colours of moisture are many, as I have said previously
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	It is necessary therefore, when one proceeds to the treatment of the abscess, to test it, and to inquire about it at first with the instrument which is called the Intromissum, according to the form of which will be described later.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	The way to inquire about the abscess, and of all abscesses, is to take this instrument and introduce it into the moist place which you find in the abscess: and withdraw your fingers gradually until you know that the instrument has pierced the skin
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then lastly touch the hand according to the measure of the abscess.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then withdraw the Intromissum, and consider what comes out through its wound
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore moisture comes out running of any colour: then dry it superficially, as I have said of other abscesses
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	If not, you know that it is dry: dry it therefore superficially with a section having the shape of a cross, as it has been taught you: and bind it with ligatures, and scrape away the skin from all sides with ease: and keep the abscess if you are able, until you have evacuated it whole
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If, however, the bladder is ruptured during the operation, and it is not possible to extract it whole, much the same happens in this case, then extract it piecemeal until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	Or if anything remains of it, even a little or a lot, the procedure returns to the beginning according to the majority of people
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If it causes you to doubt, and anything remains of it, then place a sponge wet with corrosive powders on the completion of your work: and bind the sponge, and place above it what rests upon the soft cushion, and care for it with the rest of the treatment until it heals
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If there is a large node, then two of its lips must be opened, and care for it with that which enters it.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If, however, there is a swelling of the bone or which is not pulsating: then straighten it out, and place a dressing over the wound, and leave it loose for two or three days, until the sponge putrefies and the boiling of the blood subsides: then return to the work which remains from the Node.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	About the instruments outside which are for section and perforation.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVII.</start_of_turn>
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	From these there are three forms of instruments which are introduced, and there are three kinds.</start_of_turn>
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	From these there is a large one, and a medium one, and a small one.</start_of_turn
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let them be of iron, rounded at the extremities and flattened in the middle, so that they may hasten the entrance into the bladder.</start_of_turn
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of the instruments of those who have experience, and no, that is, perforators: and one of them is called the beris, that is, the perforator, and there are three kinds.</start_of_turn
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	From the inside outwards is great, medium, and small.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	The structures extend from the center outwards, namely bones, joints, exits, fistulas and abscesses
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	They are round, triangular, blunt like a large needle which bites under the skin, from lemon juice indeed, or from air, or iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	The best of them are those that are made from lemon juice.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	There is also experience with black lead which comes together so that they may perceive fistulas through their reflection, which are reflected with their smoothness against those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	There are three kinds of them.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For indeed from the inside outwards are great, medium, and small according to the quantity of the diameter of the fistula and the degree of its constriction
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The shapes of these are diverse, and there are many kinds of them.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	For indeed from the inside outwards are simple, that is to say those which have only one curvature: and there are three kinds of them like liquids, great, medium, and small
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from the inside outwards are blind neighbours: and there are three kinds of them
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from the inside outwards are nails having two curvatures, and there are three kinds of them: and those which have three curvatures, and there are three kinds of them: all of them are necessary in their place
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	These are the forms of scalpels with which one severs and excoriates nodes and abscesses: and there are three kinds of them for indeed from the inside outwards are great, medium and small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities which are for the cutting are acute, the other extremities are not acute: and they are not placed thus, except when there is an intention to make an incision in the nerve or vein, and to cause an abrasion of the node at the same time, and in order to cure the patient and bring him peace rather than to aggravate the inflammation of the abscess
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are Magda, and are three in number.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	These are Magda, and are three in number.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The shape of the sponges which go between the fingers at the perforation of the apostem: these are not perceived by the patient. There are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	The shape of the sponges which absorb the flow of blood: these are three kinds, large, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be of air or citrine, round, of equal length somewhat like liquids: and they must be firm.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of sponges should be both large and small: in order to absorb the blood with speed when necessary, and then again when it is not necessary for the physician to be present
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	But do not use them for the absorption of blood in every part of the body, and do not use them except in places where there is carnation: such as for wounds of the leg, and hip, and wounds of the arm, and breast, and belly, and groin, and similar wounds of carnation, wetness
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes other small things like sponges, similar to the cortices of fists, are used for the absorption of blood when it flows from the site of phlebotomy, or at the incision of a vein or artery: and sometimes they are round like this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	Concerning the care of the breasts of women who suckle the breasts of their children.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When the breasts of some men swell somewhat during the night (that is to say, when they begin to become soiled during sleep) until they resemble the breasts of women: and they remain with the nipples hardened.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever abominates at this thing should cut across the breast with a lunar section, according to this form from the line A to the line G. Then scrape away the fat completely
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	After that, the physician must extract the stone from the body.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then he must join together the two lips of the wound with sutures, and care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If, however, the breast inclines downwards and is softened by its size, as is the case with women: then it is necessary to find two points on the two upper sides of the breast, similar in shape to a crescent moon, and join each one to the other at the ends so that one line is greater than the other, following the form from the line, b. to the line, g. Then, after that, scrape the skin between the two lips and remove the fat, and administer what has been said concerning the sutures and powders, which is necessary for the cure, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If, however, you do not wish to make an incision because of the patient's anxiety or because of the flow of blood: then you must extract the stone under the skin with corrosive unguent, and let it go, until that which remains of the fat has corroded.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	As for the perforation of the kidney, which happens under the rib.</start_of_turn
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.</start_of_turn
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These kidneys which happen under the rib are of the kind called Strophularia dura, which contain a bladder, and from these are the humdities which proceed.</start_of_turn
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Which are from the humdities which contain moisture, must be sectioned in a crescent shape, following the form from the line b. to the line g., and when all that is in the kidney is evacuated from the blood, then extract the stone from the kidney, and let it go until another day.</start_of_turn
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the heel is raised up, and cared for with a suitable unguent until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the heel were of the kind of knots called Strophulas, then it should be cut above that, as we mentioned in the section on Strophulas that are equal
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If, however, a swelling extends in this way as to emit pus, then administer cauterium in it, according to what we mentioned previously in this respect.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	Concerning the section of the heel which happens because of the artery and the vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When the artery is ruptured, and the skin above it is consolidated, then there is a great swelling of the heel in this way: and in the same way there is swelling in the veins also, as in this heel and swelling.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that the heel swelling and swelling are because of the artery and vein, are these: because when the heel is swollen because of the artery, it is long, aggregated in the depth of the body: and when the covering of the heel is grasped by the fingers, it feels as though there is a constriction there
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is because of the vein, is rounded in the manifest body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section of this heel is an error, and especially under the heel bone, and the ankle bone, and the throat, and in many parts of the body: and it is very dangerous
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	It is necessary therefore that its care be taken with iron, and that it be taken out from the extremities, or from the head, for in all these places.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	For concerning that which is from the swelling of the opening of the artery, find in the cut in the length on the surface of the heel.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the part with hooks, afterwards the Artery: and free it from the tunic until it is detached.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce the hook under that [tissue], and make the incision pass through to the other side, and bind the Artery with a doubled thread in two places, as you have been taught in the extraction of two Arteries which are in the flanks
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then puncture the place which is between the two ligaments with the sponge, until the blood which is in it all comes out, and it is dissolved afterwards.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then give attention to the formation of pus, until the ligaments are gone: afterwards care for it with suitable unguents until it is healed.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If there should be a swelling on account of the section of a Vein, then it is necessary that you should hold your hand as much as possible over the swelling with the skin
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce the hook under the place where you held your hand, and make the incision: and there be in it a doubled thread, until you draw it out from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then bind with it the swelling with a strong ligament: according to what I have told you concerning the ligation of the veins, from two parts with two extremities of thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If however you think that the thread is to be drawn out, then introduce another hook with another thread under the whole swelling at the incision of the needle: beforehand, and bind your thread in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry the swelling in the middle of it, until when it comes out what is in it: then cut away the excess of the skin, and let go what is bound from it
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put over it a little powder which you have submerged in wine, and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then give attention to the treatment which is done with liniments and unguents, until it is healed
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	Of the swelling which happens from the twisting of nerves.
Caput L.	Of the swelling which happens from the twisting of nerves.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	As in the case of swelling which happens in an artery or vein, in the same way swelling can happen in nerves: which can happen either through percussion or from excessive labour, or from like causes: and it is most frequent in the armpits, or the calves, or in any place where there is a joining of nerves: and it is a serious swelling.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	It is similar in colour to the rest of the body, and is to be found in various positions without pain: and when it is squeezed with pressure, a feeling of faintness similar to that of drunkenness is perceived in it
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	It is not a deep-seated swelling of the body, but rather under the skin, and it moves to all parts, and does not go forward or backward, or to the rear
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Since it is from the nerves which are in the joints, it does not need to be treated with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps it will happen that there will be a contraction.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But in that which is from the nerves of the head, or the face, find the skin with a spatula.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If it is a slight swelling, then hold it with forceps, and cut it away from its root
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If it is large, then suspend it with a thread, and remove it: then gather up the surrounding tissue, and sew it together: and take care of it until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Of the cutting away of the swelling which happens inside.</start_of_turn>
Caput LI.	Of the cutting away of the swelling which happens inside.</start_of_turn
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	These often happen to many people in the insides of their bodies, and in the rest of their bodies, these are called Fungae, because of their resemblance to fungi.</start_of_turn
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	When the root is slender and the head is bulky, and the lips are closed together.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	The root is slender, the head is bulky, and the lips are closed.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And indeed I saw a man who had two boils in his belly, which were greater than any other like mushrooms: there was no difference between them, the white, the black, the large root, and their colour was dark.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	I saw a man who had two boils in his belly, which were larger than any others like mushrooms. There was no difference between them, whether white, black, large or small root, and their colour was dark. I therefore cut them open, and I found in each one almost 18 ounces in one and 6 ounces in the other. And the operation of their incision is as you consider, if the patient is humidus, and the colour of the boils is white, humidum, subtilis radicis: then cut through with a spatula and there will be seen in your presence their caecum in the fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	A great deal of blood is expelled at the incision: be careful therefore if you are inundated by blood, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see the patient pale and timid from the incision with the iron, then take a leaden thread from the centre and tie it with it: its method is as we have said, and leave it for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add lead in stricture.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Do not cease tying the lead until it has burst through, and has fallen without work
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If the boils are large of the root, then in their incision there is something timid and fearful: especially because of what is in their belly
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	However, it is possible to cut through the middle of them.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then cure it so that it does not return.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And do not presume to cut that which is like a dark-blue spot, little sensation, bad aspect: for that is the head of cancer: and I shall remind you of cancer afterwards.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	About the care of the navel
Caput LII.	Chapter 52
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	The navel becomes prominent from many wounds
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from cuts that are over the belly: and comes out through that or the intestines, according as it happens in other ruptures
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from the blood which flows from the vein, or from the artery, as is reported
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from the clotted blood in it
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If however it is by a cut of the belly, and the discharge of the tumor: then is the color of the tumor similar in color to that of the body: and is soft, without pain: and appears in various places.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is by the discharge of the intestines, then is its place with that which we mentioned, of greater diversity
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you touch it with your fingers, it is hidden: then it returns, and perhaps makes a sound: and swells greatly at the entrance of the bath, and great labor.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If however it is by humidity, it is soft: then it is not hidden when you touch it with your hand, neither is it compressed, neither does it adhere
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	Which if by blood, then appears with these signs the tumor is black like soot
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If, however, it is because of meat that has died: then it is a severe, bulky, hard abscess, and it forms according to the quantity of one.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If, however, it is because of an infected wound: then its touch is gentle
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation in that is, as you consider, if the prominence of the navel is because of blood of an artery or vein, or infection: then it is necessary to refrain from its care.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in that is fear and danger, as I taught you in the chapter where I spoke of abscesses caused by an artery or vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the prominence of the navel is because of an intestine or a tumor: then it is necessary to remove the sick part, as long as it retains its natural movement, and to leave it extended
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with incisions around the whole navel.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then command him to rest his hand over his back
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then surround with a piece of lint about the circumference of the navel over the place where you made the incision with the knife
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the middle of the abscess upwards, with a large loop.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie it firmly in the circumference with a strong thread, or with silk thread: and let the knot of the thread be firm.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the middle of the abscess that is extended above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If, however, you find that you have captured the gut with the ligament: then draw out the knot that is alenxoted, and introduce your finger into the gut, and push the intestine inwards: and if you find a tumor, then grasp it with a loop, and cut off its excess
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If, however, the artery or vein is opposite, surround it much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your work.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles and pass them through two strong threads: and pass two needles through the circumference which you made around the swelling like a cross, which you make penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the swelling in four places over the needle: and if you wish, remove the needle and leave the place, until the extended flesh putrefies: and it will fall away by itself: or cut it when it subsides and putrefies.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it as you deem necessary from the unguents, until it heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If there is a swelling of the navel from the flesh or from moisture: then it is necessary to concave the swelling, as we have said
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And extract the blood or moisture which you find in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then care for it until the place is healed
¶ De cura CANCRI.	(End of excerpt
Caput LIII.	(End of Book 53
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	As we have said in the explanation of the species of cancer, and how it is to be treated by doctors: and caution should be taken with it in treatment with iron, so that it does not ulcerate: and we have said cancer is generated in the matrix, and caution should be taken with its treatment.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients have said that when cancer is in a place where it is possible to eradicate it: such as cancer which is in the breast, or in the hip, and in similar places, from the limbs which are to be removed in their entirety: especially when it is just beginning and small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When it is old and great, it is not proper to approach it
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	I am unable to heal anyone from this: neither do I know of anyone who has preceded me who was able to do so.
