Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	The operation in this case, when the organ is positioned as we have described, is to precede and evacuate the diseased part from black bile occasionally
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then let a bloodletting be done if necessary when the swelling is obvious.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the patient for the operation, in which the diseased part is placed alongside the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then place over the wound the nails which meet it
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then concave it from all sides with the skin, according to the prescription, until nothing remains of its roots: and let the blood flow out, and do not cut it off quickly, but rather express the place and drain all the thick blood you can, or as much as possible with the instruments
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If, however, it makes the blood flow excessively from the incision of an artery or vein: then cauterize the vein, until the bleeding stops
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the patient with the remaining care, until he is healed.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	(The text continues with instructions on treating hydrops.)
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 14.</start_of_turn>
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We shall speak in this section of the different kinds of hydrops, and how water is collected: and the signs of each kind, and their treatment with physicians.</start_of_turn>
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is cured with iron is not except the single kind of ascites: and is not approached with iron in the kind of tympani: neither in the kind of hypospasmus: for that is deadly.</start_of_turn
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you are treated for this kind of hydrops of the tympani with the physicians, and the treatment does not suffice: then consider it.</start_of_turn
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	If a patient has already been affected by weakness, or is accompanied by other diseases besides Hydropsism: such as if there are tussi or solution of the intestines, and similar conditions: then do not treat him with iron.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	If, however, the physician be of a robust spirit, and there be nothing besides Hydropsism: neither young nor old: then the mode of operation in such a case is that thou shalt elevate the patient upon thy hands, and the minister will express the abdomen with his hand, driving out the contents into the lower part of the belly
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a sponge of thorns, according to this shape.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	Sit two acute angles, long, with acute extremities like a Sponge of Thorns.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	There is indeed something of shortness of breath gradually present, so that thou pass not thereby through the operation until thou reach the intestines, and sealest the wound.
Deinde considera.	Consider carefully.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	If indeed there is a generation of Hydropsism from the part of the intestines, then it is necessary to lengthen with a section from the navel to the amount of three fingers below the belly button
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	If indeed the generation of Hydropsism is on account of the disease of the liver: then thy incision shall be on the left side from the navel to the amount of three fingers.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if the generation of it is on account of the spleen: then the incision is on the right side: and it is not necessary also that the incision should be on the side which thou wilt cause the patient to vomit, so that no excess blood flow to the delicate place.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then perforate with the instrument the whole skin
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then introduce into that section the Sponge of Thorns, and elevate thy hand with the Sponge between the skin, and draw out, as if thou art scraping it: and the quantity which thou shalt draw out shall be equal to the quantity of a nail, or thereabouts
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then perforate the sac, until it reaches Spatumile at a void place: and that is the place of water.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then extract it, and introduce it into the opening of the instrument, which has this shape
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	It is like a cannula: it is made of silver, or brass, or gold, flexible, thin: which has in its lower part a small opening, and on its sides are three holes, two from one side, and one from the other side: and its extremity is cut off, according to the manner of the cut of a needle, like water: in its upper part is an armlet
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	For when the instrument reaches the water, then it immediately descends over the instrument, ergo it evacuates from the water in an hour the quantity of a middle
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	For if you evacuate from it more than is necessary, in an hour perhaps the patient dies from the resolution of the spirit of his animal: or it happens to him fainting which approaches death.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	But evacuate from it according to the quantity of its virtue, and according to what is significant to you the state of the patient from the virtue of his pulse, and from his strength
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	Then extract the instrument, and retain the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	For it is retained immediately because of the skin which retains the opening which is over the sac: of which I have spoken, that you must perforate it according to the light of the mode.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	Then repeat the instrument every other day, if the water tolerates the patient: and extract also from the water the quantity that is appropriate.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	Do this every few days without fear, and take care from error: until there remains from the water nothing but a little bit.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.	If however you fear the patient, and you discharge from the water a great quantity: then take care of him with burial in warm sand, and with much sweating in the bath and in the sun, and expect upon the seat: and take care of him with physicians of experience, until he is healed: and cauterize upon the stomach, and the flank, and the spleen, after the extraction of the water: according to what I have said before
¶ De cura infantium qui nascuntur locis urinae eorum non perforatis.	Concerning the care of infants who are born in the urinary tract areas which are not perforated.
Caput LV.	Concerning the care of infants who are born in the urinary tract areas which are not perforated.
Quando egreditur aliquis infantium ex uentre matris suae, et caput mutonis eius est non perforatum, aut est foramen strictum, aut in non suo loco.	When any infant emerges from the mother's womb, and the head of the fetus is not perforated, or there is a stricture or is out of place
Oportet ergo succurrere cum perforatione eius statim cum nascitur cum Spatumili subtili ualde, secundum hanc formam.	When any infant emerges from the mother's womb, and the head of the fetus is not perforated, or there is a stricture or is out of place, it is necessary to perform an opening immediately when it is born with a fine needle, according to this method.
Deinde pone in foramine clauum subtilem ex plumbo, et liga ipsum: et tene ipsum tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then put in the hole a small lead weight, and bind it: and keep it closed for three days, or four
Quando ergo uult urinam emittere, remoueatur, et mingat.	When it is time for the infant to urinate, loosen it, and mix it up
Deinde reduc ipsum.	Then reduce it.
Et si tu non ponis plumbum, iam possibile est, ut urina quae incedit super locum, non permittat ipsum claudi.	And if you do not put in lead, it is possible that the urine which passes over the place will not permit it to close
Ille autem cuius foramen est strictum, medicatur cum plumbo, sicut diximus, diebus multis, donec amplificetur.	The one whose opening is strict is treated with lead, as we have said, for many days, until it becomes wide open.
Illi autem in quibus est foramen in non suo loco, laeduntur.	The one in which the opening is out of place, they are treated with lead.
Quod est, quia ex eis qui nascitur, foramen est apud finem capitis uirgae: quare non potest mingere ad anteriora, donec eleuat uirgam manu sua ad superiora.	Because the opening is at the end of the fetus's head: which cannot mix forward until it raises the head upwards.
Neque est ei generatio, propterea, quod sperma non potest peruenire ad matricem secundum rectitudinem: et est aegritudo foeda ualde.	Neither is there any generation, for this reason, because the sperm cannot pass beyond the matrix following a straight line: and it is a grievous wound of the needle.
Et modus operationis in illo est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum.	And the method for doing this is that the infirmant is placed over his back
Deinde extende caput uirgae eius manu tua sinistra extensione uehementi, et incide caput capitis uirgae ex loco priapi, cum acumine, aut spatumili acuto: sicut est incisio calami, aut sicut tu radis aliquid, ut medium eius ueniat simile capiti uirgae: et ut cadat foramen in medio secundum quod oportet.	Then extend the head of the fetus with your left hand with stretching, and make an incision of the head of the fetus from the groin downwards, with a needle, or with a sharp needle like a chisel, as with the cutting of a nail, or as with the root of something, so that the middle of the wound may resemble the head of the fetus: and so that the opening may be in the middle as it should be
Et caue tibi apud operationem tuam a fluxu sanguinis.	And take care that during your operation you are protected from the flow of blood.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	Much of the time this happens.
Oppone ergo ei cum eo quod abscindit sanguinem, et cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Counteract this with that which binds the blood, and take care of the wound until it is healed.
¶ De Albather quae accidunt in praeputio et capite uigae, et corruptione, nigredine, et adhaerentia.	Concerning the accidents which happen in the preparation of the wound and the head of the vein, and corruption, bruising, and adhesion.
Caput LVI.	Chapter LXVI.
Multotiens accidunt istae Albather in uirga, et est eminentia carnis foedae.	Many of these accidents happen in the flesh, and are the prominence of the damaged flesh
Et ex ea alia est maligna, et alia non maligna.	And from these there are both malignant and non-malignant things
Non malignam ergo oportet ut suspendas cum uncino subtili, et abscindas eam, donec mundes eam totam.	The malignant things must be suspended with a fine thread and cut away, until the whole thing is cleansed
Deinde pone super eam cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio.	Then put over the wound a covered bandage in Egyptian unguent
Deinde cura ipsum post illud cum unguento dyafinicon, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with fine unguent until it is healed
Quod si Albather est maligna, foedi coloris, tunc oportet ut administres in ea cauterium post incisionem eius et ipsius rasionem.	If the accident is malignant, dark-red in colour, then it is necessary to administer cauterium on it after the incision and to know its cause
Si autem Albather est in praeputio captiui, non circumcisi, et est pars Albather inter praeputium, et pars eius extra: tunc oportet ut auferas Albather, quae est intus in primis, donec quando consolidatur, tunc cura ipsum exterius: quoniam quando tu curas eam simul, non securatur praeputium quin preforetur.	If, however, the accident is in the head of the vein, not circumcised, and is a part of the accident which is between the preparation and that which is outside: then it is necessary to ligate the accident which is inside first, until it is consolidated, and then take care of the outside: for when you take care of the outside while neglecting the inside, the preparation will be torn away
Et iam accidunt etiam in testiculis, et praeputio nigredo et corruptio.	And also in the testicles, and blackening of the preparation and corruption
Oportet ergo, ut tu concaues totum quod iam denigratum est, et quod uult corrumpi, aut iam corruptum est.	You must therefore remove all that is blackened and corrupted, or that wants to corrupt
Deinde line super ipsum post illud cum melle quod iam concussum est cum farina corticum granatorum, et herbi tritorum cribellatorum.	Then the line above the navel with the honey which is consumed with barley flour and trefoil herbs which are crushed.
Deinde cura illud cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for that with the rest of the treatment until healed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra cauterium cum cauterio lunari, secundum hanc formam.	If blood flow increases, then administer the cautery with a lunar cautery, according to this form.
Cauterium enim est iuuatiuum ad duas dispositiones simul, scilicet ad fluxum sanguinis, et uulnus quando corrumpitur.	The cautery is applied to two positions simultaneously, namely for the blood flow and for the swelling when the flesh is corrupted
Quod si corroditur caput uirgae, et destruitur totum in hora: tunc oportet ut intromittas in meatum priapi cannulam ex plumbo, ut mingat infirmus super eam.	If the head of the worm is eaten away and the whole thing is destroyed in an hour: then it is necessary to introduce lead into the meat of the worm so that the diseased part may mix with the wound above the wound
In adhaerentia uero praeputii cum capite uirgae, et haec quidem adhaerentia non accidit, nisi in eo cuius praeputium est sanum, et non exigitur super ipsum circumcisio: et quandoque accidit adhaerentia propter uulnus, aut apostema: oportet ergo ut excories eam cum Spatumili obtuso, donec soluatur ligamentum, et liberetur caput uirgae ab omni parte.	In the adherence of the belly with the head of the worm, and these adnexions do not take place except in that case where the belly is sound and the surrounding area does not require excision: and when these adnexions happen because of a wound or swelling: it is necessary to strip away the wound with blunt spatula until the ligament is severed and the head of the worm is freed from all parts.
Quod si est difficile discernere ea exquisite, tunc oportet ut excories aliquid ex capite uirgae, et ex praeputio.	If it is difficult to discern these subtleties, then it is necessary to strip away something from the head of the worm and from the belly
Quod est, quia praeputium quando est subtile, fortasse perforatur propter subtilitatem suam uelociter.	For the belly is subtle, perhaps it is perforated because of its slightness or quickly
Deinde separa inter praeputium, et caput uirgae cum panno lini subtili, qui iam madefactus est in aqua frigida, ut non adhereant iterum.	Then separate the belly from the head of the worm with a fine linen cloth which has been made wet in cold water, so that they do not adhere again
Deinde curetur cum uino stiptico, donec consolidetur.	Then care for it with vinegar plaster, until it heals.
¶ De mundificatione infantium, et curatione ex errore eis accidente.	About the care of infants, and the treatment of errors and accidents.
Caput LVII.	Chapter LVII.
Circumcisio non est solutio continuitatis, sicut reliqua uulnera: uerumtamen cum sit ex operatione nostra, uoluntate nostra, et usus eius sit in pueris proprie, est necesse ut signemus in ea operationem meliorem, et uiam leuiorem perducentem ad salutem.	Circumcision is not a solution for the continuity of things like other wounds: however, when it is done by our operation, by our will, and when its use is in children of their own kind, it is necessary that we sign that we have done this operation for the better, and that we have not diminished the pain to the patient.
Dico ergo, quod antiqui non dixerunt circumcisionem in aliquo suorum librorum: quoniam non utuntur in legibus suis, et non est nisi quod acquisiuimus per experimentum.	I say, that the ancients did not speak of circumcision in any of their books: for they did not use it in their laws, and there is no reason except that we have learned through experience.
Quod est, quia ego inueni maiorem partem artificum, et phlebotomatorum uti mundificatione, circumcidendo cum nouacula, et cum forficibus: et utuntur alfecati, et ligaudo cum filo, et incisione cum ungula.	Because I have found that the greatest part of artifices, and of phlebotomists, consists in making incisions with a knife and with scissors: and that they use ligatures with thread and needles, and make incisions with nails.
Et ego quidem iam probaui omnes istos modos, et non inueni meliorem mundificatione cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo.	I have also tried all these methods, and I have not found a better way of making the wound than with scissors, and of tying up with thread.
Quoniam in mundificatione cum nouacula, multotiens effugit cutis.	For in making the wound with a knife, much skin is driven away.
Quoniam cutis praeputii duas habet tunicas: ergo forsitan inciditur cutis superior, et temanet tunica inferior: cogitur ergo ad incisionem ad incidendum alteram, et dolorem futurum.	For the skin of the prepuce has two tunics: therefore perhaps the upper skin is split, and the lower tunic is threatened: it is therefore necessary to make an incision in order to split the other, and to avoid future pain
Et cum mundificatione quae fit per alfecati, id est, digitalis, quo utuntur sutores, non securatur incisio extremitatis uirilis membri: quoniam fortasse ingreditur in foramen eius.	And when the making of the wound is done by the fingers, that is, by the nails of the fingers, as the surgeons do, the incision is not secured at the extremity of the member: for perhaps it will enter through its hole
In mundificatione autem cum ungula, fortasse euadit ferrum, et corrumpit operationem tuam: et cutis quidem pueri est breuis natura, et multotiens nascuntur taliter, quod non indigent mundificatione: et iam uidi illud.	And in making the wound with a nail, perhaps the iron will slip, and will spoil your work: and the skin of the child is short in nature, and many are made like this, which does not befit the making of the wound: I say this indeed
Mundificationis autem cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo, bonum experimentum detexit mihi: quoniam forfices sunt proportionalis incisionis: propterea, quod acuitas quae est superius, est sicut acuitas quae est inferius.	But with the making of the wound with scissors, and the tying up with thread, I have found a good experiment: for the scissors are proportional to the incision: therefore, as the height which is above is like that which is below.
Cum ergo premis manum tuam, proportionantur duae acuitates, et incidunt secundum operationem unam in tempore uno: et fit compressio simili figura, continens cutem uirgae ab omni parte, cum qua non cadit error omnino.	When you have done with your hand, the two acute angles proportion themselves, and they occur according to one operation in one time: and there is a compression similar in figure, containing the skin of the wound from every part, so that no error is left out.
Et modus operationis propriae est, ut facias extimare, puerum praecipue, si est ex eis qui intelligunt parumper, quod tu non facis, nisi quod ligas filum in uirga sua tantum: et dimittas ipsum usque ad diem alium.	The proper method of the operation is to make an excision, especially for the puerulus, if there is one who understands it well, because you must not leave it unless you ligate the thread in its place: and you dismiss it until another day.
Deinde fac eum gaudere et laetari omnimodo quo possibile est tibi illud, ex eo quod recipit intelligentia sua.	Then make him rejoice and be glad in every way possible from this which he receives with his understanding.
Deinde fac eum stare inter manus tuas praeparatae staturae, et non sit sedens: et occulta forfices in manica tua, aut sub pede tuo, ne uideat eos puer omnino, neque aliquid ex instrumentis.	Then make him stand between your prepared hands, and do not sit: and hide the shears in your sleeve or under your foot, so that the boy does not see them, nor anything of the instruments.
Deinde intromitte manum tuam ad uirgam eius, et suffla in cutem, et trahe eam sursum, donec egrediatur caput uirgae.	Then insert your hand into the wound and blow on the skin, and draw it up, until the head of the wound comes out.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex eo quod aggregatur in ea sordicie.	Then wipe away that which is gathered in that cavity.
Deinde liga locum signatum cum filo duplo.	Then ligate the marked place with double thread
Postea liga inferius eo parumper ligamentum secundum.	Then ligate the lower part somewhat more loosely than the upper ligament
Deinde tene cum indice tuo, et pollice locum ligamenti inferioris retentione bona, et incide inter duo ligamenta.	Then hold with your index finger and thumb the place of the lower ligament securely, and cut between the two ligaments.
Deinde eleua cutem sursum uelociter, et extrahe caput uirgae.	Then raise the skin up quickly, and pull out the head of the wound
Deinde dimitte sanguinem currere paulatim (est enim melius) et pone puluerem desuper: et super puluerem pannum in quo expansus est uitellus oui decocti in aqua rosata, concussum cum oleo ros recenti bono: et dimitte eum super ipsum usque ad diem alium: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then let the blood run slowly (for it is better thus) and put powder on top: and put a bandage over the swelling which has occurred in the wound, which has been boiled in fresh water: and dismiss it over it until the next day: and care for the rest of the cure until it is healed
Forma autem forficis ad mundificationem haec est.	The shape of the knife for this purpose is like this.
Sint hebetes duae extremitates, et sint incidentes: ne egrediatur in eis ramus claui: et sit longitudo duarum acuitatum, sicut longitudo duorum manubriorum aequaliter.	There are two cutting edges at the extremities, and the handles: do not extend beyond the root of the claw: and let the length of the two edges be equal to the length of two thumbs together
Error uero cadens in mundificatione est: quoniam fortasse effugit cutis intrinseca tota, aut pars eius apud incisionem.	Indeed, a falling away of the skin within is possible: for perhaps the entire intrinsic skin or a part of it has escaped at the incision.
Ergo oportet, ut extendas eam ex hora tua cum ungue tuo ante apostemationem loci: et incidas eam secundum aequalitatem.	Therefore it is necessary to extend your hand with your finger before the retraction of the place: and make the incision according to the equality.
Quod si non potes tenere eam cum ungue tuo, tunc extrahe eam cum uncino, et incide eam.	If you are unable to hold the hand with your finger, then extract the hand with the thumb, and make the incision
Si autem praeterierint ei tres dies, et remanet quod est sub uirga inflatum, apostematum: tunc dimitte illud, donec sedetur apostema calidum, et excoria illud cum facilitate, et incide illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi: et caue tibi a capite uirgae.	If, however, more than three days have passed, and what is under the swelling remains inflated, retract it: then loosen that which is swollen, and cleanse it easily, and make the incision as before: and be careful from the head of the swelling downwards.
Non enim nocebit ei illud.	It will not cause any harm to it.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod consolidat uulnus ex pulueribus, quos narrauimus in tractatu de pulueribus: et si inciditur ex cute supra mensuram, et euadit ad superiora, non nocet ei illud etiam.	Treat it like that which consolidates a wound from dust, as we have said in the treatise on dust: and if it happens from the skin above the measure, and goes up towards the higher parts, it does it no harm either
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod diximus, donec sanetur.	Treat it like that which we have said, until it is healed
¶ De extractione Vrinae retentae in uesica.	On the extraction of a retained limb in a swelling.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58
Urinae retentio in uesica, fit ab opilatione facta ex lapide, aut sanguine congelato, aut pus, aut carne nata, et similibus illis ex eis quae diximus ex modis curationis in diuisione.	The retention of urine in the bladder is caused by a stone, or frozen blood, or pus, or native flesh, or like these things from the things which we have said concerning the methods of treatment in the case of a swelling.
Et si non soluitur Vrina, et uides retentionem eius esse propter Lapidem, qui iam est in collo uesicae: tunc oportet ut sit infirmus super genua sua curuatus.	If the bladder does not yield and the retention is attributed to a stone in the neck of the bladder, then it is necessary that it be flexed over its knee.
Deinde componantur pedes eius super dorsum eius, et extendat uentrem suum ex superiori parte dorsi eius, et stringat infirmus anhelitum suum quantum possibile est ei.	The legs are then flexed over the back, the belly is pulled down from the upper part of the back, and the painful area is grasped as much as possible
Cogitur ergo cum collo uesicae ad expulsionem Lapidis ad posteriora: quare absoluitur Vrina.	It is thought that thus, with the neck of the bladder turned backwards, the stone will be expelled: whereupon the bladder is relaxed
Quod si non soluitur cum eo quod diximus, et uehemens sit res super infirmum: tunc oportet ut administres extractionem eius cum instrumento, quod nominatur siringa, cuius haec est forma Sit ex argento, et sit subtile, lene, concauum sicut cannula pennae auis in subtilitate radii, longum in similitudine palmi unius et medii: cui sit cannula subtilis in capite eius.	If it does not yield even thus, and if there remains something above the painful area: then it is necessary to draw it out with an instrument called a siringa, which is like a silver needle, fine and flexible, like a quill of a bird in the thickness of a barleycorn, with a fine needle at its head.
Et modus exitus Vrinae per ipsum est, ut accipias filum duplicatum, et liges in extremitate eius lanam, aut cotum, ligatura bona: et intromittas extremitatem fili in inferiori parte Siringae: et incide cum forficibus si superfluit aliquid ex lana, uerum intromitte in cannulam cum uehementia, sicut alzer.	The way to drain the bladder is as follows: take a doubled thread and tie a knot at its extremity, either wool or cotton, a good ligation. Insert the extremity of the thread into the lower part of the siringa. Then pierce with scissors if anything remains of the wool, but really insert into the needle with force, like a thrust.
Deinde inunge siringam cum oleo, aut cum butyro, et albugine oui: et fac sedere infirmum super sedem, et embroca uesicam, et ipsius uirgam cum oleis humidis, et oleo oliuae, et aqua tepida.	Then wash the siringa with oil, or butter, and vinegar. Make the patient sit on a chair, and support the bladder, and insert the needle with oil, olive oil, and warm water.
Deinde intromitte siringam in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat ad radicem uirgae.	Insert the siringa into the bladder with ease, until it reaches the root of the bladder.
Deinde dupla ipsam superius a parte umbilici.	Then double the thread over the upper part of the belly.
Deinde impelle siringam intra ipsam, donec perueniat ad Vesicam, et sentiat eam infirmus iam peruenisse ad rem uacuam: et non fit hoc secundum hunc ordinem, nisi quoniam meatus, in quo uadit, est in quo est tortuositas.	Then push the siringa into the bladder until it reaches the bladder wall, and the patient feels that the painful area has been relieved: do not do this in any other way, except when the pain is in the area where there is a curvature
Deinde extende filum cum lana paulatim.	Then extend the thread gradually with wool.
Vrina enim sequetur lanam.	The thread follows the wool gradually.
Deinde extrahe eam, et fac currere Vrinam per uiam urinae: et itera siringam, et non cesses facere illud, donec euacuetur uesica, et inueniat infirmus alleuiationem.	Then draw out the thread, and make the urine run through the bladder: and repeat the needle, and do not desist from doing this until the bladder is evacuated and the patient experiences relief.
¶ De qualitate clisterizationis uesicae cum Clepshydra.	Concerning the quality of the bladder with Clepshydra.
Caput LIX.	Chapter 59.</start_of_turn>
Quando accidit in uesica ulcus, aut sanguis in ea congelatur, aut coartatur in ea pus, et uis distillare in eam aquas et medicinas: tunc fiat cum instrumento quod nominatur Clepshydra, et haec est forma eius.	When it happens in the bladder that there is a wound, or that blood is frozen in it, or that it is clotted with pus, and the urine is distilled into water and medicines: then it is done with an instrument which is called Clepshydra, and this is its shape.</start_of_turn>
Est enim surda, id est, clausa.	It is blunt, that is, closed.</start_of_turn
Et in eo sunt tria foramina, duo ex parte una, et unum ex parte altera, sicut uides.	And there are three holes in it, two from one side and one from the other side, like urine.</start_of_turn
Et locus concauus, in quo est illud quod impellit, sit secundum quantitatem quod opilet ipsum sine additione, donec quando trahitur cum eo aliquid, ex humiditatibus attrahatur: et quando impellitur, cum eo expellatur ad longinquum: secundum quod facit clepshydra, qua proiicitur naphta, id est, ignis graecus in praeliis martis.	And the burnished area, in which that which drives it lies, should be according to the quantity which it desires without addition, until when it is drawn with it something is attracted from the humilities: and when it is driven out with it at length: according to what the Clepshydra does, which throws out pitch, that is, Greek fire in the battles.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo uis proiicere humiditates in uesicam, intromitte extremitatem clepshydrae in humiditatem, et trahe cum eo quod impellit ad superiora, humiditas enim trahitur in concauitatem clepshydrae.	When therefore urine is thrown out from the bladder, introduce the extremity of the Clepshydra into the urine, and draw out with it what drives, and the urine is drawn into the concavity of the Clepshydra.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte extremitatem eius in uirgam, secundum quod narrauimus in siringa.	Then introduce its extremity into the bladder, according to what we have said concerning the needle.</start_of_turn
Deinde impelle humiditatem cum eo quod impellit illa namque humiditas peruenit ad uesicam statim, ita quod sentit eam infirmus.	Then drive moisture with that which drives it; for moisture persists at the site immediately, as the ailing man feels.
Forma clisteris subtilis quo clisterizatur uesica.	Form a soft enema so that the uterus is cleansed.
Fiat ex argento, aut auricalco: cuius caput altius sit simile alcama paruo, et sub eo sinus inter quem cadat ligamentum.	Make it from silver or gold: whose head is like a small bowl, and under that the sinus where the ligament hangs down
Deinde accipe uesicam arietis, et pone in ea humiditatem, qua uis clisterizare uesicam.	Then take hold of the uterus of a sheep, and put in it moisture, which will cause the uterus to swell
Deinde liga eam inter duos sinus ligatura forti cum filo duplo: et calefac illam humiditatem parumper super ignem.	Then bind the two sinuses together with a strong ligature with a double thread: and warm up the moisture slightly over a fire.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem clisteris in uirgam, postea stringe manum tuam super uesicam cum humiditate strictura decenti, donec sentiat infirmus, quod illa humiditas iam peruenit ad uesicam.	Then insert the extremity of the enema into the belly, then tightly bind your hand over the uterus with moisture until the patient feels that the moisture has reached the uterus
Si autem non est tibi praesens uesica, tunc accipe frustum pergameni, et fac ex eo circulum, et perfora ipsum ab omni rotunditate sua.	If, however, the uterus is not present, then take a piece of gut and make a circle from it, and perforate it from all its roundness
Deinde intromitte filum forte in illis foraminibus, sicut reuoluuntur.	Then insert the strong thread firmly through those holes, as they are rolled up
Deinde aggrega circulum, sicut aggregatur alsofratu: postquam tu ponis in eo illud quod uis ex humiditatibus, et oleis, et aquis.	Then gather the circle, as is done with wool: when you have put in it that which you wish from moisture, and oil, and water.
Deinde liga ipsum in instrumento: et fac cum eo sicut fecisti cum uesica ex expressione cum manu tua, donec perueniat humiditas ad uesicam.	Then bind it with an instrument: and do it like when you expressed the uterus with your hand, until the moisture reaches the uterus.
¶ De extractione Lapidis.	On the extraction of the Stone.
Caput LX.	Chapter LX.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Lapidis, et curationem eius cum medicinis: et dixi differentiam inter Lapidem generatum in renibus, et uesica, et signa illius totius: et dixi Lapidem in quo cadit operatio cum manu et sectio: et est Lapis generatus in uesica proprie: et ille qui figitur in uirga: et ego sum narrans illud cum expositione manifesta et abbreuiatione.	We have spoken in the preceding discourse concerning the kinds of Stone and their treatment by physicians: and we have mentioned the difference between a Stone generated in the bowels and the uterus, and the signs of the whole: and we have mentioned the Stone in which the operation is performed with the hand and incision: and this is a Stone generated in the uterus itself: and that which is formed in the belly: and I am going to speak of this with manifest explanation and abbreviation.
Dico ergo, quod Lapis generatus in uesica, plurimum accidit pueris.	I say therefore, that the stone which is generated in the bladder, happens mostly to children.
Et ex signis eius est, quod urina egreditur ex uesica similis aquae in subtilitate sua: et apparet in ea harena alba, et fricat infirmus uirgam suam, et laborat cum ea, et multotiens pendet.	And from its signs it is known that the urine comes out of the bladder like water in its consistency: and there appears in it white sand, and it irritates the painful area of the bladder and works with it, and it hangs about many times
Deinde erigitur, et egreditur cum eo anus in multis eorum.	And then it is raised up, and comes out with it the anus in many cases.
Et est facilis sanatio puerorum, ex eo usquequo consequuntur quatuordecim annos.	And it is easy to heal the children of it, from which until the age of fourteen years passes.
Et est difficilis in senibus.	And it is difficult in old age.
In iuuenibus autem est media, in eo quod est inter illud: et eius cuius Lapis est maior, curatio facilior: et si paruus, est econuerso illius cura.	In youth, however, it is middle-aged, in which there is between the two: and the greater the stone, the easier the cure: and if small, the less is its care.
Cum ergo peruenimus ad curationem, oportet in primis, ut mundificemus infirmum cum clisteri, quod extrahat totum stercus quod est in intestinis suis: ipsum enim quandoque prohibet inuentionem Lapidis apud inquisitionem.	When we come to the treatment, it is necessary at first to purge the sick person with a cathartic, which will extract all the stool that is in its intestines: which indeed often hinders the finding of the stone in the inquiry
Deinde accipiatur infirmus cum pedibus suis, et concutiatur, et moueatur ad inferiora: ut descendat Lapis ad profundum uesicae, aut saliat de loco alto aliquotiens.	Then the sick person should be taken with his feet, and be shaken, and moved downwards: so that the stone may descend to the depth of the bladder, or come out from a high place somewhat.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas praeparatum, et manus eius sint sub coxis ipsius, ut fiat uesica tota decliuis ad inferiora.	Then let him sit down between your hands prepared, and your hands be under his hips, so that the bladder may be completely descended downwards
Deinde perquire eum, et tange eum extrinsecus.	Then inquire about him, and touch him externally.
Si ergo sentis Lapidem in spacio, tunc propera statim cum sectione super ipsum.	If you feel the stone in the space, then act immediately with a section above it
Quod si non cadat sub tactu tuo omnino, tunc oportet ut abstergas digitum indicem cum oleo manus sinistrae, si infirmus est puer: aut digitum medium si est iuuenis completus: et intromittas ipsum in anum suum, et perquire de Lapide, donec stat sub digito tuo: et conuerte eum paulatim ad collum uesicae.	If it does not come under your touch at all, then you must remove the index finger with the left hand, if the patient is a child: or the middle finger if he is grown up: and introduce it into his rectum, and inquire about the stone, until it is under your finger: and gently move it to the neck of the bladder
Deinde preme super ipsum cum digito tuo, et impelle ipsum ad exteriora aduersus locus, cuius sectionem uis: et praecipe ministro, ut premat uesicam manu sua, et praecipe alii ministro, ut extendat testiculos manu sua dextra ad superiora: et alia manu sua, ut remoueat cutem, quae est sub testiculis in parte a loco in quo est sectio.	Then first above all with your finger touch the exterior of the locus towards which you will make the incision: and command one minister to keep the vulva of your hand in place, and command another minister to extend the testicles of your hand to the exterior: and another hand to move the skin which is beneath the testicles in the part from the locus to the place where the incision is to be made.
Deinde intromitte Spatumile incidens, cuius forma haec est.	Then insert the sponge into the wound, whose form is like this.</start_of_turn>
Et finde in eo quod est inter anum et testiculos, et non in medio, ad latus natis sinistrae: et sit sectio super ipsum lapidem, et digitus tuus sit in ano: et fiat sectio transuersa, ut sit sectio exterius ampla, et interius stricta, secundum quantitatem quod sit possibile egressio Lapidis ex ea non maior.	And find in that [wound] what is between the testicles and the anus, and not in the middle, on the left side of the navel: and let the incision be above the great toe, and your finger be in the anus: and make a transverse incision, so that the external incision is wide and the internal incision is narrow, as much as is possible so that there should be no egressio of the bone from that which is not greater.</start_of_turn>
Fortasse enim comprimit digitus, qui est in ano Lapidem apud sectionem, et egreditur absque difficultate.	Perhaps therefore the finger which is in the anus will be compressed by the bone at the incision and will go out without difficulty.</start_of_turn>
Et scias, quod ex Lapide est cui sunt anguli et margines, quare fit difficilis exitus eius propter illud.	And you know that from the bone there are angles and margins which make its exit difficult because of that.</start_of_turn
Et ex eo est lenis, similis glandulae, et rotundus: et fit facilis egressus eius.	And from that [bone] is soft, like a gland, and round: and makes its exit easy.</start_of_turn
Ei ergo cui sunt anguli, et margines, adde in fissura.	Therefore for those which have angles and margins, add to the fissure.</start_of_turn
Quod si non egreditur ita, tunc oportet ut ingenies super ipsum: aut stringas super eum cum gesti decenter, cuius extremitas sit sicut Luna, quae stringat super Lapidem, et non euadat ab ea: aut ut intromittas sub eo instrumentum subtile, curuatae extremitatis.	That if it does not go out like that, then you must know how to manage above all: or you will bind over it with a dressing which is like the moon, which will bind over the bone and not slip from it: or that you will introduce under it an instrument which is fine and flexible at its extremity.</start_of_turn
Si autem non potes super cum, tunc amplifica foramen parumper.	If however you are unable above with these things, then enlarge the opening a little more.</start_of_turn
Quod si uincit te aliquid ex sanguine, abscinde ipsum cum zegi.	If anything from the blood should trouble you, cut it off with a knife.
Si uero lapis est plus quam unus, tunc impelle in primis magnum ad os uesicae.	If there is more than one bone, then push in the first one to the hip bone first.
Deinde incide super ipsum.	Then cut through it
Postea impelle paruum post illud: et similiter fac si sunt plures duobus.	Then push out the small one after that: do the same if there are more than two
Quod si magnus est ualde, tunc ignorantia est ut seces super ipsum sectione magna.	If the large one is above, then ignorance is for it to cut above with a large section
Quoniam accidit infirmo una duarum rerum, aut ut moriatur, aut accidit ei distillatio urinae assidua: proptera, quia non consolidatur locus omnino.	For in a sick person either two things happen: or he dies, or there is an excessive concentration of urine: because the place is not solidified anywhere.
Verum administra expulsionem eius, donec egrediatur: aut ingenia in fractura eius cum forficibus, donec extrahas eum frustatim.	True is to give him an enema until it comes out: or to make an incision in his fracture with shears, until you have extracted him frustrated
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc imple uulnus thure, et aloe, et sanguine draconis: et stringe ipsum, et pone super ipsum pannum infusum oleo et uino, aut oleo rosato, et aqua frigida: ut sedetur apostema calidum.	When you have finished your operation, then put on a bandage, and aloe, and dragon's blood: and bind it up, and put over it a soaked sponge with oil and wine, or rose-water and cold water: so that the wound will be cool
Deinde resupina infirmum super collum suum, et non soluas ligamentum, usque ad diem tertium.	Then rest the sick man on his side, and do not tighten the ligaments, until the third day
Cum ergo solueris ipsum, embroca locum cum aqua, et oleo multo.	When you have finished with it, embroider the place with water, and much oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dyafinicon, et unguento basilicon, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with ointment of dyafinicon, and ointment of basilicon, until he is healed.
Si autem accidit in uulnere apostema calidum additum, et corrosi, et illi similia: sicut si congeletur sanguis in uesica, et prohibeatur ex eo urina: et cognoscitur illud ex egressione sanguinis cum urina.	If, however, in the wound there is added a cold abscess, and pus, and similar things: thus also if blood is congealed in the bladder, and is prohibited from coming out: and it is known by the discharge of blood with the urine.
Intromitte ergo digitum tuum in uulnus, et extrahe illum sanguinem.	Insert your finger into the wound, and extract the clot of blood.
Nam si remanet, prouocat ad corruptionem uesicae, et putrefactionem eius.	If it remains [of the wound], it promotes corruption of the cavity and its putrefaction.
Deinde ablue uulnus cum aceto, et aqua, et sale: et oppone omni speciei cum eo quod conuenit ex curatione, usquequo sanetur.	Then wash the wound with vinegar, vinegar, water, and salt: and oppose all things which concur with this which is useful for the cure, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Et oportet in horis curationis totius, ut liges duas coxas, et aggreges, caussa medicinarum quae ponuntur super locum.	It is necessary in the course of treatment at every hour, that you join two thighs together, and bind them, because of the things which the physicians place upon the place.</start_of_turn>
Quod si lapis est paruus, et sit in meatu uirgae, et figitur in eo, et prohibetur urinae exitus: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod narro antequam peruenias ad sectionem.	If the stone is small, and is in the cavity of the bladder, and is fixed in it, and hinders the passage of urine: then treat it with that which I have mentioned before until you reach the section.</start_of_turn
Multotiens enim a sectione excusaris per hanc curationem, iam enim probaui illud.	Many are excused from the section because of this treatment, for I have proved it.</start_of_turn
Et est, ut accipias Perforatorium ex ferro alferico, cuius haec est forma, triangulatae extremitatis, acutum, fixum in ligno.	And it is necessary to take a perforator of iron, which is shaped like a triangle with acute extremities, fixed in wood.</start_of_turn
Deinde accipe filum, et liga cum eo uirgam sub lapide ut non redeat ad uesicam.	Then take a thread, and bind with it the bladder under the stone so that it does not return to the cavity.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte ferrum perforans in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat Perforatorium ad ipsum lapidem: et reuolue Perforatorium manu tua in ipso lapide paulatim: et coneris perforationem eius, donec facias ipsum penetrare a parte altera.	Then introduce the perforating iron into the bladder with ease, until the perforator reaches the stone: and withdraw the perforator slowly from the stone: and make the perforation of it, until you make it penetrate from the other side.</start_of_turn
Urina namque absoluitur statim.	The urine will immediately cease.</start_of_turn>
Deinde preme manum tuam super illud quod remansit ex lapide ab exteriori parte uirgae.	Then press your hand over that which remains from the stone from the exterior part of the bladder.</start_of_turn
Ipse enim frangitur, et egreditur cum urina, et sanatur infirmus.	It will itself break, and go out with the urine, and the infirm person will be healed.</start_of_turn
Si autem non praeparatur tibi haec curatio, propter aliquid quod prohibet ab illo: tunc liga filum sub lapide, et filum aliud supra lapidem.	But if you do not prepare this treatment for him because of something which hinders it: then bind a thread under the stone, and a thread above the stone.</start_of_turn
Deinde seca super lapidem in ipsa uirga inter duas ligaturas.	Then dry above the stone in the very vessel between two ligatures.
Deinde extrahe ipsum.	Then extract it.
Postea solue ligamentum, et mundifica sanguinem congelatum, qui fit in uulnere.	Afterwards suture the ligament and bind the frozen blood which forms in the wound
Et non est necessarium ligamentum fili sub lapide, nisi ut non redeat ad uesicam: et ligamentum aliud desuper, nisi ut quando soluitur filum post egressionem lapidis, redeat cutis ad locum suum, et cooperiat uulnus: et propter illud necesse est tibi illud quando ligas filum superius, ut eleues cutem ad superiora, ut redeat apud complementum tuum, et cooperiat uulnus, sicut diximus.	And it is not necessary to pass a thread under the stone, except that it should not go back into the cavity: and another ligament must be passed above, except when the thread is withdrawn after the stone has gone, so that the skin should return to its place and cohere with the wound: for this reason it is necessary for you to pass the thread above when you elevate the skin to its proper position, so that the skin may return to its place along with the completion of your work, and cohere with the wound, as we have said.
¶ De extractione Lapidis mulierum.	On the extraction of a stone from a woman
Caput LXI.	Chapter LX.
Parum generatur Lapis in mulieribus.	Stones are rarely formed in women
Si autem accidat alicui earum lapis, tunc difficilis est curatio, et prohibetur propter modos multos.	If, however, it should happen to any of them to have a stone, then its cure is difficult, and is forbidden by many methods.
Vnus eorum est: quod mulier fortasse est uirgo.	One of them is: a woman may perhaps be a vessel.
Et secundus est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem quae detegat seipsam medico, quando est casta, aut ex habentibus maritos.	And the second is that you will not find a woman who will confess to the doctor that she has a stone when she is chaste, or from her husbands.
Tertius est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem bene scientem hanc artem, praecipue operationem cum manu.	The third is that you will not find a woman who is well-skilled in this art, especially in performing surgery with her hand
Et quartus est longinquitas a loco lapidis: quare indiget sectione profunda, et in illo est timor.	And the fourth is the distance of the stone from the place: because it requires a deep incision, and there is fear of that
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad illud, tunc oportet ut accipias mulierem medicam, bene scientem: et parum inuenitur.	If necessity compels you to do this, then you must take a medical woman, who is well-skilled: and few are found
Si uero priuaris ea, tunc quaere medicum castum, subtilem, et praesenta mulierem obstetricem bene doctam in re mulierum, aut mulierem quae in hac arte innuit partem artis: fac ergo eam praesentem, et praecipue ei, ut faciat totum quod praecipis ei ex inquisitione super lapidem.	If you prefer beforehand, then seek a skilled physician, subtle, and present a woman obstetrician who is well-learned in matters concerning women, or a woman who has learned a part of this art: do this immediately, and particularly tell her to do everything that is prescribed to her from the inquiry concerning the stone.
In primis quod est, ut aspiciat si mulier est uirgo: tunc oportet ut intromittat digitum in anum eius, et quaerat lapidem.	Firstly, if she is a girl, let her insert a finger into her belly and search for the stone.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo inuenit ipsum, coartet eum sub digito suo, et tunc praecipe obstetrici, ut intromittat digitum suum in uuluam infirmae, et inquirat super lapidem, postquam ponit manum suam sinistram super uesicam, et comprimit eam compressione bona.	If she finds it, she should grasp it under her finger and then command the obstetrician to insert her finger into the lower part of her belly and inquire about the stone, after she has placed her left hand over the waist and applied good pressure.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo inuenit lapidem, tunc oportet ut gradatim moueat eum ab orificio uesicae ad inferiora cum summa uirtutis suae, donec perueniat cum eo ad radicem coxae.	If she finds the stone, she should gradually move it from the opening of the uterus towards the lower parts with all her skill, until she has brought it down to the root of the hip bone.</start_of_turn>
Deinde secet super eum apud oppositionem medietatis uuluae apud radicem coxae, ex quacunque parte praeparatur ei, et sentit lapidem in illa parte: et digitus eius non remoueatur a lapide, coartans sub eo: et sit sectio parua in primis.	Then she should cut above it at the middle of the belly near the root of the hip bone from whichever side is most convenient for her, and she will feel the stone in that place: and do not move your finger from the stone, holding it tightly under it: and make a small incision at first.</start_of_turn>
Deinde intromittat radium super illam sectionem.	And then insert a needle over that incision.</start_of_turn>
Si ergo sentit lapidem, tunc addat in sectionem secundum quantitatem proportionatam quod lapis egreditur ab ea.	If she feels the stone, then add to the incision according to the quantity that the stone comes out with.</start_of_turn
Et scias, quod species lapidis sunt multae.	And know that there are many kinds of stones.</start_of_turn>
Ex his enim est paruus, et magnus, lenis et asper, longus, et rotundus habens ramos.	Among them are small and large, smooth and rough, long and round having a branch.</start_of_turn
Scias ergo species eius, ut significetur tibi per hoc super illud quod uis.	You know well the sort of it; for this indicates by this above what you desire.
Si ergo uincit te sanguis, tunc adde in loco zegi tritum, et tene ipsum hora una, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If blood boils up, then add in the armpit some unguents, and keep it for an hour, until the blood is separated.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis: et fac, ut praepares tecum ex instrumentis, quae dixi in extractione lapidis in uiris, ut adiuueris per ea in operatione tua.	Then return to the operation, until the stone comes out: and make ready with the instruments which I mentioned in the extraction of the stone from the bladder, that you may aid in that operation.
Quod si uincit te fluxus sanguinis, et scis quod expulsio sanguinis est ex arteria quae incisa est: tunc pone puluerem super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis strictura decenti: et non mutes illud: et dimitte lapidem, et non extrahas ipsum.	If blood flows too much, and you know that the evacuation of blood comes from the artery that has been cut: then put powder over the place, and bind it with threads of the thickness of a barleycorn: and do not stop it: and let the stone go, and do not pull it out
Fortasse enim morietur mulier infirma.	Perhaps the woman is weak.
Deinde cura uulnus.	Then care for the wound
Cum ergo sedatur acuitas sanguinis post dies, et putrefit locus, tune redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis.	When the pain of the wound has subsided after a few days, and the place is putrefying, then return to the operation until the stone comes out.
¶ De sectione suiper Herniam aquosam.	Of the incision for a herniated belly-ache filled with liquid.
Caput LXII.	Chapter XII.
Ramex aquosa non est, nisi aggregatio humiditatis in sifac albo, quod est sub cute testiculi continente ouum: et nominatur sifac.	The swelling of the belly is not from water, except for the gathering of moisture in the white membrane under the testicles which contain eggs: and it is called a hernia
Et quandoque est in panniculo proprio sibi, quem praeparauit ei natura in parte oui, donec putetur: quod est ouum aliud, et est cutis testiculi inter sifac album, quod diximus: et non fit illud nisi raro.	And when it is in its own sac in the belly, which nature has prepared for it in the part of the testicles until it is full: that is an egg, and is the membrane of the testicles between the white membrane which we mentioned: and it does not happen except rarely
Et generatio quidem huius ramicis, est ex debilitate quae accidit testiculis: quare effunditur ad eos haec materia.	And the generation of this swelling is from the weakness which happens to the testicles: whereupon this matter flows out to them
Et quandoque accidit ex percussione super testiculos.	And when it happens from a blow upon the testicles.
Et haec humiditas est habens colores multos.	And this humidity has many colors.
Aut enim est color eius decliuis ad citrinitatem, aut est sanguineus rubeus, aut faeculentus, niger, aut est aquosus albus, et est illud quod est plus.	Or it is of the color of the setting sun, or it is a reddish-brown, or greenish, black, or white, and the like is more
Et signa quibus scitur ubi sit aggregatio aquae, sunt ista.	And the signs from which it is known where the water is gathered, are these
Nam si est in sifac albo quod diximus, tunc apostema est rotundum ad longitudinem parumper sicut figura oui: et non apparet testiculus, quoniam humiditas continet eum ab omni parte.	For if it is in the white swelling which we mentioned, then the swelling is round about the length like the figure of a pine tree: and the testicle does not appear, because the humidity contains it from all sides
Et si est humiditas in panniculo proprio sibi, tunc apostema est rotundum cum parte oui, et propter hoc extimat homo quia est ouum aliud.	And if the humidity is in the testicles themselves, then the swelling is round with a part like that of a pine tree, and on account of this the man knows that there is another one
Et si humiditas est inter cutem testiculorum et sifac album, tunc cadit sub sensu.	And if the humidity is between the skin of the testicles and the white swelling, then it falls under the sense.
Quando ergo uis cognitionem coloris humiditatis, tunc experire colorem humiditatis in apostemate cum Intromisso quadrato, cuius forma praecessit.	When therefore one wishes to know the color of the humidity, then to experience the color of the humidity in the swelling with the introduction of the quarter-square, whose form precedes.
Secundum illud ergo quod egreditur in uestigio Intromissi, iudica de illo quod est inter ipsum.	According to that therefore which proceeds from the indication of the introduction, judge concerning that which is between that.
Cum ergo uenimus ad curationem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, ut phlebotometur si possibile est ei illud, et uides corpus eius plenum.	When therefore we come to the treatment with iron, then it is necessary to give the sick person rest, and to draw off blood from him if it is possible, and to fill his body with liquid
Deinde resupinetur super dorsum suum super rem altam parum, et pone sub eo pannos multos.	Then he rests upon his back upon a high thing, and places under him many cushions.
Deinde sede tu super sinistram eius, et praecipe ministro, ut sedeat a dextra eius, qui extendat uirgam eius ad unum duorum laterum cutis testiculorum, et ad partem mirach uentris.	Then sit thou upon his left hand, and command the minister, that he sit on his right hand, who extends his palm of his hand towards one of the two sides of the skin of the testicles, and towards the part of the belly
Deinde accipe spatumile latum, et seca cutem testiculorum ex medio per longitudinem, usque prope pectinem: et fiat sectio secundum rectitudinem aequedistantis lineae quae diuidit cutem testiculorum, donec perueniat ad sifac album comprehendens: et excoria ipsum et obserua, uel caue ex hoc, ut seces ipsum: et sit excoriatio tua qua ipsum excorias, ex parte quae suspenditur cum ouo plus: et subtiliter scrutare cum excoriatione secundum quantitatem quod tibi possibile est.	Then take the broad sponge and dry the testicles from the middle towards the loin: and make an incision according to the rule of the equidistant line which divides the skin of the testicles, until it reaches the white layer which encompasses the testicles: and scrape it off and watch, or cut it out in this way: and let your scraping be such as you scrape the part which hangs with the testicles towards the greater part. And scrape cautiously according to the quantity which you are able.
Deinde perfora sifac plenum aqua perforatione ampla, et extrahe totam aquam.	Then pierce the bladder with a wide needle and extract all the urine.
Deinde separa inter duo labia sectionis cum uncinis, et extende sifac ad superiora, et non tangas cutem testiculorum comprehendentem: et incide sifac qualitercunque est possibile tibi incidere ipsum, aut cum totalitate sua, aut frustatim, praecipue latus eius subtile.	Then separate the two lips of the incision with hooks, and stretch the bladder upwards, and do not touch the testicles which are encompassed: and make an incision in the bladder as you consider possible, or with all its substance, or incompletely, especially its broad side superficially
Nam si tu non exquisite perscrutaris, in incisione eius non fit securitas, quin aqua redeat.	For if you do not examine carefully, in making the incision there will be no security, for the urine will return.
Si autem procedit ouum exterius a cute sua in hora operationis tuae: tunc quando compleueris sectionem sifac, reduc ipsum.	If however anything external comes out from its place at the time of your operation: then when you have completed the incision of the bladder, reduce it.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cutis testiculorum cum sutura.	Then join together the two lips of the skin of the testicles with sutures.
Deinde cura ipsum sicut reliqua uulnera, donec sanetur.	Then care for it like the rest of the wounds, until it is healed.
Quod si inuenis ouum corruptum ex nigredine alia, tunc oportet ut liges uasa, quae sunt suspensorium, timens fluxum sanguinis.	If you find anything corrupted from blackness else, then it is necessary that you bind the veins which are the source of the blood flow
Deinde abscinde testiculum cum suspensorio, et extrahe ouum: postea cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then remove the testicles with the suspension, and extract the urine: afterwards care for it as we have said before
Si uero aqua est aggregata in duabus partibus, tunc scias quia sunt duae ramices: seca ergo partem aliam secundum quod fecisti in altera aequaliter.	If indeed urine is aggregated in two parts, then you know that there are two branches: dry therefore the other part equally as you did the other
Et si aequatur tibi, ut sit operatio una, tunc fac: deinde absterge sanguinem.	And if it be equal with you, that the operation be one, then do this: afterwards withdraw the blood.
Et intromitte in sectiones lanam submersam in oleo, aut in oleo rosato: et pone deforis lanam aliam quam submersisti in uino et oleo, et expande eam super duos testiculos, et mirach uentris: et pone desuper pannos duplicatos, et sunt puluilli: et liga eos desuper cum ligamento, quod est habens sex secundum hanc formam.	And insert the lancet beneath the skin in the belly, or in the groin: and put outside the lancet another lancet than that which thou didst submerge in the wine and oil, and expand the belly above two testicles, and open the belly: and place over it doubled layers of linen, and there will be nails: and ligate above with a ligament, which is having six according to this shape.
Deinde sumantur duo panni, et suantur, et impleantur la na carminata, secundum hanc similitudinem: et fiant extremitates quibus premitur ex coto, aut lana humida: et aggregentur cum strictura in lumbari bracharum: et una extremitatum accipiat super anum usque ad dorsum, et secunda accipiat ad partem pectinis: et duae extremitates super duas coxas inferius, et duae extremitates aliae super duo inguina, et aggregetur strictura tota in lumbari bracharum.	And then take away two cloths, and wash, and put in the carmine, according to this likeness: and let the extremities be those which are sent from the hip, or a wet lancet: and gather with the stricture in the lumbar region of the arms: and one extremity shall take upon itself over a knee until the back, and the second shall take upon itself to the part of the loin: and two extremities upon two lower thighs, and two extremities upon two buttocks, and gather the stricture throughout in the lumbar region of the arms.
Et, quandoque artificialiter medicatur haec ramex cum cauterio loco sectionis cum ferro: et est, ut accipias cauterium cultellare subtile, et seces cum eo cutem testiculorum: et est ignitum, secundum quod narrauimus: donec quando detegitur sifac album continens aquam: tunc accipe cauterium, secundum hanc formam.	And when it is necessary to treat this swelling artificially with a cautery in the place of the section with a knife: and it is that thou shalt take the cautery of a fine knife, and cut with it the skin of the testicles: and it is ignited, according as we have said: until it is discerned that there is white fat containing water: then take the cautery, according to this shape.
Assimilatur literae graecae.	Thus are the Greek letters assimilated.
Deinde perfora cum eo illud sifac, et est ignitum, donec egrediatur humiditas tota.	And then pierce with it that swelling, and it is ignited, until all the moisture has gone out
Deinde extende sifac cum uncinis, et excoria cum cauterio subtili ignito, et incide ipsum secundum quod possibile est tibi, donec eradices totum eius.	And then stretch out the swelling with hooks, and scrape with the cautery of a fine fire, and cut it through according to what is possible for thee, until thou hast cut through all of it
Et caue ex ouo, ne tangat ipsum ignis.	And take heed from the belly, let it not touch the flame.
Et scias, quod haec operatio est saluior, et longinquior a fluxu sanguinis, et melior quam operatio cum sectione.	And know that this operation is safer and more lasting than one with bleeding, and better than an operation with incision
Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit in hora sectionis, aut in hora cauterii apostema calidum, aut fluxus sanguinis, aut aliquid aliud: tunc oportet ut cures quod contrarietatem tibi facit ex illo cum curatione quae conuenit ei, secundum quod praemissum est.	If indeed it makes resistance in the hour of incision, or in the hour of cautery of the afterburn, or bleeding, or anything else: then it is necessary to treat that which makes resistance to it with the treatment which is fitting for it, as has been said before
Si autem infirmus est timidus, et non expectat super hanc operationem, propter horribilitatem suam: tunc administra perforationem secundum quod ego narro illud: et est.	But if the patient is timid and does not expect this operation on account of its horror: then I administer perforation according to that which I have said above: and thus
Quando certificatur tibi apud te per illud quod diximus de significationibus, quod ramex est aquosa: tunc oportet quod facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	When you are certain with me about the signification of the aquosa [substance], which is poured out: then you must cause the patient to sit on a raised seat.
Deinde perfora apostema in inferiori parte sui cum spatumili lato: et pone perforationem secundum longitudinem corporis, et sit apertio ampla, donec currat aqua tota.	Then perforate the afterburn in the lower part of it with a broad spatula: and place the perforation according to the length of the body, and let the opening be wide open, until all the water has run out.
Deinde pone super locum cotum, et liga ipsum, et dimitte ipsum ut currat residuum aquae: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then place over the place the heel, and bind it up, and let it run out the rest of the water: then care for it until the wound is healed.
Si autem contrarietas sit egressioni aquae in hora qua perforas ipsam: et non sit illud nisi propterea, quia panniculus albus contrarietatem facit in orificio uulneris, et prohibet exitum aquae: tunc oportet ut intromittas pennam in uulnus, aut instrumentum cum quo extrahitur aqua hydropicorum, cuius forma praecessit: aut adde in operatione uulneris parumper.	If indeed resistance be found in the hour when you perforate it: and it is not because of that, because a white cobweb makes resistance in the mouth of the wound and hinders the issue of the water: then you must introduce a needle into the wound, or an instrument with which the water of life is extracted, whose form has gone before: or add in the operation of the wound a little piece of wool.
Et scias, quod aqua redit, et aggregatur post sex menses, aut circiter eos.	And know that the water returns and is gathered after six months, or thereabouts.
Cum ergo aggregatur, tunc pertoretur secundum eundem modum, et pertransibit infirmus dies suos.	When the patient is gathered, he is then returned to the same manner, and the infirm passes over his days.
¶ De cura Ramicis carnosae.	Regarding the care of the flesh-wound.
Caput LXIII.	Chapter LXIII.
Scias, quod in sectione super hanc Ramicem, est ex timore perducente ad perniciem in pluribus dispositionibus.	You know that in the section above this Ramus, there is fear that leads to perversion in many situations.
Quapropter uidetur mihi eius dimissio saluari ex ea.	Therefore its dismissal from this [wound] is seen as a healing factor
Et ego sum rememorans operationem in ea, et species apostematis.	And I am reminding you of the operation in this and of the kind of dressing
Dico ergo, quod accidunt apostemata multa in corporibus, ex quibus componuntur testiculi: et fit illud ex caussis multis, scilicet.	I say, indeed, that many abscesses happen in bodies, from which testicles are made up: and this is from many wounds, namely
Aut ex superfluitate acuta, uel acri, quae effunditur ad testiculos.	Or from acute or acrid moisture which flows to the testicles
Aut ex percussione.	Or from impact.
Et est color apostematis secundum colorem corporis, et non inuenitur ei dolor: et est apostema graue.	And the colour of the abscess is according to the colour of the body, and it is not found to be painful: and it is a serious abscess
Et fortasse est apostema lapideum, cuius color est fuscus, et non est sensus ei.	And perhaps it is a stone abscess, whose colour is dark, and there is no feeling in it
Et quandoque fit ex nodatione arteriarum, et inflatione earum: sicut iam praecessit eius rememoratio: aut ex inflatione uenarum.	And when it comes from the swelling of arteries, and the inflation of them: thus was its reminder mentioned above: or from the swelling of veins
Quod ergo est ex eis ex inflatione arteriarum, cognoscitur per dispositionem apostematis, quando comprimis ipsum digitis tuis.	Which indeed comes from the swelling of arteries, is known by the disposition of the abscess, when you press it with your fingers
Et non oportet ut tangas ipsum prorsus.	And it does not behoove you to touch it directly
Illud uero quod fit ex inflatione uenarum, non dispergitur ex eo aliquid apud compressionem cum digitis.	That which comes from the swelling of veins, is not dispersed by anything by the pressure of the fingers
Et iam possibile est, quod super hanc speciem fiat sectio, et super reliquas carnes: et est, ut seces cutem testiculorum.	And it is possible that over this kind of abscess there should be a section, and over the rest of the flesh: and it is like cutting the skin of the testicles
Deinde extende ouum ad sursum, et extrahe ipsum cum sifach albo: et libera suspensorium ex uasis, et liga uasa: et incide suspensorium postquam tu liberas ipsum ab omni parte ex partibus oui.	Then extend the limb upwards, and extract it with a white sponge: and release the suspension from the belly, and ligate the belly: and cut off the suspension when you have released it from all parts of the limb.
Si ergo ouum consolidatum est cum illis carnibus natis, tunc oportet ut attrahas ouum, et incidas ipsum.	If any limb is consolidated with those native bones, then it is necessary to grasp the limb and cut it off.</start_of_turn>
Et si adhaerentia est inter aliquid ex siphaket, aut in eo quod est inter uasa: tunc oportet ut liberes totam illam adhaerentiam, et incidas eam incisione rotunda.	And if there is an adhesion between some of the sponges, or in that which is between the belly: then it is necessary to free the whole adhesion, and cut it with a round incision.</start_of_turn>
Si autem est natiuitas carnis in loco adhaerentiae quae est retro: tunc oportet ut incidas totum eius, et extrahas ouum, sicut diximus.	But if there is a natural bone in the place of the adhesion which is behind: then it is necessary to cut through all of it, and extract the limb, as we have said.</start_of_turn>
Cum ergo completur operatio tua, tnnc imple uulnus in lana infusa in oleo rosato, et uino: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When your operation is complete, then put a bandage on the soaked lancet in rose-colored oil, and wine: then care for it with the remaining care, until it heals.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura Ramicis, quae est cum Vite.	Concerning the care of limbs, which is with Vite.</start_of_turn
Caput LXIIII.	Chapter 122.</start_of_turn>
Uitis est apostema inuolutum quadam inuolutione, simile botro, cum mollificatione testiculorum: et fit difficilis super infirmum motus et exercitium, et deambulatio.	Uitis is swelling which involves the whole limb, like a bag, with softening of the testicles: and it makes difficult the movement and exercise of the infirm person, and walking.</start_of_turn
Et in curatione huius aegritudinis est ex timore, propter illud cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And in the care of this ailment is fear, because of which there is recollection.</start_of_turn
Verum oportet, ut dicamus operationem in ea secundum quod fecerunt primi.	But it is necessary to say that in this case the operation must be performed as the first people did it.</start_of_turn
Dico ergo, quod oportet ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	I say therefore, that it is necessary to make the infirm person sit on a raised seat.</start_of_turn
Deinde impelle suspensorium testiculorum ad inferiora.	Then drive the suspension of the testicles downwards.
Deinde tene cutem testiculorum cum digitis tuis, cum uasis quae sunt propinqua uirgae: et teneat ea minister alius, et extendat ea extensione uehementi.	Then hold the skin of the testicles with your fingers, with the nails towards the groin: and keep it supported by another hand, and extend it gently.</start_of_turn>
Deinde incide cum spatumili lato acuto sectione transuersa in directo uasorum, donec detegantur uasa.	Then make an incision with a sharp knife across the scrotum, until the testicles are revealed.</start_of_turn>
Deinde excoria ab omni parte, sicut diximus tibi in extractione Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then remove the skin from all sides, as we have said concerning the arteries in the groin.</start_of_turn>
Postea fige in eis acum in qua sit filum duplum, et liga ipsum in primo locorum quibus accidunt Vites: et liga ipsum iterum in ultimo eorum.	Then fix in place with a stitch in which the gut is doubled, and ligate it at the first place where the veins are: and ligate it again at the last of these.</start_of_turn
Deinde seca ea in media sectione recta secundum longitudinem corporis, et extrahe quod aggregatur ex humiditatibus faeculentis corruptis.	Then dry it in the middle by a straight cut according to the length of the body, and remove what is gathered from the corruption of the bowels.</start_of_turn
Deinde cura uulnus cum curatione reliquorum uulnerum, in quibus uis generari saniem, ut cadant uasa quae nutriunt unum testiculorum.	Then care for the wound with the care of the rest of the wounds, in which oil is generated to bring about the healing of the testicles.</start_of_turn
Non est enim malum per illud.	There is no bad thing in that.</start_of_turn>
Si autem accidat Vitis omnibus uasis, tunc oportet ut extrahantur propter hoc testiculi cum uasis: ut non priuetur ouum nutrimento, propter incisionem, et tabescat, uel arescat, et non sit iuuamentum cum eis.	If, however, the veins should be injured in all the testicles, then it is necessary to remove them along with the testicles: so that they do not lose nourishment by the incision, and that they do not become gangrenous, and that they do not cause any damage to the surrounding parts.</start_of_turn
¶ De cura Ramicis intestinalis.	(This section is omitted from the translation.)</start_of_turn>
Caput LXV.	(The translation continues with the next chapter header.)</start_of_turn>
Euentus huius Ramicis est ex sectione, quae accidit in sifach extenso super uentrem in parte inguinum ex mirach uentris.	The event of this ramus is from the section that occurs in the groin above the hip in the part of the groin from the navel of the belly.</start_of_turn
Quare descendunt intestina ex illa Ruptura ad unum testiculorum.	Why do the intestines descend from the rupture to one testicle?
Et haec Ruptura est aut ex sifach, aut extensione eius.	The rupture is either from a fracture or an extension of the latter.
Et accidunt istae duae species ex caussis multis: aut ex percussione, aut saltu, aut clamore, aut eleuatione rei grauis, et similibus.	These two kinds of rupture happen from many causes: from a blow, from a jump, from a scream, from the elevation of a heavy object, and similar things.
Et signum, quando est ex extensione sifach.	The sign is when it is from an extension of the fracture.
Est quod accidit paulatim in tempore longo, et non accidit subito: et est apostema aequale uersus profundum: propterea, quod sifach comprimit intestinum.	It happens slowly over a long time, and does not happen immediately: and it is equal in height to its depth because the fracture is compressing the intestine
Et signum eius quando est ex sectione sifach, quia facit accidere ex principio sui dolorem uehementem subito: et est apostema diuersum, apparens sub cute propinque: et illud est propter exitum intestini, et cursus eius ad exteriora sifach.	The sign is when it is from a section of the fracture, because it immediately causes pain and swelling: and it is a different swelling, which appears close to the skin: and this is because the intestine has escaped through the fracture and is flowing outwards
