Et quandoque egreditur cum intestino zirbum: et nominatur haec Ramex intestinalis, et zirbia: et quandoque fit cum uentositate.	And sometimes it escapes with the intestine: and this is called intestinal hernia, and swelling: and sometimes it happens with swelling.
Et quandoque currit in intestinum stercus, et retinetur illic: et est cum eo pernicies infirmi: quoniam facit accidere dolorem prauum, et praecipue quando premitur.	And sometimes it runs into the intestine and remains there: and this is with great pain: because it causes pain to press, and especially when it is released
Et in curatione specierum aegritudinis huius cum ferro est timor: quare oportet ut caueatur casus in ea.	And in the treatment of this kind of ailment, fear of the fracture is great: therefore it is necessary to prevent its occurrence in this case.
Et modus operationis est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut reducat intestinum manu sua ad interiora concauitatis suae, si obedit reditui.	The method of operation is to push out the main cause of pain in the patient, so that the intestine returns to its own cavity.
Deinde resupinetur super collum suum inter manus tuas: et eleua crura eius.	And then it is laid back over the collar of its column between your hands: and you elevate its limbs.
Deinde extende cutem quae sequitur cutem ad superiora, et seca cutem testiculorum totam per longitudinem.	And then you spread the skin following the skin upwards, and dry the testicles completely along their length
Deinde fige in duobus labiis sectionis uncinos, secundum quod indiges ad aperiendum sectionem cum eis: et sectio sit secundum quantitatem, quod sit possibile, ut egrediatur ex ea ouum.	Then fix in two holes the section of the bowels, according to what is necessary to open the section with the instruments: and the section should be according to the quantity, as much as is possible, that it may go out of it whole.
Deinde excoria siphak, et quae sunt sub cute testiculorum, donec quando detegitur sifach album, durum ab omni parte: tunc intromitte digitum tuum indicem in eo quod sequitur testiculum, in eo quod est inter siphach album, quod est sub cute oui, et inter sifach secundum, et absolue cum eo adhaerentiam quae est in posteriori parte oui.	Then strip away the skin and whatever is under the testicles until the white belly of the intestines is seen: then insert your finger into the index of that which follows the testicle, in that which is between the white belly and the testicle, and between the intestines and the white belly, and hold together what is on the back of the belly
Deinde moue cum manu dextra ad interiora cutem testiculorum: et cum hoc extende sifach album ad sursum, cum manu sinistra: et eleua ouum cum sifach ad partem sectionis: et praecipe ministro, ut extendat ouum ad sursum: et tu solue adhaerentiam, quae est retro solutione completa.	Then move with the right hand to the inside of the skin of the testicles: and with this extend the white belly upwards with the left hand: and elevate the gut with the white belly to the part of the section: and command the minister to extend the gut upwards: and you will solve the adhesion which is at the complete solution.
Et quaere digitis tuis, ut non sit aliquid illic ex intestino inuoluto in sifach albo duro.	And inquire with your fingers that there be nothing there in the gut which is in the white belly or hard.
Si autem inuenis ex eo aliquid: tunc impelle ipsum ad uentrem inferius.	If however you find anything there: then push it downwards into the belly.
Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	Then grasp the clamp, which has a thick thread made of ten threads: and insert it at the back of the intestines, that is, the layer which is under the skin of the testicles which follows the section: and cut off the extremities which project from the thread, until there are four threads left
Deinde compone quaedam eorum super quaedam cum figura quae sit in modo crucis: et liga cum eis alsifach, de quo diximus, quia est sub cute testiculorum ligamento uehementi, donec non possit aliquod ex uasis, quae nutriunt eos mittere ad eos aliquid: ut non accidat inde apostema calidum.	Then make a loop with some of them over some with a shape like a cross: and ligate with instruments as we have said, because the ligament which we have mentioned is under the skin of the testicles, and it cannot have any nourishment which nourishes anything: so that there may not be any suppuration of the belly.
Et pone iterum ligamentum secundum extra ligamentum primum, longinquum ab eo minus duobus digitis.	And place again a ligament outside the first ligament, which is longer than the two fingers by less than two fingers.
Et post ista duo ligamenta dimitte ex sifach, quod est sub cute testiculorum, quantitatem magnitudinis digiti: et incide reliquum totum secundum rotunditatem, et aufer ex eo ouum.	And after that, two ligatures must be let go from the siphons, which are under the skin of the testicles, as much as the quantity of the magnitude of a finger: and the rest must be cut through according to the roundness, and take out whatever remains.
Deinde seca in inferiori parte cutis testiculorum sectione, ex qua currit sanguis, et sanies: sicut narrauimus in eo quod praemissum est.	And after that, the lower part of the skin of the testicles must be sectioned off, from which blood runs, and it must be healed: as we have said before in this matter.
Deinde administra lanam submersam in oleo, et pone in uulnus: et administra ligamentum quod narrauimus.	Then apply a soaked bandage to the wound and put in a sponge: and manage the ligament which we have mentioned
Et quandoque cauterizatur sifach album quod diximus, post incisionem eius timendo de fluxu sanguinis.	And when the white siphons have been cauterized as we have mentioned, after the incision of it there is fear of the flow of blood.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	It often happens like this.
Et dimitte ligamentum, donec cadat per se.	And let go of the ligament, until it falls away by itself.
Si autem tardatur casus eius, tunc embrocetur cum aqua calida: et pone super ipsum illud quod diximus, donec cadat.	If, however, its case is delayed, it must be bound up with warm water: and put on top of it what we have mentioned, until it falls away
Deinde cura uulnus cum reliqua curatione uulnerum, donec curetur.	And then care for the wound with the rest of the treatment of wounds, until it heals.
¶ De Ramice uentosa.	Of a wound filled with blood.
Caput LXVI.	Chapter LXVI.
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	In such a wound no one should dare to put their hand over its treatment with a knife.
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	And the first will say that it is like what we have narrated in the Ramis which is like with a Vite.
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	That is, as a ligature has been made after the section above it with ease: then cut through in the middle, and care afterwards with what opens it up until the ligatures fall away: and care for the wound, as we have said, until it is healed
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	On the disruption which occurs in the groin.
Caput LXVII.	On the disruption which occurs in the groin.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	When a rupture happens in the groin, as we have said, and the place is prominent, and does not descend to the testicles anything from the intestines: and if it descends, it is little, and returns in every hour: but if it is prolonged with this time, an opening is added in the groin, until the intestines descend into the groin.
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	And this happens from the extension of the groin, which is in the groin, as we have said
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	That is, because the groin is stretched: then it softens and relaxes the place, and the place becomes prominent.
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	And its care is with cautery, as it has been said before.
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	And sometimes it is cured with an iron, in this way: and the patient lies on his back between your hands
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	Then dry the place of the rupture after it has relaxed and become prominent, by cutting across the width, according to the quantity of three fingers wide
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	Then string the intestines and those which are under the skin, until the white fat is detected, which is under the skin following it
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	Then take the radium and put it on the place which is prominent from the groin, and press it down to the depth of the belly
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	Then sew up two places which are prominent at the extremities of the radium from the groin, and join them with a single suture: then withdraw the extremity of the radium
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	And do not cut through the intestines at all, neither draw out any hair or anything else, like I told you in the treatment of intestinal branches
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	Then care for that of the wounds.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	When the threads are cut, bind up that, and restore the wound, until it is consolidated
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	Let it not be beaten against, and do not add prominence to the rupture.
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	And the cautery is better in this place: because it is closer to the flesh.
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	About the softening of the skin of the testicles
Caput LXVIII.	Chapter LXVIII.</start_of_turn>
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	Many times the skin of the testicles is softened in some men, because the flesh which is between them is softened, and its aspect is spoiled
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary for the one who is asking for its care, to make the diseased person lie upon his back, and to cut through the whole softened skin over the natural skin
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	Then gather up two lips together with a suture: and if you will, sweat at first the superfluous of the softened skin by means of three sutures, or four, and firmly suture them.
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	Then cut between the sutures.
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	Then care for the care of the remaining wounds, until they are healed, and the threads are cast off
¶ De Castratione.	About castration.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXIX.	Chapter LXIX.</start_of_turn
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	You know that castration is excluded in our law: and for this reason I am not permitted to remind you of it in this book: and it is not necessary to remind you of it, except for two ways.</start_of_turn>
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	Of which one is that it should be in the science of medicine when it is asked about: and to know its treatment when it happens.</start_of_turn
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	And thus another method is that we often need to castrate some animals for our treatments, such as horses, asses, and cats, and those of the like.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	I say therefore, that castration is done in two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	Or by cutting off.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	Or by incision and cutting through
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	And in that way which is done by attrition, the operation is this: we make the animal sit in warm water, until the testicles become soft and limp, and hang down: then we take hold of the testicles and draw them out until they break and do not appear under the touch
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	And in castration done by incision and cutting, it is necessary to hold the animal securely and grasp the testicles with the left hand.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	Then tighten the cord and cut through all the surrounding tissue at one place, until when two testicles have descended: then you cut through them after you have excised the fat surrounding each one, and do not leave anything protruding except for the fine fat
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	And this method of castration is better than that done by attrition: for attrition may perhaps leave something behind from the testicles, which the animal may still desire for coitus.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound, until it has healed.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	And for the care of hermaphrodites there are two methods.
Caput LXX.	Chapter 70.
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	A hermaphrodite is born from two parents.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	One of them is that it appears in the space between the scrotum and the testicles, or in the area between the two testicles, a figure like that of a female vulva, in which there are hairs: and sometimes urine comes from the area between the testicles.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	Among women there exists one kind, and the vulva of a woman is above the pubic bone like the testicles of a small man altogether, projecting outwards: of which one is like the penis of a man, and two are like two testicles.
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	And the care of the three kinds, of two from the men and one from the women, is: because it is necessary to cut away the added flesh until the impression of them is driven out.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	Then the care of the rest of the wounds.
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	As for the second kind of men from which urine proceeds, which is in the belly of the testicles, there is no operation, neither is there any care for it whatsoever
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	Of the incision of the Tenticle, and the protruding flesh in the vulvas of women
Caput LXXI.	Chapter LXXI.</start_of_turn>
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	The Tenticle sometimes adds itself above the natural thing, until it is fed and becomes ugly in appearance: and sometimes it swells in certain women so much, that it expands like in the men, and persists until coitus.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	It is necessary therefore to cut away the superfluous Tenticle with one or two incisions: and do not finish by cutting through, especially at the root: lest there should happen the flow of blood
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then the care of the wound itself, until it is healed
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	The flesh which is born in the mouth of the womb, until it has been completed: and perhaps it comes out to the outside according to the form of a tail: and because of this some call it caudal fistula.
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore to cut away the flesh as we do the Tenticle, and to care for it, until it is healed
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	Concerning the care of the Alratica, which is a woman’s navel that is unpierced.
Caput LXXII.	Concerning the care of the Alratica, which is a woman’s unpierced navel.
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	The Alratica is, as it is a woman’s unpierced navel, or a small hole.
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	It is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	It is accidental from an injury that preceded it: and thus it is either born from the flesh added to it, or from a fine membrane, or from a hair: and it is either in the depth of the matrix, or in the sides of it, or in the upper part of it, or in the lower part of it: and it hinders coition and pregnancy, and delivery, and perhaps it hinders menstruation
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	And its knowledge is by the aspect of the obstetrician, if the visible hair is close at hand
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	If it is not visible, then seek for it with your fingers, or with an X-ray
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	If it is from a fine membrane, and is close to two teeth: then correct it, and break it up.</start_of_turn>
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	And it is like placing over two lips two little pins.</start_of_turn
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	Then place your thumbs of both hands together, and the woman sits with her back resting on her buttocks.</start_of_turn
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	Then stretch out two lips with force, until the fine membrane is ruptured, and the hair is opened.</start_of_turn>
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	Then grasp the hair, and soak it in oil, and put it in its place: and the woman should lie down every day, so that it does not harden in another place.</start_of_turn
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	If, however, the membrane is thick and tough: then it is necessary to cut it with a blade like a sickle leaf.</start_of_turn>
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	If, however, the swelling is from flesh grown, then suspend it with hooks, and cut it through: and let there be with you medicines which flow blood without biting, such as acacia, and dragon's blood, and thus aggregated with alum.
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then give a wide lead pencil made of lead, so that it does not harden too quickly, and keep it for a few days: and give an ointment of dry lint, then care for the rest of the treatment until healed.</start_of_turn>
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	And when there is born in the matrix the swelling of other tissues: it is necessary therefore that they be cut through in this way: for as long as there is no cancerous ulcer, there is no contradiction with iron in all things.</start_of_turn>
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	Concerning the care of hemorrhoids, Athehelil, and Bothor of the red ones in women.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXXIII.	Chapter 73.</start_of_turn
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	Hemorrhoids are indeed a bursting of the veins, until blood flows out excessively.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	When they are thus diminished, hemorrhoids become small: and I have already said in the discourse of their species and their signs: and I will say here what is taken from them for treatment, and what is not.</start_of_turn
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	I say, therefore, that hemorrhoids which are in the belly opening, and which do not appear to the senses: then there is no treatment with iron for them.</start_of_turn
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	Those which are however in the belly opening over which the sense falls, are those which are cured.</start_of_turn
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	It is necessary therefore that you admit the woman to a cold house.</start_of_turn
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	Then suspend the hemorrhoids with hooks, or with rough cloth, and cut them from their roots.</start_of_turn
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	Then powdered ochre above the ease [of bleeding] with flow of blood from one perforation without alteration: as acacia, and dragon's blood, and thus, and the like.
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	Then powder it upon the foot an hour together with the wall.
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	Then place it in cold water afterwards
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	If the flow of blood persists: then make the patient sit in a decoction of alum, and barley flour, and saffron, and the like.
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	Then take barley flour, and mix it with honey and vinegar, and make a plaster with it on his back.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	If blood is thus shed with it, it is good: and if not, make it adhere to the wound edges, and blood clots, without cutting
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	Then take wool, and soak it in tarragon oil, or arnica oil, or almond oil, that is, alum, wine of potage, and make it adhere to the wound
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	When the swelling subsides, then care for the place with unguents until it is healed.
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	Although it is red like the heads of garlic, and has a rough appearance
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	It is necessary therefore that you cut off what appears from it, as I have said before: and care for the wound until it is healed
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	Of the perforation of the uterus which happens in the matrix.
Caput LXXIIII.	Chapter 74.
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	Many kinds of swelling happen in the matrix, as cancer, and stone swelling, and ulcer, and tumors, and swellings, and herpes, and swelling of the spleen, and fistula, and hemorrhoids, and piles, and calculus, and cold swelling.
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro.	And I say moreover that I have mentioned all the diseases and their kinds, their signs and their treatments in this discourse: it is necessary that I speak in this treatise about the calcification that occurs in the matrix when it is separated from the other calculi which support health, and to describe how it is opened with an iron.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is necessary to consider this matter carefully.
Tunc si dolor apostematis in incaeptione sua est acutus cum percussione sua, et flamma, et febre: et uides ipsum rubere: si cadit super ipsum sensus, tunc non properes cum perforatione eius: et cura ipsum cum eo eo quod iuuat super maturationem, donec quando quiescat acuitas accidentium.	If the pain of a calculus in its inception is acute with percussion, fire and fever: and you see it become red: if it falls upon the senses, do not attempt to perforate it: care for it with that which helps the maturation of the calculus until the acute pain has subsided
Tunc oportet ut facias sedere mulierem super sedem quae labeat duo sedilia, et reclinetur, uel appodietur super dorsum suum, et aggreget pedes suos ad partem inferiorem uentris: et sint coxae eius expansae, et ponat brachia sua sub genibus suis, et liget utraque ligamento conueniente ad illud.	Then it is necessary to make the woman sit upon a cushion which supports two cushions, and that she recline, or that she be placed upon her back, and that she bring her feet down to the lower part of the belly: and that her knees be spread wide, and that she rest her arms under her knees, and that she bind both ligaments conveniently to that.
Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	Then let the obstetrician sit to the right, and administer the instrument with which the opening of the maternal orifice is opened.
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	Whose form comes in those things which are after.
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	And it is necessary that when you administer this instrument, you should hold the liver with a wide grasp at the root of the maternal matrix: so that it does not go deeper into the matrix than is necessary, and does not injure the lower part.
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	If however the instrument should be greater in size than the depth of the maternal matrix, then it is necessary to place sponges upon the covering of the profound matrix: in order to prevent the entrance of the whole instrument into the profound matrix: and it is necessary to place a sponge, which runs through the instrument, from the upper side: and to hold the instrument and to rotate the minister of the sponge until the profound matrix is opened
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	When the exit [of an abscess] appears, and it is grasped by the hand, and is soft and yielding: then it is necessary to cut it out from its root with a wide scalpel.
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	When the abscess has been evacuated, then it is necessary to place a swab dipped in vinegar or a green olive oil, which has some astringency, on the root of the excision: and lay the swab on, and extract the section from the depth of the belly.
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	And place externally over the abdomen and over the wound a wet wool blanket submerged in water, in which there are bulges of pus.
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then care for it two days later with an ointment which is suitable for this, until it is healed
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	And when the belly and the wound have been washed, it is to be bathed with water and honey: then with water in which the radix of lily or long asparagus is boiled: then return to the ointment.
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	If the wound has been hidden inside the belly, then it is necessary to prohibit treatment of it with iron, and treat it with that which we have said in the instruction.
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	Concerning obstetrical doctrine, how to treat the embryos of women, according to a figure not natural of the egress.
Caput Lxxu.	The provided text does not include the translation of the remaining portion of the sentence, so I am unable to complete the translation request.
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	It is necessary for the Obstetrician to first recognize the natural figure of delivery.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	When a woman, during labor, is pressed downwards and desires to smell the air, and she lets out a sound over what is above her that is of delivery, and the fetus comes out: then you know that this delivery is natural, and that the head is coming out first, and the second with it: or suspended, or hanging from the navel.
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	When these signs appear, it is necessary to compress the abdomen, so that the embryo may descend quickly.
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	Since when it descends from the head, the second part descends with it, and they are carried out by those superfluities which cause them harm
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	Whoever is beyond this part is unnatural and harmful
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	For when the fetus comes out through the feet, and the body goes before the head, and the feet and hands together, or one foot alone: or the head and hands together: or the abdomen: or perhaps it turns over on its neck, and similar things happen with other figures which are harmful.
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	It is necessary therefore for the Obstetrician to be prudent and cautious in all these matters, and to beware of error and miscarriage: and I show all the figures of these things and how they are formed, and I indicate their significance, and I stand over them.
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	When the fetus comes out through the head naturally, and when it urges itself forward on the woman, and the delivery becomes difficult for her, and the signs of its weakness are seen: then let her sit down, or let the women hold her up: and let her breathe deeply with the smoke of rue and with fragrant oils.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	Then let the Obstetrician insert his fingers between the toes of the heel and find the second one, and grasp it with his nail, until it comes out from the moisture: and press the woman's abdomen until the fetus comes down
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	If it does not come down, then it is necessary to instill the woman with the mucus of rue, with the addition of sesame seeds
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	Then command her to bear down forcefully: and make her cough with a spasm, and hold her hand and nose for an hour.
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	The fetus forthwith departs.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	If two hands of the fetus depart at the outset, it is necessary to reduce them gradually with ease
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	If, however, they do not yield inwards, then place the woman over the seat and elevate her feet above: then press down upon the seat with the earth: and the woman should be held, lest she fall at the impact.
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	If the hands do not depart and the fetus dies, then cut down the hands and extract the remainder of the fetus: and bind the hand with a cloth and extract it with evenness: for it itself will depart.
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	The fetus emerges upon its feet
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	When the fetus emerges upon its feet, then it is necessary to push it upwards: then gradually bend the fetus: afterwards equalize it
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	Then grasp one foot of it and extend it gradually.
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	When they depart up to the hips, then command it to lie down, that it may be compressed, and make it yawn with force: it will depart if God wills it
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	And if it does not depart as we have said, then gradually reduce the fetus until you place it according to its natural form.
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	For it itself will depart at the time of delivery.
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	If it is hindered as to this, then take from the thick mucus of the navel-cord, and sponge it with oil, and gum dissolved: and pierce all through in the belly of the stillborn with a good blow: then bind it with the woman's urine, and the lower part of her belly.
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	Then make it sit in warm water, until the afterbirth follows naturally.
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	When the lower parts are swollen from heat, make for them a sieve of myrrh: and support them.
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	When the lower parts are swollen from heat, make for them a sieve of myrrh and support them.
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	Then make them lie down: and bind their limb and nose: and compress the lower part of the belly with ease
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	For the heat will go out immediately.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	The heat goes out above the knee and the hand
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	When it has gone out in this form, then it comes inwards gradually touching the hand
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	Then the woman lies down on her neck, and hangs her feet downwards: and she lies down on the bed, and puts her hands together
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	Then compress the belly gradually.
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	Then draw out what is under her feet from the nails until it is prepared in the lower part.
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	If the heat does not go out, then grasp her feet and move them up and down with might
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	Then compress what is above the navel gradually, until the heat ascends to the upper parts
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	Then put your hands inwards gradually and equalize the heat gradually: and command the woman to compress, until the heat goes out.
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	The heat goes out laterally hanging from the hands
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	It comes down in the reduction of her hand.
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	If it is not possible to reduce it, then elevate the woman, and make her walk.
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	If she is unable to walk, then make her lie down on the bed: and bruise her limbs with a slight blow
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	Then apply the unguent which you prepared from mucilages.
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	If it is grasped by a part, then make it rest upon its seat
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	Then consider in reduction of the hand, and equalize the limb according to its natural shape: and make the woman groan, and command her to compress herself, until she is discharged
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	The limb comes out over its collar, with open hands, and its face is towards the mother's back
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	Let the Obstetrix grasp the limb, then gradually rotate it, and equalize it with ease.
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	When it is equal, then place upon its wound what we have mentioned from the ole and mucilages
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	Then command her to move slowly
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	When you have done this, then make her sit upon her seat, and command her to lean to the right side
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	Then command her to compress: and make her groan with concentration.
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	The limb is prepared to come out on the right side
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	When it has descended to the opening of the matrix in this way with the second, then split the second with your nail, until it is evacuated from the moisture.
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	If it is suspended upon the face of the limb, and the collar, then cut it from the navel: so that it does not remain and die
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	Then drive the limb inwards, until you place it according to what is necessary: and command the woman to compress herself somewhat: she will depart by herself through the easy exit.
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	The exit of twins, or many fetuses.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	You know that twins are often born: sometimes three are born, and sometimes four.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	It is indeed an unusual thing, and rarely happens.
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	Indeed, it is beyond nature for five to survive together: and they are separated by the navel-string of each of them.
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	Sometimes they come out like a single fetus through the natural outlet: easily. But sometimes they come out through an unnatural outlet, as we have mentioned.
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	If some of them are difficult at the birth, and approach that which we have mentioned as unnatural, then care for them as we have said: and let the midwife be gentle and do as she does with ease and delay, and adapt to every figure as she is prepared for it from her skill and experience
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	Remember that this comes about in the womb from the embryos, and they are aborted
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	When one, two, three, four, five, six, seven or more are formed in the womb: and indeed I have seen a woman who aborted seven, and another who aborted fifteen of them all formed
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	Which is the work of the measurement of a wise man
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	Therefore all this pertains to the science of Obstetrics.
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	Perhaps therefore it will be like that: oppose it with that which pertains to it.
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	Of the extraction of a dead fetus.
Caput LXXVI.	Chapter 76.
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	When you care for a dead fetus with medicine as I said in the discourse and it does not come out, and you must perform an operation with your hands, then you must consider carefully
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	If a woman is of good virtue and is not suffering from any accident which would cause her to fear the loss of her life: then it is necessary that she lie down upon the bed, with her head inclined downwards and her legs elevated: and the attendants must hold her firm from two parts, or she must be bound to the bed, so that her body is not pulled out during the extraction of the fetus.
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	Then the moisture of the matrix is to be taken from olive oil with alum, fennel, and poppyseed.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	Then the obstetrician should wet his hand with these oils and mucilages: then he introduces the instrument into the matrix with ease.
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	Then he seeks the location in which the hooks of the fetus are fixed, and the convenient place for it
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	Consider then, if the fetus is prepared to descend upon its head: then fix the hooks in its eyes, or in its neck, or in its mouth, or in its palate, or under its beard, or under its chin, or in the neighbouring ribs, and under the hypopondria
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	If however the descent is upon its feet, then in the loin and the middle ribs
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	And it is necessary that the hook be held with the right hand: and put the curvature of the hand on that which is between the little finger and the ring finger: and introduce it with the hand with ease, and fix the hook in one of those places which we mentioned, until it reaches the navel
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	And fix in opposition to it the other hook, or the third, if necessary: so that there is an equal tension, and it does not incline towards the part
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	And be extended with an equal extension, and do not be extended only in a straight line, but move towards all parts, so as to relieve its exit: thus it is done with a tooth during its extraction.
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	It is necessary in this that which is between them, so that the swelling may be softened.
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	If that which is retained from that remains, then it is necessary that the physician apply some fingers with oil to that part, and introduce them from the side, so that it may recoil with that which is retained
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	If therefore the part of the fetus goes out, then change the nails to another place which is higher: do this until the whole fetus comes out.
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	If therefore the hand goes out before the other, and it is not possible to reduce it because of its adhesion: then it is necessary that it be covered over with a dressing
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	Then extract it until when the whole thing comes out, it hangs by the nail or at the ankle joint: and so it is necessary that you make the hand in the other place, and in two feet.
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	If however the head of the fetus is large, or if there is adhesion in its going out, or there is water gathered in the head: then it is necessary that the surgeon introduce between the fingers a Spatumile spinosum, and find the head with it, and extract the water: or break it with the instrument which is called Almisdac, which has a form like that of the other instruments in the following chapter.
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	Likewise do in the case of a fetus of large head, then it is necessary that the membrane be divided: or extract it with the placenta, as we have said.
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	Then draw out the bones with forceps.
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	If therefore the head goes out, and is caught at the ribs: then it is found until the moisture which is in the chest is drained out.
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	If therefore it does not complicate, neither obeys the going out: then cut off the head roughly, as much as is possible to you
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	If the lower part of the belly is affected with swelling, or is affected with water-retention: then it is necessary to drain it out until the moisture has subsided from it.
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	If the fetus lies upon its feet, then its traction is easy, and its direction towards the maternal bones is gentle.
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	If, however, it is closed up within the belly, or the chest: then it is necessary to pull it out with the hand which you put over your hand: and uncover the belly, or the chest, until the swelling has subsided from it
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	If, however, the rest of the limbs are raised up, and the head is returned: then the obstetrician puts in his left hand.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	If, therefore, the maternal bones are open: then he puts his hand into the depth of the womb, and grasps the head, and pulls it down with his fingers until it reaches the maternal bones: and then he puts in his thumb, or two thumbs, and pulls with them
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	If, however, the maternal bones are closed, because of a thick swelling which has happened to it: then it is not necessary to work over it, but it is necessary to administer an effusion of soft things: and administer plasters: and sit in waters which soften and moisten
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	If the fetus lies upon its side: it is possible to equalise it: then it is necessary to administer what we said concerning the present fetus.
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	If it is not possible to do this, then it is necessary to make an incision, and to extract it.
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	And it is necessary not to let anything escape from the second part altogether.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	When you have completed your operation, then administer what we said concerning the postpartum swellings which happen in the womb
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	If blood flow increases, let it descend into the styptic aquas, and manage the rest of the treatment.
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	I have also seen a woman who had a dead fetus within her: afterwards she was impregnated above the former blood, then the other fetus also died.
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	It happened to her after a long time that she had a swelling in her belly, and it became inflated until it burst open: pus began to flow from it.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	I was called to treat her and I treated her for a long time: the wound did not heal
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	I placed upon her from some strong sponges some attraction: and it came out from the bone place
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	Afterwards a few days passed, and the bone came out again.
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	I rejoice in this, because there is no longer any bone in the belly
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	I thought that there were dead fetuses' bones in her belly
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	I inquired about the wound and extracted many bones, the existing woman being in a better state: and from that time on she emitted little pus from the place
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	I did not confirm this to be foreign, except that there is art in it, and the aid of a skillful physician with his hands in treatment.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	Concerning the forms of the necessary instruments for extracting the fetus.
Caput LXXVII.	Chapter 77.
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	Here below is the form of the Strictor, which is like a book, with two rings at the ends of two sticks being equal in number to two rings.
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	Indeed this vertigo must be finer than the strictor: or make it either of ebony or of seasoned wood
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	The breadth of every limb is like two fingers; and the margin of each side is like a single finger; and the length of each of them is palm and middle. And in the middle of the two limbs are two bulges of the same kind of limb which, having been fixed in both, have a length of middle palm and somewhat less; and the breadth of each of them is like two fingers, or less.
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	Two bulges intervene inside the bone of the matrix, so that it opens when two vertebrae are turned.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	The form of the vertebra which opens the matrix
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	Another shape like that, thinner and smoother
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	It is made from Ebony wood, or ivory, according to the shape of pincers
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	In its extremity there are two bulges, like the two thumbs above: and the length of each bulge is like a palm; and the breadth of each is like two fingers
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	When therefore you wish to open the matrix with this, then make a woman sit over a bench, with her feet hanging down, and open that which is between her buttocks
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	Then introduce these two bulges together into the matrix: and you hold the lower end of the instrument between her thighs
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	Then open your hand with the instrument, like you do with pincers, equally according to the quantity of what you wish to open from the opening of the matrix, until the obstetrician does what he wants
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	The other form of the vertebra is called the driving force which drives out the fetus.
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	The almond-shaped form which contains the great head: and it is assimilated to a pair of pincers which have teeth in their extremity, like the thumbs
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	When the limb is twisted, as with forceps of this kind, like water which has teeth like sharp teeth, with which it incides and counteracts.
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	The form of the Almisdac which counteracts the head of the small bones
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	The form of the neighbor having a single spine
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	The form of the neighbor having two spines
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	The form of the forceps which have teeth like sharp teeth, with which it counteracts the head of the fetus.
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	The form of the spatula having two extremities to bind the head
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	The form of two spatulas also of the hands
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	These instruments are used for all purposes, and the more various their kinds and the more they are prepared by the artificer, the faster is the operation and the greater is its success among men, because of their quantity.
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	Do not disdain any of these instruments because they are prepared for you
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	It is inexcusable for anyone to be without these things.
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	About the extraction of the second [tooth].
Caput LXXVIII.	Chapter 78.
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	When the second [tooth] is retained at the root, then it is necessary to remove the lower teeth in order to retain the breath.
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	Then make a grasp with your thumb and index finger: and clench your hand over its bone, and cover its breath.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	If it comes out by this, that is good.
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	If not: then grasp the root firmly, and pierce through the socket with a needle: and put in it herbs that open the womb, such as chamomile, rue, mugwort, mint, parsley, and acacia: grasp all these herbs, or some of them, and soak them in water, and put them over fire.
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	Then place an embolus of Arundis over the opening of the coopertor's vessel, and the other extremity in the bone of the matrix: and keep it in place until the vapor has passed to the cavity of the matrix.
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	Then make a mark as we have said before.</start_of_turn>
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	It will come out easily afterwards.</start_of_turn>
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	If, however, it remains after this treatment and does not come out: then command the Obstetrician to immerse his hand in the fat of sesame or high mucus.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	Then he will introduce it into the belly and search with it.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	When he has found it, then grasp it and pull it out slowly.</start_of_turn
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	If, however, it is an appendix in the depth of the matrix, then introduce the hand again, as we have said above, until it has found the appendix, and then pull it out gradually in a straight line, so that the matrix is not torn by the pulling: indeed it is necessary to move it with ease to the right and left: then add in quantity the attraction.</start_of_turn>
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	It will obey you then, and will be cured, and will go away from the adhesion.</start_of_turn
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	As for the bone of the matrix if it is contracted, as we have said before: treat it with a mark and medication of the vessel with herbs.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	If, however, it does not come out with all that we have said: do not be rash in your handling of it in your attempt to extract it.</start_of_turn
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	It is necessary, however, that what comes out of the matrix towards the woman's side should be bound to the woman's hip.</start_of_turn
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	Then anoint the cavity with unguent composed of four drugs.
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	It will putrefy the cavity within a few days, then dissolve and disappear.
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	Truly, when putrefying, it will emit a foul odor from the abdomen and head, and will bring about discomfort in that area.
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	Therefore, it is necessary to apply suitable fumigations for this purpose
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	Some of the old ones are experts in fumigation with mustard and powdered alum
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	The manner in which a woman is fumigated during her second stage and menstruation
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	It should be like a bath of urine, or from the horns of a wild ass: and put out wide extremities over the flame: and let the fumigation be placed over the loins: hold it until the fumigation is consumed: and do it again another time
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	For the treatment of an unpierced animal.
Caput LXXIX.	Chapter LXXIX.
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	There are many boys who are born with an unpierced nose, and whom I have seen to suffer from slight swelling under the tip of the nose
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	Therefore, the obstetrician must pierce it with his finger: and if not, pierce it with a pointed spatula: and take care not to touch it
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	Then put on it soaked wool in wine and oil
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with unguents, until it heals.
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	If indeed it is to be pierced, then put in the hole a lead cannula for many days, and take it out when the boy wants to breathe freely.
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	And sometimes the piercing of the nose is caused by the consolidation of a wound, or by a fistula.
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	It is necessary therefore that the incision be complete and the consolidation be removed, and then it is cured as we have said with the dressing and lead.
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	Concerning the treatment of fistulas which occur in the lower part.
Caput LXXX.	Chapter 8.
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	Fistulas which occur in the lower part are of two kinds: Nodatio and Grossitudo which occur close to any deformity: and are either one fistula or several
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	When the Nodatio has been removed, it is opened and white watery moisture or subtle pus runs from it
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	And when these fistulas are penetrating.
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	They are recognized as penetrating by what comes out with the discharge and the swelling, when the patient expels something from his bowels: and perhaps something from the worms
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	The fistula is from the worms when they are penetrating up to the rectum and even to the meat of the bowels.
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	And they are penetrating from the worms up to the joint of the hip, and up to the node of the tailbone
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	However, that which is recognized as a penetrating fistula until it reaches the bone, even if it is not penetrating, is when you introduce your finger into the fistula with an index of your hand: and introduce a thin needle into the fistula from the air, or from the iron, when there is no swelling
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	When there is swelling, then introduce into the fistula a thin needle from lead or a hair from a horse's tail, until you feel the needle, or the hair in your finger
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	If you do not feel the needle itself, or if there is no discharge from the wound, or swelling, or worms as I have said: then you know that it is not penetrating: so proceed with the treatment
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	When the fistula is penetrating as far as the bladder or the meat of the urine: then its signification is the outflow of urine from it, and its prohibition from this so that the place may be consolidated with the physicians.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	When it is penetrating as far as the hip joint or the bone of the hip: then its sign is that the limb hangs there, if not with a twist as far as the bone: and the origin of pain in the circumference of the part, and that pus always comes out from it: and that no remedy is useful in it, neither is it consolidated with oil
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	And in all these penetrating fistulas there is no complete cure: the cure for them is toil and perseverance, from the stupid physicians who form them.
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	But in those which are neither penetrating nor old, hope for healing is expected with rest: as I have said before and I will prove: and it is that the sick man should lie between your hands over his back: and lift his legs up to above his hips, and that his thighs should be inclined towards his belly
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	Then introduce lead, or air, if there is a twist in the fistula, until you know where the limb hangs
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	And if the sick man feels pain around the limb, then it is necessary to put your finger on the limb.
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	If you feel the limb trying to penetrate through itself that you have detected, besides that which you feel between your finger and the limb, and between the flesh: then you know certainly that it is penetrating: it is not useful to work on it, because its cure is not like that which we have said
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	They say that in some men the wound is healed by the carnation of flesh, and by the application of medicine which is expected to cause it to swell: that is, as before, to apply gentle fire under the circumference of the fistula, as has been said, and to introduce the flame into the fistula, until it hangs around the limb
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	Then repeat that twice or thrice until you know that all the added flesh has become soft, like the veins of a bird's wing.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	Then deal with the wound covered with butter, until the added flesh comes out: then deal with it when the flesh has become soft.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	If it is healed, that is good.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	And if not, it will not heal with any other treatment
Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	And if it comes out and does not reach until your finger which is in the year, and is between the thumb and the great toe, and there is thick blood from the flesh, or pus: then make an incision in that which follows the surface of the skin, then dry the skin from the start of the incision, and you dry with the finger which is in the fistula until the drying reaches the extremity of the finger, and the finger is freed and falls off
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	Then soften the soft flesh which has become like the veins of a bird's wing, so that nothing remains of it
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	If however blood has clotted between you and the operation, so that you cannot remove the flesh: then it is better to cauterize with fire or with acute medicine
Quoniam cauterium cum igne aggregat habitudines bonas, adustionem illarum carnium additarum, et abscisionem sanguinis, et exiccationem humiditatum.	For indeed cauterizing with fire unites good habits, brings together the added flesh, and stops bleeding, and dries moisture
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, aut caulibus tritis, donec locus emittat pus, et egrediantur illae carnes adustae in pus.	Then deal with the wound covered with butter, or bruised stalks, until pus comes out, and the added flesh comes out with the pus.
