Deinde cura tunc uulnus cum unguentis consolidatiuis, generantibus carnem duram: et sunt medicinae in quibus sunt stipticitas et exiccatio.	Then deal with the wound with solid supports, consolidative unguents, which generate tough flesh: and these are medicines which have stypticity and drying power.
Nam quando restaurantur, tunc iam sanatur: et non times iterationem.	When restoration is complete, then healing follows: and not by repetition.
Si autem Fistula iam peruenit usque ad profundum ani, et elongatur a superfluitate corporis: tunc intromitte digitum tuum in anum, et inquire cum eo.	When the fistula persists deep in the rectum and is prolonged by excess of body weight: then insert your finger into the rectum and inquire about it.
Si ergo sentis tentam, et inter te, et inter eam est uelamen ex sifac, aut carne, et est propinqua penetrationi: tunc non est operatio in illo, nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	If you feel resistance, and between you and the fistula there is either fat or flesh, and it is close to the penetration: then there is no operation in that place, except as a last resort, with confidence and hope
Quod est, quia administratur in eo unus trium modorum: aut ut cauterizes ipsam, sicut diximus: aut seces eam, donec consequaris concauitatem eius, ut sit possibile tibi intromittere licinia, et curationem ex proximo.	For in that case one must administer three methods: either you cauterize the fistula itself, as we have said; or you dissect the vein, until you have reached its depth, so that you can afterwards introduce a ligature and effect a cure.
Et non procedas multum cum sectione, ut non incidas lacertum continentem anum, et accidat super infirmum exitus egestionis absque uoluntate.	And do not proceed too much with the incision, lest you cut through the membrane of the rectum, and cause an excessive discharge of feces without their consent.
Deinde cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then care for it as we have said
Fortasse enim sanabitur: aut elonges ipsum uelamen, et mundes ipsum postquam secas ipsum usque prope anum, sicut diximus, aut cum tenta, aut cum instrumento alio acutae extremitatis.	Perhaps indeed it will heal: or you will lengthen the vein, and cleanse it when dry until it is close to the rectum, as we have said, or with the finger or with an acute instrument.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas quae sunt in sectione, usque ubi potes cum perscrutatione.	Then remove the clotted blood which is in the incision, until it is firm with the touch of the finger.
Deinde conare restaurationem uulneris totius cum sectione, et orificio superiore ubi consolidatur: et remanet Fistula aperta in interiore parte anus, et erit leuius super infirmum.	Then attempt to restore the whole wound with the incision, and the upper orifice where it has been consolidated: and the fistula will remain open in the inner part of the rectum, and will be less painful
Et quandoque suitur Fistula secundum hunc modum: et est, quando intromittis tentam in Fistulam: et est in latere ani circa superficiem corporis cum cute et margine ani: tunc accipe tentam perforatae extremitatis, quae est sicut acus aleskef, id est, praeparantium coria, secundum hanc formam.	And when you suture the fistula in this way: that is when you insert your finger into the fistula: and it is at the side of the rectum around the surface of the body with skin and the margin of the rectum: then grasp the perforated extremity, which is like a needle with a head, that is, prepared for splitting the skin, according to this form.
Et intromitte in eam filum inuolutum ex quinque filis, et circiter ea.	And introduce into the loop five threads, and encircle them.
Deinde intromitte tentam cum filo in Fistulam, donec consequatur concauitatem eius.	Then introduce a tensioner with a thread into the fistula, until its concavity follows it.
Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	If there is a perforation in the inner margin of the anus near the root, then withdraw the thread from that hole: so that you can introduce your finger into the anus and withdraw the end of the thread, and join the two ends together: and tighten both of them, and let it go on the first or second day: and the more the thread has penetrated the flesh, tighten it well, until those parts of the flesh which are between the two ends of the thread have become soft and fallen away: then care for the wound, until it has healed and become whole again.
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	But if the opening of the fistula is not penetrating: then make it penetrate in whatever way you prepare it, except that it is not in too deep
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	You must not make it penetrate because of the tear, so that you do not damage it
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	Then do as we said above, until it has healed.</start_of_turn>
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	Make the sponge of spicery which is found in the fistula, which has an acute curvature upwards, and the other part is not acute, so that it does not damage what is not necessary, like water.</start_of_turn>
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	As for the stitching of hemorrhoids from which blood runs from the incision of them: and care of the incisions.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXXXI.	Chapter 81.</start_of_turn>
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	There are hemorrhoids of two kinds.</start_of_turn
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	Or they are inside the anus, like the stones of a grape, or cherries: or they are like the seeds of a bean.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	There are both small and large ones among them: and blood always flows from them, and it is one, and there are many.
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	They are outside the body and at their extremities
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	Indeed, those that are outside the body are mostly small and moist, from which flows clear water, or rather blood that flows slowly: and they are according to the color of the body.
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	And the treatment of the one that is inside the body is that you must apply pressure to the wound: and express [the blood], until the anus comes out, and then appear the stitches.
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	Therefore, do the same with hooks and suspend with your finger.
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	Then cut at the roots of these things
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	If they do not remain in the body by their hooks, because of the moisture of these and their softening: then cover them with rough cloth, or with wool felt, and draw them out with your fingers
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then cut at the wound, and powder over the wound after cutting any warm powder, so that it stays in place like cautery
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterize them according to what was said in the chapter on cautery
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for the wound until it heals.
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	If the anus does not come out, then instill the patient with a small enema in the rectum, so that it is washed with it when he defecates, and the wound will come out quickly, when the patient defecates.
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	If however the stitches are outside the rectum, then the thing is easy: and it is as if you were grasping them with your finger, or grasping them with a hook, and cutting them off
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then care for them until they are healed.
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	Whoever shuns incision with the sword, must now administer suture according to this method.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Take a prepared thread, and introduce it into the wound
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then draw out the needle to the upper part, and make it penetrate with the needle at the root from the other side: and pass through two extremities of the thread, in the lower part of the needle, and let them be lateral: and tighten the thread strongly.
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then knot the thread, and draw out the needle
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all the wounds, and let go of the needle from one hand: and do not let it touch, so as to prevent excessive bleeding from it.
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then place over the wound a soaked bandage in rose-water, or vinegar, and put it over the wound: and command the patient to rest.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then let go of it until it has healed.
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When the wounds have healed, care for them with unguents, and remain with them until they are healed
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	(End of excerpt
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	Many times these occur from excessive straining of the bowels, and the nature of constriction.)
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When these things have been done, and they do not yield in medicine: then it is necessary to make incisions with the point of a Spatumilian needle, or with your finger, until they become moist, and the outer layer which hinders consolidation be removed.)
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then care for them until they are consolidated according to what is necessary.)
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	If, however, they do not consolidate: then repeat the incisions with greater reason than before, until they bleed a great deal, and are afterwards cared for until they are healed.)
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	On the treatment of swellings of the limbs, and of those not in the limbs: and of bites of scorpions, and of ants.
Caput LXXXII.	On the treatment of swelling of the limbs, and those not in the limbs: and of bites of scorpions, and of ants.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	You know that an Almirmar is not anything except a round node according to the colour of the body, like a head of a nail: and it happens throughout the body, especially in the lower parts of the feet and the fingers: and it arises from pain in walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	It is necessary therefore that you drain what is around the nail, and hold it with forceps, or with a needle, and eradicate it from its root
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then care for it: and if you wish, cauterize it according to what is before mentioned in its chapter.
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	As for bites of scorpions, one of them is a small, rough, filtered, round elevation above the surface of the body
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And they happen many times in the hands of children.
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And the treatment of it is to extend the bite, and to cut it: or to tie it with a silk thread: or with a hair, until it falls out
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you wish, cauterize it according to what is mentioned above with fire, or with acute medicine: and thus the bites of the inversed and the non-inverted scorpion will be eradicated with an instrument which I will tell you of
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	And as for ants, it is also a small, filtered elevation, large, above the surface of the body, which swells inwards: and when it comes into contact with cold, it feels like the bite of an ant, and it happens throughout the body: and most of them happen in the hands
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And the treatment of it is to take a needle from the beak of a sparrow, or a strong bristle: and put it over the ant, until a circle of the thread is contained from its parts
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then draw your hand back with the needle until you have severed what is around the ant: and place the needle deep into the flesh, and extract the ant from its root.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	Or if you wish, do this with an air needle, or a needle of iron, according to this fashion.</start_of_turn>
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the upper part of the needle reach the tip of the thumb which is being grasped, so that it may relieve the tension of the thumb and its retraction.</start_of_turn>
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	Or if you wish, cauterize the ant according to what has been stated in the chapter on cautery of the Athelil.</start_of_turn
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	Concerning the forms of instruments which are administered to Clisteria in ailments of the animal, and concerning the solution of the belly and the colon.</start_of_turn>
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter 83.</start_of_turn>
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	When the Clistera becomes ex silver, or from gold, or from blown glass, or hammered out.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And when they are made of these instruments, small and large, according to those in which they are administered.</start_of_turn
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	This is because it is administered in the care of young children who are feeble and sickly, just as the clistera of those animals.</start_of_turn
Clistere magnum.	Large clistera.</start_of_turn
Cistere paruum.	Small clistera.</start_of_turn
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	The needle, that is, the upper part of which is to which the uterus is bound, is to be broad according to this manner: and there should be a distinction so that the uterus is bound like water, and the lower part which enters the belly should be blunt, that is, not open, soft, flexible, drawing towards smoothness: and on one side there shall be two holes, and on the other side one hole.</start_of_turn
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	The breadth of the opening should be according to the length of the rays, less so the greater; and there should be a space in which to place the instruments from the belly of the beast: either from parchment of the beast, which is according to the form of the asofrat of the palm.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	The hole is to be made through multiple perforations as it turns, and there should be space between every perforation equal to the width of a finger
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then insert into the holes a strong thread from raw thread, which is from ten threads, or thereabouts, and join the two ends together as with an asofrat
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When it is thus placed in the space, the string is to be passed through the head of the clips between two distinguishing constrictions of strength.
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then clip with it.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	This is the form of the circle which is here depicted, and of the holes
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of the clipping with it is: to grasp both the belly or the belly from the medicine, which is warmed according to the quantity of the sufferer's tolerance: and take care that it is not too hot or too cold, or too cold.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the patient is laid upon his back, and raises his legs upwards: and place under it the leather, that is, the skin of men, or linen.
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then apply the extremity of the clip with fat, or with alum, or with mucilage of barley, or like these.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then insert it into the hole with ease.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then take hold of the belly with both hands and press it out with the thumbs until it has evacuated all that is in the clip into the intestine
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then extract the Clistere, and elevate the patient's limbs towards the side.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	If the physician thinks it appropriate, then hold as much as you can
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps throughout the night, this is the greatest aid of all
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	If, however, you put the Clistere into the solution of the belly, and the exit comes to an end: then repeat the Clistere until he is healed.
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	If there are hemorrhoids or apostemata of the buttocks, then let the Clistere be slight and soft, from the Clisteres which are given to children.
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form of the gentle Clistere above that which is strict of the skin
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	Of the treatment of wounds of the head without fracture of the bone.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Head wound number 84
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have said in the discussion of the treatment of wounds that it agrees with the book, and I will say here the treatment of these with the hand and with the physicians according to the supplement.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say therefore, that wounds are varied according to the thing which causes them, and according to the place where the wound falls
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	The things which cause wounds to be multiple are like the blow of a stone: or the incision of a sword or knife: or percussion with a lance, or wood, or arrow: and the like of these things from many causes
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	Wounds which are caused by the place of the body are like a wound which falls on the head, or the neck, or the chest, or the belly, or the genitals: and the like of these from the parts of the body
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	I am reporting on the treatment of certain wounds, in order to set forth a ratiocination and rule concerning the remainder of wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	I shall begin with simple head wounds: for the memory of compound injuries often arises at the beginning of the third chapter.
Dico ergo.	I say therefore.
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When a simple wound occurs on the head, and there is no fracture of the bone: consider then, if there is any fragment of stone, or like things, and if the skin only is fractured: and the wound is great, and the pain is severe: then act promptly, and perform a cephalic bleed: do not delay this: and extract from him from the blood according to the quantity of his virtue: if there is nothing that prohibits it, especially if there is little blood issuing from the wound
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the bleed be from the opposite side of the wound
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the patient abstain from eating and drinking, and from great food.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If indeed anything hinders the decrease [of the bleeding], then let him abstain from meat and do not approach fish or eggs.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And apply over the wound if it happens to him a soft swelling, a poultice of fat infused in rose oil only, or with wine in which there is a styptic.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	If indeed you are secure from the soft swelling, then apply over the wound, if there is any remnant of blood, and it has not changed its colour, the powder which I will speak of later: and if it has changed its colour, then place over it some unguent until it is healed
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	If indeed the wound is great, or is from a wound of the sword, and similar: and the edges of it do not adhere by means of little stitches, then adhere them together themselves, according as I shall speak in the wounds of the belly concerning the stitching of them
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If, however, a bone has been detected as displaced and hangs loose, and its retention is not possible, except in a small suspension: then cut it off.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Care for the bone with the physicians, and restore it to its place in the skin, and command the patient to eat foods which are rough in texture, such as heads and cooked wheat, until the pulse is restored: and similar things.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	If you find putrefaction in the flesh, and it does not adhere to the bone: then cut off the putrefied part entirely, and throw it away: then care for the wound
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	If, however, in his wound there is an artery, or a vein from which blood flows: and it is not severed by the physicians, then inquire about the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If indeed you find it not severed, then cut it off with sponges or ligate it.</start_of_turn>
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If necessity compels you when it does not agree with what we have said, then cauterize it until the bleeding is stopped.</start_of_turn>
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If, however, these wounds are small and simple: then the matter is easy and light: thus as to sprinkle upon them this powder: because it consolidates them before they change them by air.</start_of_turn
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Method of applying the powdered ochre.</start_of_turn>
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Mix part one of olive oil, two parts dragon's blood, and three parts unburnt lime together: mix them all thoroughly, and make a paste: apply this to the wound, and bind it tightly, until it adheres well to it and clots with the blood.</start_of_turn
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then string it up with wool, and leave it, do not wash it until it has dried, so that it does not become softened.</start_of_turn
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine.
Caput LXXXV.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Until it is healed, it is not eradicated by medicine
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	If the wound be deep, or if it happen to break into that sinus in the lower part of it, where pus is gathered, then perforate it in a depressed place in that.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If an artery be cut in the wound, and there follow a flow of blood: then separate it, or dry it up, and ligate it: or cauterize it if need be for that.</start_of_turn>
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	If indeed a piece of cartilage or the whole guttur is fractured, and the fragments are close together: then unite the edges of the skin with a suture over the neck of the guttur, and do not touch the guttur, rather equalize it, and reduce it to its natural figure.</start_of_turn>
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then bind it tightly with a bandage, and discharge it in a few days.</start_of_turn>
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with poultices which have styptic and drying qualities, until it is healed.</start_of_turn>
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	If indeed the wound has made an imprint in the bone, then inquire about it: then if there are fragments of bone in that, extract them all, or whatever can be extracted from it: and what cannot be prepared, discharge it, until the wound is healed, and the swelling is separated and diminished.</start_of_turn
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	If indeed the wound is fresh, then powder over it the powder which I have mentioned.</start_of_turn
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	If indeed bone is seen in the wound, and a fistula is formed: then care for it as is mentioned in its chapter.</start_of_turn
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	(The text continues with instructions for treating wounds in specific areas of the body.)</start_of_turn>
Caput LXXXVI.	(End of the text.)</start_of_turn>
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If there is a percussion of a lance or a knife, and the wound is deep, then consider it.</start_of_turn
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	If any moisture issues out of a wound when the patient breathes, then you know that the wound is mortal.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If it does not reach deep, and it is merely accompanied by blood: then you do not put in it from the first hour any powder, neither do you tie it up, lest the blood remain in its depth and be lost. Return to the heart, and let the patient die: but put in it some absorbent dressing, and draw out the blood in two days.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	If indeed the dressing is not present there, then put in the opening of the wound some coarse wool, so that it may absorb that which issues out of it from the moisture: and cause the patient to sleep over the wound, so that it may heal what collects in it.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	If indeed more than three days or more have passed since the wound occurred, and the patient has neither spasm nor bad tremor of the heart nor bad constriction of the breathing, and all other symptoms have ceased: then you know that the wound is healed.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Treat it therefore with care and with medicines, and with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	If indeed the healing is excused, and it always opens up: then you know that a fistula has been made
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	Treat the wound from its head to its foot.
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from a cut of a knife, or from a nail, and is simple on the surface of the chest or back: then treat it as if it were sutured, if it is large: or with powder if it is small
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if indeed it has made an imprint in the bone, and has burst from it: then inquire about the wound, and properly remove the bone fragments that are separated.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	If they are not separated, then emit them, until the bone becomes rotten, and the enemy will be appeased by the extraction of them.
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	The remaining wounds of the accident are judged in the care of the rest of the limb, which is their judgment
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Of the wounds of the belly, and the exit of the intestine, and the evacuation of the bowels.
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter 87.</start_of_turn>
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	The disruption which happens in the belly is great, medium, or small.</start_of_turn>
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	From the great (injury) sometimes the intestine comes out, or several intestines.</start_of_turn
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Therefore the introduction (of the intestines) is difficult, and the suture is more difficult and arduous.</start_of_turn
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And the small disruption is also difficult in another way.</start_of_turn
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	Therefore it follows, that the reduction (of the intestines) is more difficult, if you do not take proper care in the introduction of them to their place immediately: because it swells, opens, and thickens: and therefore it is difficult for them to enter.</start_of_turn
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Therefore the medium disruption is better: because with it the reduction of the intestine is not difficult, as it is with the other two sorts.</start_of_turn
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	You know that the suture of the belly is done in four ways.</start_of_turn
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two sutures are common in the suture of the belly, and in the suture of the rest of the body: and two other sutures communicate properly with the rest of the wounds.</start_of_turn
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	But indeed there are other methods which are proper with the suture of the belly: and I will narrate one and the other with exposure and declaration.</start_of_turn
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	Therefore I say, when a wound is small and something protrudes from it from the intestine, and it is difficult to reduce it: then that is because of one of two modes.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Either because of the smallness of the rupture, as we have said: or because of an inflation in the intestine caused by the cold of the air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When it is thus, then it is necessary to heat it, so as to immerse a sponge or a wet bandage in lukewarm water alone
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or boil in water a little barley, some thyme, and pepper, and embrace with these the intestine, until the inflation is resolved.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	When it makes a sticky liquid: it is better than plain water in resolving the inflation.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When the inflation has thus been resolved, then moisten the intestine with the lukewarm liquid in which it has been boiled, or with roughened linen
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For thus it will soothe its entrance with something small.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	But if it is expelled after this treatment, then find in the small rupture with the instrument with which hemorrhoids are cut.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	The first treatment is better when prepared beforehand than by cutting: and it does not compel to cut after necessity and defect of the instrument
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part be acute and the other not acute, and the extremity soft not with the smoothness of asphalt, but rather somewhat obtuse: and that is like a wound, as is the liquid
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	When thus the wound is increased and the intestine enters, then it is necessary to reduce it according to its natural form in its own place, if possible over that: because that is better
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When the disruption is wide in the lower part of the belly: then it is necessary that you make the patient lie on his back, and elevate his legs above his head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if it is in the upper part of the belly: then place his head low, and raise his chest above that which is below his waist
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And in the same way if the disruption is in two parts of the belly: then place your attention and your care always in this, that the part which has the wound should be above the other part.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	It is necessary in large wounds and in medium wounds to take this into consideration.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	In small wounds, place this according to what is prepared for you.
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make sure that there is present between your hands the minister who holds the entire disruption with his hand: and close his lips.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then take out from it those who follow the suture one after the other: and this is the common method of stitching one
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is necessary to take an awl, or the number of awls according to the quantity of the wound's amplitude.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then take away from the edge of the disruption the quantity of an index finger, that is, the physician: and fix the awl one beyond which you put the thread into the skin at two extremities, with two extremities of the fat which is under the skin from the inside, until you have made the skin penetrate from another part, and you have gathered together two extremities of the skin, and two extremities of the fat: and there are four orders
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then suture with a double thread around the circumference of the awl several times until two lips of the wound are aggregated with a decent aggregation.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Release the breadth of the finger also, and fix in place an obtuse angle at another point: afterwards draw back the suture with the thread as you did with the first needle.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	Do not cease to make it until you have completed the constriction of the whole wound
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And let there be medium-sized needles between the breadth and the thickness: because the fine needles easily slip through flesh: and the large ones are difficult to pass through the skin: for this reason it is necessary that there be medium-sized ones in the thickness, and the breadth.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	It is not permitted to pierce the skin at two adjacent extremities: so that the flesh is not easily pierced, and the wound does not open before its consolidation, and does not lengthen even with the suture, so that the wound is not obstructed from its consolidation
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then pierce the extremity of the needle, so that it does not wound the patient during his sleep: and place on the skin small cushions from the wool from all sides, which hold the extremities of the needles: and release them when you know that the wound has consolidated
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this is the kind of suture which is more suitable for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For these wounds one, or two, or a few needles are sufficient for the suture.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	The second kind of suture is common, so that the extremities are four: two of the skin and two of fat in one wound, with a needle in which the thread is even in thickness and breadth
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have pierced with the needle the four extremities, reduce the needle from the part from which you began so that the thread which has been drawn back falls from the upper part of the wound: so that the suture is like the stitching of cloth, and put between every stitch as much of the thickness of the smaller finger
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	Men know this suture.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	When such a suture has been made, men know that a wound has occurred in the belly which was caused by a knife, and that the wound was of great size, for it had burst open for two palms from the middle of the intestine, and there was a rupture in the middle of the belly.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	And so he reduced it after he had put the intestine outside the wound at the end of twenty-four hours.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	And it was consolidated in a space which lasted for about fifteen days: and I cared for it, and it healed: and he went on living for many years afterwards, living in his accustomed manner.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the physicians judged that it would not heal.</start_of_turn>
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	And indeed, it was a miracle that it healed without ointment.</start_of_turn>
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	For I was in a place where unguentum could not be found, and no one among the physicians had it.</start_of_turn>
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	I put upon the wound a bandage twice a day, and I bathed it with warm water every day, until it healed.</start_of_turn
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	And there are two kinds of sutures which I shall relate according to the narration of the sermon.</start_of_turn
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And thus you begin with a sharp suture: and you penetrate from the outside inwards towards the interior.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When you have thus pierced the skin, and in the lacertum of the skin, according to the length and breadth of the entire body: withdraw the point of the needle in the side where you inserted the needle, and make penetrate from the inside outwards in the opposite side at the other end.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When you have thus made the penetration, then make the penetration once more in this way in the same side from the outside inwards: and withdraw the point of the needle which is in this side, and make penetrate the needle from the inside outwards in the opposite side at the other end: and make penetrate with your penetration as you make the penetration in the point of the needle which is in the outside, until you have pierced the whole thing.</start_of_turn
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then commence also from this side likewise, and draw out the same with the extremity which is from the heel on the other side, and extract the point from the skin as it has penetrated.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then reduce the skin to this side also, and draw out the heel which is on the other side with this extremity: and extract the point from the skin as it has penetrated, and make this part whole once more, and the other: make this part whole after the other, until the entire limb is according to this example
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the sum of all these sutures is like that of the sutures of the skin: thus that you draw out one part from one extremity of the skin, and draw out the other part from the other extremity, until you have completed it.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second kind of proper suture which Gale has mentioned.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This is the explanation which Gale has said concerning the way in which some physicians join together every part in order to make it equal in proportion, and apply one extremity of the heel to the other heel, and the other extremity to the other heel.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And this is done according to what I have said.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	It is necessary to bring the point of the awl close to the inner part of the heel from the outer side, and make the point penetrate inwards only in this place: and draw out the two heels.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then draw out the point again, and make the point penetrate from the outer side to the inner side of the two heels, namely on both sides
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	And draw out both of them again, and make them penetrate from the inside to the outside in the two other heels which are on the opposite side
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this method of stitching is the best of all common sutures, and is the suture whose progress is remembered.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is indeed the word of Galen.
Et dixerunt quidam.	Some have said this also
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The gut suture is corrected with two cubes.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	That is, introduce into the belly two threads: and begin with the needle which is beside you, and make it pass through until it reaches the other side, following the suture which is between the layers of skin.
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And know that when the rupture is in the middle of the gut: then the suture of that is more difficult than the rest of the gut
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	The judgment of the ulcer of the wound is the judgment of the rest of the wounds
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	That is, because when you follow the wound along with its blood, before it changes itself: and you reduce the intestine, and bring the gut back in place: then you put on the powder of incense on the wound
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	For if the air has changed the wound: then put on over it some unguents which are to you present, until they make pus: and the thread will fall out, and the wound will be consolidated, and the pain will cease
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for this in the same way as for the care of the rest of the wounds, until it heals
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	But if there are no medicinal preparations with you: then put on over it immediately, from which it begins to emit pus, soft wool: and change it twice a day, as I have told you, until it heals
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not administer other medicine in various ways, when the wounds are simple.
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	If however you fear that the wound communicates with the major limbs in the lesion: then you must immerse wool lint in lukewarm water, or in rose-water: and put it around the parts which are between the groin and the armpits
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If he feels pain, or swelling, or putrefaction in his intestines (for this often happens to him), then let him drink a cluster of vinegar, black, warm: especially if the putrefaction has already penetrated into the intestine, and an opening has been made through to its cavity.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that that which is ex the great intestine is easier to heal: and that which is ex the small intestine is more difficult to heal.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	The large intestine, however, which is called Ieiunum, does not suffer healing from a wound that has happened in it throughout: and this is because of the multitude of its veins, and the greatness of them, and because of the subtlety of its body, and for its nearness to its own nature of nerves
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	If, however, that which proceeds from the wound is a hernia, and you must reduce it: reduce it according to your reduction of the intestines equally.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If, however, it has passed beyond that space, and has become black, or dark: then it is necessary that you bind it up with a thread above the place which has become denigrated from it, so that the blood flow does not issue from it.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in the hernia are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut that which is beyond that ligament, and put two hanging threads from the lower part of the wound outside of it: so as to alleviate the attraction of it, and the extraction of it from the case of the hernia, and the emission of pus from the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remember the wound that happened in the Intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When a disruption happens in the Intestine, and it is small: then it is possible, in some men, that it may be restored: because I saw that which was wounded in the middle of the abdomen with the blow of a lance, and it was a wound from the right side of the abdomen, and it was old: and a fistula was made, and it went out from it egestion, and swelling
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	I undertake the care of him until I am relieved from his treatment: neither shall I cease to work subtily until he is healed, and until the place is firm and stable.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	Once I have completed the treatment, I fear over the patient lest something else happen to him which might cause him further harm: and nothing of that kind has happened to him from me
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	I remain in better moods, eating and drinking, trusting and confident, having bathed and exercised in his diet.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And some physicians have said that when there is a wound in the intestines and it is slight: then it should be bound up in this way.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And it is like taking large ants.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then join together two lips of the wound, and put an ant between the two lips of the wound which have the opening over the two lips of the wound.
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	When you have put the ant on top of that, and closed the opening, cut off its head, and bind it firmly, and do not unbind it
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	And put another ant beside the first one, and do not cease doing this until you have done as much as the whole wound
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then reduce the wound and its opening.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	These heads remain annexed in the intestines until the intestines are healed, and are healed, and do not cause harm to the patient any further.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	It is also possible to bind up the intestines even with a fine thread: which has been taken from the intestines of an animal, and is annexed to this when it is introduced into the belly
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And take the extremity of this thread from the intestine, and remove much of it.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then the ligature in its extremity is taken up by a fine thread.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then insert the thread into the knot, and pass it with it through the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then draw it down to the disruption (of the tissue).
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And in this manner of suturing with hooks and intestine, there is no less need than with confidence and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	You know that which is great, wide, especially if it is in a slender intestine: then there is no skill except subtility, and no healing is to be found at all
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	Concerning the care of ulcers and fistula.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Chapter 88.</start_of_turn>
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	You know that every wound, or swelling when it grows old and decays, and becomes an ulcer, and does not consolidate, and always emits pus, and does not heal: then it is called universally in any part of the body a fistula, and we call it Zuchemen.</start_of_turn>
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a fistula is indeed according to truth a filtered knot, hard, white: with which there is no pain, which has the shape of a bird's wing: and because of this some call it Risati, that is, a wing.</start_of_turn
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And sometimes in some hours it is moist, which emits pus.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And sometimes the moisture may split in some hours.</start_of_turn
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And when this moisture is much, and is little: and is great, and is soft.</start_of_turn
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And as I have already said in the discourse, then when I said that every ulcer which does not heal, neither is born in that flesh, is not because of one single cause.</start_of_turn
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	When one is suffering from a lack of blood in the body: or from the malice of its nature: or because between the inner and outer lips there is a hard substance which hinders the natural growth of flesh: or because there are many ulcers and pus: or because an ulcer in itself is putrid and the matter which comes out of it is of bad quality: or because the medicine is inappropriate for its treatment: or because corruption is falling in the region, which is a kind of pestilence: or because of some characteristic of the region, as for example in Caesaraugusta, where digestion is difficult for patients and recovery from illness is delayed by nature: or because there is only one bone, or many bones.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	I have mentioned all these causes and signs and their treatments with the physicians in discussion. It is necessary for you to write here the treatment for fistula and stone, which is done by one operation with the hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	You know therefore that fistula can occur in all parts of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	There are various kinds of fistula which proceed from one great vessel or artery, or nerve, or sac: or intestine, or bladder, or some bone: or from some joint or composition of bones: such as the hand and foot. And there are those which arise from the proximity of a principal limb and of like things
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Thus, the fistula of this kind is caused by difficult and incurable ailments, and is associated with laboriousness and ignorance
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	If, however, the depth of any fistula does not reach these places which I have mentioned, and if you hope and trust in its treatment, and wish to achieve knowledge of it, then attempt to draw out the matter by air or by instrument, if the fistula follows a straight course. Inquire about it with the physician concerning the matter itself
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	If, however, there is a twist in the Fistula, then investigate it with a fine lead weight.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	For the lead weight, on account of its gentle weight, will adhere to the curve of the twist.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	If the Fistula has multiple orifices, it is not possible to do this with a fine weight alone
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	So draw out the gut from each orifice of the orifices of it.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For the humidity which you draw out causes the gut to slip from other orifices, and runs out from them.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then inquire carefully in what way it is possible: whether it is bone or nerve, and that the Fistula is long or short: or that the Fistula is one having multiple orifices, and is stretched over all of it, with the sum of your force: with your inquiry of the patient and the discovery of pain on compression with your hand over the place, and similar signs and symptoms following.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When you have stood at all these positions truly, then proceed to treatment with confidence: that is to say, you must consider whether the Fistula is near and apparent, or far from the junction, or from a nerve, or artery, or vein, or any place which I have mentioned: then dry the Fistula according to what has been said above from the narration, and take out what is in it from the filtration, and corrupted meat, which is born from the orifice in the meat, or pus, and similar things: and care for her until she is healed.
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	If, however, the Fistula is of great depth, and is according to the rule: then it is necessary to open her up as deeply as possible
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	And then remove from her all her corrupted meat
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then administer the round pills in acute medicines: and introduce them until you have encompassed the fistulous cavity with iron: do this with the former as often as necessary, until the acute medicine has eaten away the whole of what remains in the fistulous cavity from corruption.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore it with the unguents which generate healthy flesh, until it is healed.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If indeed it does not heal by this, then cauterize it according to what we have said before
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If indeed the cause of the fistula is bone, and you suspect that to be the case: then inquire about it, and dry it up according to what I have told you: if it does not prevent you from anything from the limb or from the bone or from any main nerve, as we have said
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If indeed it is detected that the bone is there, and there is some corruption and blackness: then burn it out until the corruption of it is entirely gone.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with that which nourishes it, until it is healed.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	When if it does not heal, and pus comes out as before: then you know that you have not brought about the entire eradication of the corruption
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Reveal it further according to this, and bring about an explanation of it, and an explanation of the surrounding area with your greatest diligence
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If indeed it heals, that is good: and if not, you know that that corruption is in a profound depth of the body, which you have not been able to overcome
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	It is not in this way that you will overcome it, except by leaving it to the natural course of things
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	If indeed the small bone is corrupted, and it is possible for you: draw it out with fine forceps which fit to it
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If there are many bones, then make an exquisite attraction of them all, and do not send anything forth from your hand with your fortitude.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If indeed there is moisture in something and there is no fear of incision, or of error: then incise those moist parts and flesh, if there are any, and liberate the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If indeed the bones are not prepared for extraction from your hand, then place upon it what will cause it to putrefy: and send it away, until it has putrefied what is around the bones from the flesh and moisture
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And keep an ointment on it so that it does not harden.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And let the incision be as small as you made it in your operation
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	And put upon it, if necessary, a bandage soaked in sulfur dust with oil: or a bandage soaked in Egyptian unguent, or any other unguents of your desire.
