Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when they putrefy, these indeed are the moist parts, and they are separated from the bones, the bleeding will be alleviated from the extraction of them, and their attraction will be perfect
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	If indeed there is a large bone, such as a thigh bone or a hip bone, and the like of them, and what is corrupted from it is great: then take away that part with the utmost reason, until that black spot and corruption is gone
Deinde restaura uulnus.	And then restore the wound.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	If indeed what is corrupted is great, and the corruption has reached the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to cut through it entirely, and to open it up to the depth where the corruption is: then care for it until it has healed
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I tell you, what happened to me in my own leg: that you may take it as an example and an assistant for your operation.
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	A youth of about thirty years of age suffered pain in his leg, because something had moved above its middle within the body, that is, from within, until it reached the thigh, and there was swelling: and there was no external cause for it.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	The swelling lasted for some time with the error of the physicians, until the abscess opened, and many materials came out with it.</start_of_turn>
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And after that, the healing took place, until the thigh was bound up, and many holes were made in it: which all emitted pus and moistened the body.</start_of_turn>
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	The physicians treated him for two years altogether, and there was no knowledge of the art of the hand in it, until I was called, and I saw his leg and the materials which were running out of those holes: even all the men who saw him fainted, and his color grew pale.</start_of_turn>
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	There was an attempt to reach one of the holes with their hands, and the attempt reached the bone.</start_of_turn>
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I examined all the holes: and I found that they all communicated with each other throughout the thigh.</start_of_turn
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	I treated him accordingly, and I closed one of the holes, until I reached a piece of bone: and I found it corrupted: for it was broken, defaced, putrified, and perforated, until it had penetrated as far as the marrow.</start_of_turn
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	I saw what was detected to me, and prepared it from the broken bone.</start_of_turn
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I judged that there was no soundness in the bone except for that corruption, which I cut away and closed.</start_of_turn>
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I extirpated it.</start_of_turn>
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I establish the restoration of the wound along with the consolidated physicians in a spacious place.
Et non est consolidatum.	It is not consolidated yet.</start_of_turn>
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I tried again, and I found upon the second examination above the first: there was a continuous corruption with the bone: and I saw that there was also corruption from that very corruption.</start_of_turn
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I attempted to restore it.</start_of_turn>
Et non est restauratum.	It is not restored yet.</start_of_turn
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	I found it therefore above again, and I did not cease to cut the bone piecemeal, and to attempt to restore it: and it is not restored, until I cut from the bone around the space of one palm, and I extracted that with the marrow.</start_of_turn
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with the physicians, and it was consolidated quickly, and healed: and no further operation was necessary for this purpose, except for the disposition of the weakness of the patient, and his little tolerance, and my fear of death for him, because he was suffering from all these things from excessive evacuation of the bad humors.</start_of_turn
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was healed completely: and was born in the place of the hard bone, and a good disposition was made in his body, and his spirit returned to him: and he recovered in his own dispositions: and he did not suffer from any obstacle in walking or sleeping ever after.</start_of_turn
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.	But if the prominent bone in the body is fractured: then it is necessary to support it thus: take a ligament and bind the extremity of the prominent bone: and command someone to extend it upwards: and put another ligament from a thicker thread than the first.</start_of_turn
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then bind the ligament over the flesh which is upon the bone: and extend the extremity of it, so that you draw the flesh downwards: and you will see the flesh above the place where you wish to cut, so that it does not damage the flesh.</start_of_turn
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place wood or a board under the lower bone in the center: since when you do this, it does not hinder that it will cut corrupted flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	The incision should be made close to the corrupted area, so as not to cause damage to the bone, and must not protrude excessively so as to cause pain or discomfort to the patient.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the bone is corrupted and does not protrude, the surrounding parts must be preserved with the part that is corrupted: and the corruption is in the middle or in that part: then remove the flesh from all sides of the entire bone
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place a lower wood.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Afterwards make the incision from the first part where the corruption is, until the incision reaches the other side: and let the incision be of equal length to the corruption, as we have said before
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If the corruption is at the junction, make an incision through the corrupted junction and cut the bone where the corruption continues on the other side
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If indeed the corruption is in the continuation of two junctions, then it is not in that area except by abrasion.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If the corruption is in the palm of the hand, or in the sole of the foot: then the matter is difficult and dangerous
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	It is true that you must inquire about the nature of the corruption.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And abrade carefully the surrounding area as much as you are able, and remove the corrupted part according to any method that seems good to you: when it does not cause damage to the vein or nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	You must know that for the cutting of bones, and the making of incisions, there are many instruments, according to the position of the bones, and their preparation, and their length, and their breadth, and their thickness, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Wherever it is necessary, prepare an instrument suitable for each kind of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	Know that these operations are great and significant concerning the kind of instrument which is suitable for them, for they demand long experience in their study
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And you will recognize the modes of this art by the evidence of the modes of the diseases: for then you will find that it agrees with them from the instruments in respect of all illnesses
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	I am firm in the last chapter of this book concerning the number of instruments which I have set out as examples of those which you will encounter, and the test which you will make on others.
Forma Serrae.	The Shape of the Knife.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The Shape of the other Knife
Forma Serrae alterius.	The Shape of the other Knife again
Forma Serrae alterius.	The Shape of the Knife once more
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This shape of the Knife is made with the blade slightly off-center
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its arch be above, its point from the steel: and its handle from the box, and let it be pyramid-shaped and off-center
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The Shape of the Scissors for Sutures
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this Scissors be in the shape of the head of the stellate key: and its points according to the shape of the holes of the needle-holder
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it does not suit except when it is rough against that head of the sutures, when it is broken or when the bone is broad and large
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The Shape of the larger Scissors
Forma medii Rasorii.	The Shape of the medium Scissors
Forma Rasorii lati.	The Shape of the broad Scissors
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The Shape of the Scissors which have a concavity
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	The form of the rash is different from the others.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	The form of the rash is different from the others in that it is more widespread on the extremities
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The rash is small and faint in colour.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The rash accompanies bone fractures.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The rash is also large in size
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This resembles a wound made by a knife, and the extremities are like mountains: it appears in many places because of the fracture of the bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The form of the rash agrees with the cause of the wound in the bones
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	The extremities are triangular in shape, and the edges of the extremities are acute
Fit ex Indi.	Like that of India
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	It is like that which we said of rashes, incisions and mountains
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	Concerning the incision of the extremities and the suture of the bones
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter 89
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities are putrefied, either by an external cause or an internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore you have treated the disease with medicines, and the cure has not been effected: if you do not cut away the corruption of the limb which has not been remedied by the medicines, the patient will either die from the disease or from the defect of the limb itself
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign of this is that the limb becomes black, either because it is burnt by fire or putrefies after it has been blackened: until the putrefaction of the limb has advanced to such an extent that it extends throughout the whole body
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	So then you must make an incision in this case, and in the same way if the cause of the corruption is a wound from some venomous creature: such as a scorpion of the sea, a spider, a flea, and things of that sort
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If there is any corruption, or percussion [of the bone] is at the extremity of the finger, then cut off the finger, and do not leave the space of the corruption, but cut on until the whole hand is done.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	If the same happens in the hand, then cut off the hand from the root of the bone, and do not leave the space of the corruption, but cut until the forearm is complete.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	If it happens in the forearm, then cut off the forearm at the elbow joint
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If, however, the corruption has passed beyond the elbow, and you go round the elbow: then that is the death of the patient.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And to administer besides this from care, is the quantity of blood.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do with the foot, when the corruption comes to the finger, then cut off the finger at one of the joints: and if it comes to the heel of the foot, then cut off the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If it comes up to the knee, then cut off the leg at the knee joint
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If the corruption has gone above the knee, then there is no recovery in this, except dismissal, and leaving the patient to die.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the way to cut off a limb, or to preserve it, is to string the ligaments below, which you wish to cut: and string another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And extend one minister ligament downwards: and extend another minister ligament upwards
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between two ligaments, with a saw having a broad blade, until the whole flesh is gone.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then cut or preserve
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you take away from all parts of the limb a strip of skin, and do not touch the healthy place: and you must add injury to the patient, and make the swelling cold.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If blood flow inside should increase while working, then cauterize the place immediately: or put above it some powder which will absorb the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Return then to your medicine until completion is reached.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a bandage suitable for it, and care for it until it heals
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I say that this happened to me in my foot, thus also happens to me.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because it happened in my foot at night, with a burning which assimilates with the fire: and the corruption of that happened first in my finger, until the whole foot was affected
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	He therefore withdrew from himself, after he had cut away the corruption of the limb with an excision of its gangrene, which he found from pain and burning: and it healed at the junction of the bones
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption happened to him in the thumb of his hand again
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He came to me, and I attempted to restore his limb with the things which I placed on his hand by the physicians after the purification of his body: and the superfluity did not disappear, but it began to spread to another finger: until the corruption spread to his hand itself
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me to cut off his hand: and I did not do it, hoping for the return of the superfluous limb: and I also feared for his life at the incision of his hand itself.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For the man's courage was great in this case.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	When he had despaired of me, he went away from home: and he returned to me again from that place because he had become better, and he cut off his whole hand: and it healed
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	Neither listen to this narration, except that it be an aid concerning that which falls from the kind of this disease: and that it be meaningful as it is signified, and according to how it is done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Neither heed this tale except that it be of service concerning the care of bones and the quality of blistering with the physicians.
Caput XC.	Chapter 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When swelling happens in some limb by carnation, and the space of the swelling is prolonged until collection of pus has taken place: then it is burst or pierced, and what is in it is expelled, and the place is left empty as though it were a cavity: and the skin which is over it is like a membrane which has been stretched out: and it does not reach its ultimate corruption, neither does it reach the bone, nor the nerve, nor the ligament: it is called a sinus, and not a fistula, indeed if its space is prolonged until corruption affects some parts of the limb, then it is called a fistula, or swelling
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And its care is that you cut through the whole skin as it is wrinkled: and especially when it has been stretched out like a membrane: and trust that it does not adhere to the place, because of its corruption
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will adhere and that no corruption will result from this: and if there is hardness in the skin from the flesh, then care for it with blistering: and consider it as a sinus
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus which comes out of it has a foul odor: then blistering is to be done with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, oil, and saffron, equal parts, gathered in a cavity: and they are boiled over fire until the medicine boils: and it is added to honey
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take out from it what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and blister with it the sinus: and close its opening, and give the medicine for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with expression: do that every day until the sinus is healed and the stench is gone.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	When it has been plastered with burnt lime, when it is not present, take burnt lime of wood or of ilex, and sprinkle it on water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then extract it, and plaster it with this, until you are confident that the sinus has been removed
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient does not tolerate the Egyptian medicine, nor burnt lime and water, then plaster it with water and honey, to which something of ground cinnamon has been added
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or plaster it with honey and wine mixed together, because honey has the property of healing and drying: and the wine makes the sinus adhere, especially when there is excess of astringency and dryness in it.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this a few times, and you are confident that the corruption of the sinus has passed away: then plaster it with something that makes flesh grow in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is good to take from the plaster diaphnesicon: and dissolve it with rose water and wine: or plaster it with some medicine, and anoint with others, of whose properties are written in the treatise on unguents
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the opening of the sinus is narrow, in which a canula of the plaster will not pass: then widen it with tin or put in the cavity a piece of lint soaked in Egyptian unguent, or in castor oil, until it is widened
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And in like manner if it is also a wide opening, then gather its lips together with stitches: and withdraw from it as much as is contained in the plaster without adding anything.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	If, therefore, the opening from which the pus runs out is elevated towards above: then dry it in the hollow place which is in itself, so that the pus may run out from that as far as below; for when the pus is collected in depth, it hinders the generation of flesh in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible to dry the sinus somewhat below its lower part as desired: then try to prepare the limb with the preparation which will cause the pus to flow out more easily as desired
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try not to retain anything of the pus at all in it: and take solidifying medicines which are placed over the sign, suitable for this purpose
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And extend them over the membrane of the skin.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And let the membrane be of such a quantity as to make communication of the whole sinus possible.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then pierce with forceps directly at the opening of the sinus, making the opening of the sinus larger.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then stretch out from fine threads over another membrane, according to the quantity of the hole: and place it upon that in a long position away from the opening of the sinus, so that it may alleviate the escape of pus from that: and do not make the membrane too large, except after a few days or so once a day.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is above the opening of the sinus should move in every hour, so that what is aggregated in it from the pus may go out: and you will know whether it is going out much or little, or digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And with this consider again the place of the sinus itself, whether it feels pain in itself, or whether there is no pain in it, or whether there is swelling in it, or whether there is no swelling in it
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When you have thus completed your treatment in this way, and you have seen what comes out from the opening of the sinus: then you will know whether the sinus is still adhering, or has approached adherence: then you must remove it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you remove it, then renew the dressing.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If, however, it escapes from the Sinus beyond a long space, do not despair of its adherence, for its healing approaches, because from men are those who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and from beasts are those who act contrariwise to that.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If, however, it escapes from the Sinus after many days with undigested pus, then you know that the Sinus does not adhere
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If, therefore, the adherence of the Sinus is delayed and its condition is prolonged: then add in the treatment the physicians, who are indeed physicians, who make the substances both moist and dry: like unguentum dyafinicon, when added to it the excess of addition from the zega.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from the last thing which is to be cured, that is, to take unguentum dyafinicon and dissolve it with rose water, and apply it over the old liquid equal in amount to the substance itself
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then mix it with this and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And it does the same thing to this, when there is no unguentum dyafinicon present, honey, when you boil it down, until it thickens, and you use that with it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh, and aloes, and olibanum: mix them all together, and grind that up over honey while it is over the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then apply on the surface of the wound, and bind it over the Sinus: and apply with the honey which you boiled down, until it has thickened: and grind over it the species, and put on the wound, and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when administered in that aristolochia longa, and roots of lilium coelestis, and is lily: and barley herb, and centaurea.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use simple or compound instruments, and these alone; and the chisel itself: and powder on wax as I have said, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the matter of the sinus persists and does not heal with this treatment: then you know that there is corruption in its depth: either that it makes an impression in the bones, or in the other hard parts, or in the ligaments: then treat it as fistula, as has been said before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	As for the treatment of panaritis and nail drawn out, and incision of the finger added, and section.
Caput XCI.	Chapter XC.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritis is a swelling that arises under the nail of the thumb or finger of the hand, or foot: and sometimes it arises in the rest of the fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When it persists, and is neglected, and the swelling grows, the nail becomes soft: or it is broken and pus comes out of it until it destroys the root of the nail: and sometimes it breaks the whole thing, and sometimes the corruption reaches the bone, and there is a foul odor: and the limb becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you have treated it as we have said above, and the cure does not take hold: then it is necessary to cut away the whole superabundance that remains from the nail with a knife
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the nail afterwards.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	The cautery is to be used cautiously
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If indeed the bone is sound, and the nail is also sound, and the fat of the nail is still adhering to the meat inside, and it is beginning to irritate itself: then it is necessary to place a piece of radium beneath the nail at an angle so that it presses down on the meat; and cut through the meat easily, and place over that which remains of the meat which has been burned by the doctors, corrosive and astringent, until it has vanished
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If, however, corruption has set in the bone, then it is necessary to cut away the bone and extract it: for it will not heal as long as the corrupt part remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see the decay and corruption advancing in the finger, then cut it at one of the joints, as has been mentioned previously concerning its reminder
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it is healed.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, there should be attrition or concussion of the nail, or if there is pain in it: then it is necessary to bleed the diseased part at the outset.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp spatula from above downwards to the tip
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And take care, lest the cutting should penetrate the flesh under the nail, for thereby you will cause additional pain and swelling to the diseased part
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with it which rests pain.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	A finger which has been added which was born in the hands of men, perhaps is altogether fleshy: perhaps there is some bone in it, perhaps there is the nail in it: and sometimes some of them are born from the root of the joint, or the nature of it is in some node of the finger
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	He who is born in some node of the finger does not move: and he who is born near the joint of the finger, perhaps moves
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	He who is born of bone is easily cut
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, as you would cut the nail with a broad spatula from the root downwards
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	As for him whose nature is in the root of the joint, the cure is difficult
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Abstain therefore from incision of it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	Abstain therefore from incision of it.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
¶ De incisione Vitium.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Caput XCII.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Abstain therefore from incision of it
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then draw the ligature around the limb from the upper part of the thigh down to the lower part of the knee with the gutta.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then make a knot at one, two, or three wide places.</start_of_turn>
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then elevate, that is, draw out the blood from the lower part of the leg up to the top, and from the top downwards as a phlebotomy for the patient at first.</start_of_turn
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then draw out the limb until blood has drained out as much as the patient's condition tolerates.</start_of_turn
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind the limb: and command him to abstain from foods that generate black bile: and repeat the evacuation and the phlebotomy, when the veins are full, and this will be beneficial for the patient.</start_of_turn
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	The elevation of the limb is to be done in this manner.</start_of_turn>
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	If there are many hairs on the limb, shave them off.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then immerse the limb in a bath: or bind it in the limb with warm water, until the veins become red, and swell: or perform an exercise of strength, if there is no bath available, until the limb is warmed.</start_of_turn
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin along the line of the vein: or at the end of the limb near the knee, or at the lower part of the limb near the heel.</start_of_turn
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with needles, and scrape the vein from all sides, until sensation returns: and it is at the return of sensation that the blood in the limb turns red from black.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it comes out of the skin, the blood is like a white cord.</start_of_turn
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce the instrument under the edge of the radium, until it rises and emerges from the skin: suspend it with a single hook, firm.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then perform another incision nearby, about the width of three fingers wide.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then remove the skin from the upper part of the bone until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then raise the instrument with the radium as you did before, and suspend it with another hook, as you did before
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then perform another incision, or several incisions, if necessary
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then raise it up, and cut the last incision at the heel
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then extract the instrument from the incision above the instrument itself
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you have extracted the instrument from all the incisions, until the wound has healed: then make another incision
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If, however, it does not yield to being extracted and raised: then introduce a strong needle with a double thread, and ligate the instrument, and extract it: or introduce the instrument under the radium: and move your hand over the whole, until it comes out
Et caue, ne incidatur.	Take care not to cut through it
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut through, it is difficult to extract the instrument without causing damage to the surrounding area
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When you have finally extracted the instrument: then place over the wound a bandage soaked in wine and rose oil, or oil: and care for the wound until it has healed.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vein is contracted, having a twist which involves parts, and is not as we have described according to the rule: then you must find on the instrument over all the twist of it, and the place of the twist itself
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend the bowels with the hooks until the whole belly has been elevated: and be careful at the section above the belly that you do not cut through any blood vessels or wound them: for it is difficult to elevate or extract the bowels above.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore be prudent.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The formation of the incision where life is healed.</start_of_turn>
Forma Vncini caeci.	The formation of the incision of the blind gut.</start_of_turn
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It has no curvature like the other incisions, neither is it acute at the extremities, so as not to wound the blood vessels: and it is large in extent, gentle: for if it were slight, it would tear the blood vessels by its slightness. Indeed it is better to have a large extent than a slight one.</start_of_turn>
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of the vein of the thigh.</start_of_turn
Caput XCIII.	Chapter XCIII.</start_of_turn
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the thighs in warm countries, like Alizegi and the Arabs, and in dry, warm countries, few in number, that is, in which no herb or tree grows.</start_of_turn
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is also generated in other parts of the body besides the thighs.</start_of_turn
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is from the putrefaction that occurs under the skin, like that which occurs inside the bodies of serpents and worms ascarides, and worms generated between the skin and the flesh.</start_of_turn
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein is that which occurs in the thigh inflammation and swelling.</start_of_turn
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place is dried.</start_of_turn
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein is extracted from the place of drying, as if it were the root of a plant, or an animal.</start_of_turn
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore it appears from that extremity [of the limb], then it is necessary that you involve over the very body of the lead, whose weight is from a drachma to two drachmas and a nodus of itself: and discharge the suspended lead from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	When therefore it appears from that extremity something outwards, involve that in lead and nod it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it continues for a long time, then cut off part of it, and involve the rest
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	Do not cut through the root before the whole thing has gone out.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you cut through, it contracts and goes into the flesh: and makes the swelling swell up, and brings about bad ulcers, and putrefaction in the place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary that it be gently pulled out slowly, until it comes out whole from its end: and nothing remains of it in the body: and from this it goes out through some vessel in a man which is equal in length to five palms and ten fingers
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And so it has come to me, for it has gone out of the body for twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If however it happens to you at the hour of your treatment: then introduce radium into its cavity and perforate it with a long hole, as with the body, until everything that is in it is evacuated: and administer the putrefaction of the place with the doctors for a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for the swelling.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein when it has many branches, especially when it appears at the junction of the foot, or in the foot itself: and there are many holes in it, and it goes out through every hole branch
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Care for it as we said before, and as is prescribed
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	About the section above the worms generated under the skin, and it is called the bovine disease.
Caput XCIIII.	About the section above the worms generated under the skin, and it is called the bovine disease.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	It is called the bovine disease in our land because it frequently happens to bulls; and it is a small worm which is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it goes throughout the body, ascending and descending: and it is perceptible to the sense during its walk from limb to limb, until it bursts wherever it bursts through the skin in the place, and comes out
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the corruption of some humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	Just like worms and serpents, that is to say, lice and roundworms in the belly
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And they are feared for their malice
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	When it itself goes into the body, and ascends to the head, and persists in the place: then perhaps it bursts open there, and comes out, and destroys the eye: and this frequently happens.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	When you want to cure it, and extract it, then it does not cease until during its walk and its appearance to the sense
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	It is necessary therefore to string that which is above it and that which is under it with strong ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and extract it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it has penetrated deeply into the flesh, and you do not find it: then put a cautery over the place with fire until it dies
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And more than that, it is the corruption of it which corrupts the eye, as we said
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If, however, you see that the eye is still moving in the head near the eye, then string under it over the eyebrow a strong bandage.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry above it and extract it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the patient should be bound about with salves that dissolve harmful humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	Of the incision above the eye-brow Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Day XCVI.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This ailment is called Nakir in our land: and it is a pain which arises in some member: then it is transferred from member to member.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And indeed I have seen it myself, as I have told you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a woman who was sick in some village
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And I found her arm swollen and fluid in the vein of the arm
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw that another swelling was proceeding with worms, so that it went up to his shoulder as quickly as possible: as quickly as silver runs from one place to another.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	The pain therefore departed from that place and settled in the shoulder
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	And after an hour it went away throughout the body, until it reached the other arm
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	And she told me that it had repeated itself throughout her whole body, as I saw
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was amazed at the speed of its change from member to member
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And indeed I had never seen this ailment before like this before
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	Truly many are the people who suffer from pain that changes from limb to limb: and not the eye itself, like the eye in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	I do not believe this to be the case, except in the case of women, from whom the swelling of the lower limbs is detected: hence it appears that the sense of touch is perverted by this displacement.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	It is necessary that these things do not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and have moist bodies, with hidden swelling of the veins
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore he has received treatment for this, and the patient feels that the pain has ceased: then, if it appears in the eye, as we have said, then grasp above and below the eye quickly: and dry above the eye until the swelling has gone: and cauterize the place.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If however you do not see the eye itself: then cure it with an outward application, and with that which expels the swelling, and anoint it with saffron and similar things.</start_of_turn>
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	(The provided text does not include information regarding the extraction of arrows, so I cannot translate this portion.)</start_of_turn>
Caput XCVI.	(The provided text does not include a chapter header, so I cannot translate this portion.)</start_of_turn>
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are varied according to their kind, and according to the place from which they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their variety is great: for some have large teeth and few, and some are concave and some are convex.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And there are those which have three angles.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And those which have tongues.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And those which have stars.</start_of_turn
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	The ailments that are beside the limbs in which they fall, are according to two modes.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or else the limbs are from the principal limbs which are hollow, such as the brain, and the heart, and the liver, and the lung, and the kidneys, and the intestines, and the bladder, and the like.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls into any one of these limbs, and there appear to you signs of death, which I will tell you afterwards, then it is necessary that you extract the arrow from that limb, for death follows its course in that place in many positions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these signs of sickness do not appear, and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the limb, then extract it and care for the wound
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	From the signs then of the brain when it falls in this way, and the arrow penetrates the bone, and comes out upon the brain, is: because there arise from it soda which causes vomiting, and swelling, and dizziness, and redness of the eyes, and inflation, and redness of the tongue, and spasm, and mixture of the intellect, and vomiting of bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood comes out from the nostrils, or from the ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is broken, and the voice is destroyed
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And there comes out from the place of the wound a white moisture like pus
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And there comes out from it like the blood of meat
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore these signs appear, then abstain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it does not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of the arrow when it falls in the heart are: that it is itself close to the left breast: and it feels as though it were fixed in something hard, not in something soft.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow's movement is like that of a pulse: it runs out of the wound of black blood.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And following this comes cold at the extremity, and cold sweat, and fainting
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	You know therefore that death approaches uncertainly
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And a sign of an arrow when it wounds the lung is the exit of bloody foam from the wound: and the following swelling rises up and changes the colour of the patient.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And the great and high spirit departs: and it seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls into the chest, which is in the belly: then it is near the flanks: and there is a great sighing with pain and fear, with gasping: and all the limbs of the arms move
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	If the arrow falls into the stomach: then perhaps it comes out of the wound with some indigestible food
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	If it falls into the belly and is fixed there: something of stool or urine or intestine which has been broken comes out of the wound
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	There is no hope in its cure, neither in the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If the arrow falls into the bladder, and urine comes out: and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is strong over the patient: then you know that it is mortal
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The rest of the limbs, such as the face, and the neck, and the gut, and the upper lip, and the assistant, and the ribs, and the spine, and the shoulder, and the elbow, and the thigh, and the knee, and the heel, and those things which are like limbs are all affected according to many arrangements: when it does not find the arrow in the artery or the nerve: and there is no venomous arrow
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	I say that I have seen that these arrows are useful for your treatment.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	Because they cure the eye by causing the arrow to penetrate the tear duct of the eye and the root of the nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	I took it from the other side under the fat of his ear: and he was healed, and no wound remained in his eye
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from the Jew, which was embedded in the fat of his eye under his lower eyelid: and the arrow was already covered by the edge of the wood of the bow: it was a great arrow of the Turks, with a leaden head, in which there were no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	He was healed therefore, and no evil happened to his eye
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the belly of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	It was an Arab arrow, and that is the kind that has ears
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	And so over two ribs: and it was submerged in his belly
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	I held it there until I extracted it: and the Christian was healed
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I extracted another which had been embedded in his bowels: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After that, when thirty days had passed and no change had appeared in his condition concerning the arrow, we thought that he would recover without it: so we extracted the arrow and he was healed, and no evil happened to him
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	I saw a man whose arrow had been lodged in his back, and the wound was closed with a bandage over the wound.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After seven years, the arrow was extracted from the root of his thigh
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And indeed a woman came to me who had a sagitta lodged in her belly, and a wound had closed over it on the outside; and the sagitta remained inside: and it had not altered from its previous position, and the woman had no recollection of any natural operation having been performed on her.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And indeed another man came to me who had a sagitta lodged in his face; and a wound had closed over it, and it remained: and he found no great pain associated with it; and such things are frequent.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted a sagitta from the King's nose, which had lodged there in the middle of his face, and it had descended to the right side below: and the entire sagitta was hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	I was summoned to care for him after the incident of the sagitta for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I found the wound of the sagitta to be strict and cold to the touch
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	I asked him about any tingling sensation there, and he did not feel any; and indeed he himself found the puncture mark and the pain on the right side
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I hoped that this was the puncture made by the extremity of the sagitta
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I applied plaster to the place where the painful swelling appeared, confident that the swelling would subside, and that the sign of the sagitta would reappear on the surface: and this did not happen in the place of the accident, indicating that the sagitta had not followed its course
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I continued to apply the plaster for many days: and no accident happened, and the wound closed in the meantime: and he became conscious of the sagitta once more within his nose on a certain day
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I place therefore over that [area] a sharp knife, corrosive for many days, until it is opened: and when I grasp it with my hand, I note the tip of the arrow that is entangled in the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	And then I added to the opening of the wound the said sharp knife until we saw the tip of the arrow clearly: and I passed beyond that with it for about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	And when the wound had been enlarged, and I could insert my forceps into it, and move it, and it would not come out: then I did not cease to cauterize, and I applied over it as with the minds of engineers, until I completed over it on a certain day with forceps that I had made, as it happened in the end of the chapter, until I had extracted it
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the physicians say that the cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I restored it therefore, and the wound was consolidated and healed completely: and nothing remained of the illness
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of the extraction of some arrows: so that you may know the rule and the signification of that which I have not said
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended by the narration: neither does this book comprehend them, nor does the prudent artificer compare them with many, but rather with few; and because of that which is present, above all that which is absent: and he finds a new operation and a new instrument among the descent of all these arts when these things happen
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say therefore that arrows do not come out of the members in which they are fixed, except according to two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by extraction from the place from which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or from the opposite part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which goes out from the place from which it entered, or that is a proceeding arrow in the fleshy place: it is drawn out, and goes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not yield to the drawing out at the time when it falls: then it is necessary that you delay its drawing out for some days, until the flesh surrounding it has become rotten: and then the drawing out will be easier, and will go out more completely
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And in like manner if it is in a bone, and does not yield to you at the drawing out: then you must also delay it for some days: and draw out again every day with the drawing and the moving until it comes out completely
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not yield to you after days: then you must perforate all around the arrow in the very bone with fine silk thread, until the arrow is loosened
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	And then draw out the arrow and remove it
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the arrow is fixed in the head of the bone, and has gone through one of the sinuses of the brain, and appears from the lower part of any of those wounds which I have mentioned: then you must abstain from the drawing out of the arrow, and simply let it go, until it has become equal in size to its former state after a few days.
