Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow remains fixed, the decay does not prolong itself to it
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, except in the body of the bone only, and does not penetrate to the marrow: and remains sick for some days, and no other accident has happened to it: then think of the drawing out of the arrow and its removal
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If however it is fixed firmly, and does not yield to you at the drawing out: then apply poultice around the arrow as I have said: then take care of the place, until it is healed
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If, however, the arrow is hidden in a part of the body, and is hidden and concealed from sense: then inquire concerning it with a hook.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then grasp it with some instruments which are suitable for its attraction.</start_of_turn>
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If, however, you are unable to see above it, because of the constriction of the wound, and because of the length of the arrow in depth: and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein: then find above it until the wound be widened, and it is possible to extract the arrow.</start_of_turn>
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	Which if there be to them ears which hold fast to the flesh fixed in the bone from every part, every thought with which you can think to loose it, and to loosen, if you cannot over the evacuation of the flesh in the fracture of the ears, and the twisting of the ears, until it yields.</start_of_turn
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you when you administer the extraction of the arrow, in whatever place it is, then utilize the twisting of your hand with scissors to all parts, until you make the arrow go away: and with the last little effort, that the arrow does not break, and that it be difficult for you to grasp it, and for its extraction.</start_of_turn
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you are unable to see above it from an hour hence, then leave it for a few days, until the things which are around it have become putrid.</start_of_turn
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat it: for it will be useful to you if it does not make the flow of blood worse. Then administer what we have said in the chapter concerning the care of wounds: and guard your virtue from the incision of the vein, or nerve, or chord.</start_of_turn
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer skill in every way that you can in order to facilitate the evacuation of the arrow: and let it be with ease, and tranquility, or slowly, and firmly, as I have told you.</start_of_turn
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	It is necessary that you make the patient conform to the shape of the arrow as it is in the case of an arrow wound.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	It is necessary that you make the patient conform to the shape of the arrow as it is in the case of an arrow wound.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If it is not possible to make the patient conform to the shape of the arrow, then do what is possible from the figure.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow which comes out from the opposite side, or which proceeds from that to the outside: make a bulge at the tip of the arrow by means of the sense of the upper part of the skin near it, and remove the surrounding tissue. Dry the wound above and let the section be according to the quantity that they grasp in their forceps.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw out the arrow: it will come out easily by itself
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it remains in the bone, then turn your hand according to the roundness, until you press the arrow into the bone, and expand it: then draw it out
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave it for a few days: then try it again, until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If the arrow is embedded in wood, then drive it out with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If the wood breaks, and you wish to administer a drive: then introduce an instrument with a concave edge into the wound so that the concavity of the instrument will be in the heel of the arrow: then drive out the arrow with that
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If the arrow is concave, then drive out the arrow with an instrument entering the wound.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	The arrow will be driven out by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisonous, then it is necessary to cut away the whole flesh in which the poison is: if this is possible
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then care for it as is fitting.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If an arrow has fallen into the chest, or in the belly, or in the bladder, or on the side: and it is close to what you touch with your hand, and you can cut over it: then cut, and cauter from the incision of the belly, or the nerve, and extract the arrow.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then apply a bandage, if necessary, and care for it until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	This is the form of forceps with which arrows are extracted
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	There are two similar extremities like the beak of a bird, which are made like iron: when they grasp the arrow, they do not slip from it
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	There are many kinds of forceps, great, small, medium, according to the quantity of the magnitude of the arrow, and its thinness, and the breadth of the wound, and the constriction of it.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	Concave Impelling Form
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the Surd Impelling Form
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the shape of the extremity like a Radius, so that its entrance into the concave arrow is alleviated, and it is driven with it
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This concave extremity is concave like the beak of a bird: so that the entrance of the arrow into itself and the driving of it is alleviated
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On Phlebotomy of Veins
Caput XCVII.	Chapter 127.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	The veins that are usually phlebotomized in the body are thirty in number.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these, there are six in the head: two pulse veins, which are behind the ears, called the two Herbes: and two arteries which appear in two temporal regions: and two veins which are in the two tear-ducts of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes: and a vein prepared in the middle of the forehead: and a vein which is at the extremity of the nose
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two guides, which are in the cheek.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins which are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins which are under the tongue
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	And the veins which are phlebotomized in the arms are five in every arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of them is the Cephalica, and it is from the lateral aspect of the shoulder: and it is called the vein of the head
Et Fusca.	And the Fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And the Media is composed of the branches of the basilica and the cephalic vein: and it is called the vein of the body
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilica, which is situated in the domestic side: and it is also called the Titillicaris
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it is called the vein of the belly
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the Funis brachii, which is situated above the elbow: and it is in which phlebotomy is performed, and which appears above the thumb in the manifestation of the apposition
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the Saluatella: and it is a vein which is between the annular and the radial: and there are two branches to it
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is which is under the curvature of the thumb from the lateral side of the shoulder
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the Saphena: and its location is at the ankle from the lateral side of the foot
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the heel: its place is at the heel from the side of the heel.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg are three similar bones like those.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	About the cutting of the two bones after the Aures
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The cutting of the two bones which are after the Aures is an antidote for ancient cataracts, headache, swelling, ulcer of the head and other old ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the cutting must be according to what is said
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	It is that the head of the sick person be shaved: and the bone of his head be fractured in the place of the two bones with rough cloth friction well done
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then let the patient hold his neck with his hand, until two bones appear
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their place is after the Aures in two depressed places of the head
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Inquire therefore easily with your finger, and where you feel the pulse of them under your finger, there is the sign with the scar
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the cutting knife, which is called Incidens
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce it under the bone into the hole, until the phlebotomist reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift up your hand with the bone and the hole towards the upper part, and cut the bone with the incision of the phlebotomist
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be equal to the quantity of two joined fingers, or about that: and let blood flow out as much as you wish
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind the limb with bandages, and let go of the limb, until it is healed
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And previously in the book it was mentioned that the incision of the ears and their cauterization are among the initial procedures.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	And concerning the phlebotomy of the two arteries in the temporal region
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	As for the two arteries located in the temporal regions which are to be phlebotomized, this is done for an ancient migraine: for a sudden severe headache, and for persistent vomiting: and for a course of acute discharges reaching the eyes
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of the phlebotomy which is to be performed must be carefully considered according to what you have narrated to me
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The patient should tightly clench his neck for a long time until two veins become perceptible to the touch: and the pulse of the ears should be demonstrated under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then the sign with the cautery is given.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then elevate the skin above the vein with your index finger and make the incision of the phlebotomy beneath it, and elevate the vein above.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And make the incision as you did in the two veins above: and let the blood run out according to the quantity that you deem necessary
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loosen the patient's bandage, and place your finger over the vein for an hour
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then place on the limb and the pulse, and bind it tightly above the constriction: and let it go when it is healed
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And previously in the book it was mentioned that the recollection of the ears, their incision, and their extraction are among the initial procedures
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	And concerning the phlebotomy of the front vein after the phlebotomy of the Cephalic vein
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	The phlebotomy of the front vein after the phlebotomy of the Cephalic vein is done for ancient facial ailments: and for a migraine, and for redness: and for ulcers and wounds.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And what is the quality of his phlebotomy, according to what I have said.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The patient should steady his neck with his hand until the vein becomes visible.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then grasp the instrument which is called the Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	What is its shape like?
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Set the prominent point at the head of the Fossorium over the vein, and pierce over it with a needle, or in any other way like this: and let the blood flow out according to the quantity you wish
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then close the perforation of the patient, and tie it off, until it is healed.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And when it is opened with the phlebotomy hook
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	It is not proper that the phlebotomist should be of acute temperament, like the rest of the phlebotomists, but rather of gentle temperament
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And the phlebotomy should be performed according to the course of the blood vessels: because the bone is close by: and perhaps the phlebotomist will break when it is slight.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	About the phlebotomy of the veins in the two lacrimal bones.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	The nourishment of the two veins which are in the two lacrimal bones of the two eyes is to the eye from scabies and redness: and to the eye, and the itching and pains of the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of their phlebotomy is that the patient should steady his neck with his hand
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then the phlebotomy is easy: and you are standing over his head
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And do the phlebotomy according to the course of the blood vessels to a small length, with a small phlebotomist, wide rather than narrow, for in this place there is no bone
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the phlebotomist is unskilled at the extremity, he may break it.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let him run from the blood as much as is necessary for you
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place over the wound a cushion, and bind the wound once at night, and solve the wound.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	Regarding the phlebotomy of veins of the nose
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose are phlebotomized for acute fever, excessive sweating, facial pain such as migraines, and redness of the face, especially when it is long-standing
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of it is that it tightens the patient's neck
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take the thumb of your left hand and grasp the phlebotomy slightly low, long: and fix it in the middle of the nose itself, between that which distinguishes the nose according to its straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Because the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary that you should keep your last hand with the phlebotomy close: and let the blood flow according to your need
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	And bind it once at night
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	The wound itself will soon recover
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	Regarding the phlebotomy of veins of the guide (carotid
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	The phlebotomy of the guide veins is indicated for constriction of the breath, and the inception of leprosy, and melancholic diseases, and swelling and ulcers of the malar, and corrosiveness, that is, herpes of the arteries of the face
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of these is that it tightens the patient under both cheeks in his neck with a ligature: and let the artist stand over the head of the patient, and the patient should be sitting on a seat
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then the vein is to be cut to the width of the wide phlebotomy.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw out from the blood the quantity deemed suitable, or according to that which is required for the purpose.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do likewise with the other vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then close the ligament and bind the two veins with a middle clamp: so that the diseased part is not injured
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let it rest until morning
Sanatur enim uulnus.	The wound will heal by itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	Regarding the phlebotomy of veins, Algeberich.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	Veins, however, according to Algeberich, are phlebotomizable: because they cause swelling in the throat, corruption of the gums: and bad ulcers: and fissures of the lips, and bad ulcers, even those which are in the nose, and in the vicinity of it
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of the phlebotomy of these veins is that you make the patient sit before you: and bind his neck with an awl
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn his lip up, and look at two veins: one of which is on the right side of the lip, and the other on the left side of it: and their demonstration is by the blackening of both of them.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because in the vicinity of them are small veins, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Cut therefore both of them with the incident incision
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if there is doubt in your mind, and you do not know which of them it is: then you must resort to the incision of the greater of them, and their demonstration
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And do likewise with the two veins which are in the upper lip: and most frequently runs with it: and cut two veins which are in the lower lip
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	From the vein under the tongue after the cephalic vein has been bled.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	From the vein under the tongue after the cephalic vein has been bled.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of the bleeding should be such that the patient sits between your hands facing the sun: and lift up the tongue and look under the tongue from one side of the tongue to the other side of the tongue: and the color of both should descend towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	The bleeding should be complete on both sides: and take care that you do not put your last hand in the bleeding.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under the tongue are arteries, and perhaps blood flows out from those arteries
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	Of the three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	And the three veins which are bled in the elbow are such that their bleeding is customary in all men
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And their bleeding is done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by pressing with a blunt needle: or by using oil to reduce the bleeding: or by drying with a knife, which is Alnesil
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Alnesil is suitable for the section
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And there are various kinds of needles, both broad and narrow according to the width of the veins and the tension of their form. The form of the needle for bleeding from a blunt needle is broad like water
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is suitable for opening wide veins, filled, protruding, apparent, large, and those which contain thick blood, turbid
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this needle for bleeding is smaller in width and has a finer extremity
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	It is suitable for phlebotomy of the fine veins which contain slight yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	It is suitable for phlebotomy of the fine veins which contain slight yellow blood.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	However, those veins which are three in number which are called "Basilicae" are an excellent phlebotomy.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because they draw blood from the swellings which are under the throat and the collar, from the loin towards the chest, and from the groin: and it is suitable for phlebotomy with the vein and not against it, as it may cause harm if it is done otherwise.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If it is done carelessly and the needle pricks the vein, the blood flow will be interrupted
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary to dry the area around the puncture with Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If these veins do not appear clearly, then it is necessary to seek another one, or ask for another branch of it: or to phlebotomize in another place, such as the branch of the forearm
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	Since it is clearly visible, and dry the vein with Anesil as we have said before
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to phlebotomize the same vein again, then it is necessary to first tighten the forearm, so that you can recognize the place, until you know the exact place of the pulse
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the place with the thumb, afterwards the forearm, and dry the vein with a concave incision with the needle and Anesil as we have said before
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And take care not to puncture too far from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	When you go, when you tighten the ligature, the inflation in the place which you marked with the thumb, then that inflation is the inflation of the artery: you must therefore stop there
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If the blood spills out at the phlebotomy, like the urine of a boy, and is thin and red: then you know that it is from an artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then it is right, and place your finger upon the place where it is longer, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If the blood is shed (and it is often shed) then tighten the arm and let go of it: and let the patient beware of its movement: and be above its fear
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Do not move it for a few days until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If, however, the blood does not shed, and it increases for you: and you perceive it not in your moment of medicine, then cut the artery if you see it.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities are stretched and the blood is shed.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the bark of a quince, and find its middle: take one half and tighten it above the place of the narrowest part with ligament and veins until the next day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is shed, that is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then care for it as for one whose pulse has been cut off by the flow of blood: and the cutting of the blood in these matters is not difficult on account of the smallness of the wound and the possibility of the ligament from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	Of the phlebotomy of the forearm.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The veins of the forearm are used for phlebotomy, because they draw blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: because they are composed of the branches of the basilica and cephalic veins, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	It is convenient for the phlebotomist that there be above his fear of phlebotomy, for under it is a nerve
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If, therefore, anything is added to the puncture of the phlebotomy, and it encounters nerve, it will cause swelling in that place, and the healing will be difficult, and it may not heal entirely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And that nerve appears very sensitive to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is hidden in some people, and is slight, and is not evident: then you must take care that you do not perforate the vein more than is necessary, section it with Alnesil, and take out the nerve with your skill
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If there is a vein between two nerves, then find the vein in length
¶ De uena Cephalica.	About the cephalic vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The punctures of the cephalic vein, however, are useful, because they draw blood from the head, and confer it to the ailments of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is proper in this vein, if you will, to puncture it with the needle of the olive, or with the needle of Myrtle: because it is safer for all the veins, because it is neither an artery nor a nerve
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	It is true that it is proper to touch the head with the puncture of the phlebotomy, and that you seek a softer place: and it does not harm it, if it is not found with the first blow, as it will return on the subsequent puncture.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Perhaps sometimes it is delayed in some people when it is not punctured on the first blow, but it does not harm them that delay in anything
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	## On the usefulness of phlebotomy, and the precautions to be taken in observing it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy, and the accidents which accompany it, in the rectification of which you must consider
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Firstly, know this, that phlebotomy is not to be administered except in the conservation of health, and its preservation, and caution against the coming of illness.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And let phlebotomy be done in a vein of the cubit, namely the Cephalica, and the Fusca, and the Basilica
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And let phlebotomy be done at the beginning of spring after fasting, in summer, and autumn, and winter after meals, when there are signs of repletion.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And let phlebotomy be done on the first or third day after three hours have passed
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Phlebotomy, however, which is administered in illnesses, has no fixed hour: but when it is expedient and necessary for this, in the night or day, and at every hour, and at every time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not fitting that phlebotomy be done in children until they are more than fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Neither should phlebotomy be done in a pregnant woman except from the fourth month until the seventh
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Neither in old men who have passed their sixties years
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When, however, anyone wishes to undergo phlebotomy for whatever reason: it is necessary to cleanse the intestines beforehand with a mild enema, if there is much retained stool: that the veins do not become irritated by the evacuation of putrid matter from the intestines to the principal parts
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Neither should phlebotomy be done in a patient who is suffering from excessive nausea, nor in a drunkard, nor in a euphoric state, until this has been remedied by the passage of time from the underlying cause
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Neither in a patient suffering from hydrosis
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let a bloodletting be repeated after a colicky passion, omitting it, and the flow of the belly, and the multiplication of coitus, and work, and exercise, and drunkenness, and eating, and all that dissolves virtue from the body or animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Consider then in the subtlety of humors before this, whether the blood is thick with food and drink, and the physicians: if it is possible for it.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then introduce a poultice, if it does not prohibit it: or perform some exercise, so as to make the blood finer.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And perform a bloodletting of it in the chest, around the third day: as we have said: and endeavor that he evacuate his belly of all the bad things of the animal: such as envy, and anger, and fear: and from all bodily things, such as work, and pain, and excess, and such like these.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And make his food present things which are with the use of men from fragrance, and smell, and joy and such like these in quantity as is possible
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the blood-letter sit above the pillow, which is higher than the blood-letting hand: then draw out his arm, and wipe it with the hand of the blood-letter twice or thrice
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then bind the ligament with a bandage, and wrap it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the binding be temperate, because when the binding is unequal, or by excessive force in the binding, it hinders the course of the blood: or in softening, then it hinders the course of the blood also
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the binding let the blood-letter wipe his hand together until the veins are filled and the senses are relaxed.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then the phlebotomist should withdraw blood from the vein with little pressure, as was formerly.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he places his finger on the mark of the left hand above the vein at the place where he wishes to perform the phlebotomy, slightly: so that the vein does not slip away, and that the percussion is certain
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For indeed from the veins is more difficult than from the arteries as concerning the fleeing of the vein during the phlebotomy: and from the inside is that which is filled with air: and when one places the phlebotomy on the vein, it contracts under the phlebotomy, and the phlebotomist is struck, and the vein does not open: and if it does open, it is tightly closed: because of this therefore it is necessary that the phlebotomist should be firm and attentive in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he lays the phlebotomy aside.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If indeed the vein opens from the one side only, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat it with the other side slightly below or above with speed: if the place does not recover
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	Which if it recovers, or if the patient is faint, then let him go home on the first or second day: and do not tighten the ligamentum
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps indeed the swelling will go down.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	Neither must he put in a poultice.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then he will repeat the phlebotomy if he wishes.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	And if the opening is small, or blood runs slowly: and you are afraid lest it should go outside the quantity which you wish: then repeat the phlebotomy in the same place according to the rule, and add a little more to the operation
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this with great care, before the incision is made, for in many people the place is sore already from the operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you see that the place has already been sore, then you must not go over it any more, for this will not excuse you from your duty
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put something soft of oil over it: because it will soothe the course of the blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	It is better in this place than pure oil, and than any other oil.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And do the same with the application of oil in all your bloodletting, which you do by prohibiting the course of the blood: and they make this like turmeric, saffron, and alum, when one of them is put on the place with the other
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	The blood will then become thin and dissolve, when it is thick
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If this happens in the place of bloodletting there will be great swelling, for this happens very often, especially with those who are not bled except with oil, or with a slight opening of a vein: then cleanse and put over the place a sponge soaked in water and salt, warmed up: and bind for an hour: for it will dissolve.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do this after the blood has been let from the vein, with the completion of its course, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If anything black or yellow remains in the place after a few days, it does no harm: and if it does, put over it something of aloe, or of myrrh of remedies: or something of the juice of mint, that is, of calamine or something like that
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And many swelling and eminences happen in bloodletting at the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Put your hand over it, then if you find softness under your compression of it, then that swelling is bad
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, as we have said, you must put something upon it from this.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from that artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster over it with something which has styptic properties, so that the place is bound up.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the rest of the treatment until the wound is healed
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary to draw out every man from blood in proportion to his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which appears from the colour of the blood over the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For blood which is black, then send it away to go, until it becomes red: and in like manner if it is thick: then send it away until it becomes thin: and in like manner if it is acute: until its sharpness is gone
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for him who is full, strong, and indigent to draw out blood little by little, so that he strengthens the phlebotomy by doing so, and that the phlebotomist be wide: and in him who is weak, let it be the opposite of him
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary to draw it out in small quantities, and that the hole be strict: and it is better that it be administered in phlebotomy by a cut, not by a puncture
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood, and from a cut: and is more laudable and safer than phlebotomy by breadth and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to whom it has happened to faint during phlebotomy, it is necessary to give him before phlebotomy a spoonful of bread soaked in pomegranate juice: or vinegar, if he is feverish: and draw out from him blood in three or four quantities.</start_of_turn>
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	If the complexion is cold, then take before the phlebotomy a loaf of bread infused in myrrh, or in scented honey syrup with spices, or in scented syrup with a strong odor.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If syncope occurs during phlebotomy, and its cause is the excessive discharge of blood: then it is necessary to drink in the water of meat, and a mild aromatic syrup: and to flavor it with algae, and to support the chest with these. And do all that we said in the chapter on syncope concerning evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wishes to evacuate his arm and stop the bleeding: let him who has had a phlebotomy because of excessive evacuation, and his blood is weak, let him gradually dissolve the blood with the measure of his ability in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wishes to evacuate his arm and stop the bleeding, and his body is strong: let him do this after seven hours, or nine from his first phlebotomy
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from his body towards the side which is inclined downwards: let him do this in the second or third day
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whom there is much hot and acute blood, and who causes a fever: let him evacuate from this blood in one vessel, and draw from this quantity greatly: and increase the opening until syncope occurs: after which you must restore all the conditions of the phlebotomy: and put your hand over the pulse of his wrist at the course of the blood, so that there is no risk of syncope in that place.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Many times this happens when the phlebotomist is ignorant and neglectful.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not right when one wishes to evacuate the arm and solve the blood when the orifice of the vein is closed and there is a difficult discharge of blood, as if it were premature over that which is excessive, and the head is thrown back too quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	It is bad that it is delayed, indeed let it go forth, until it is bled in the second [attempt].
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Remove it with speed when the bleeding has ceased from the orifice of the vein, and place upon it some saline dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	Place upon it some alum or saffron, and compress it gently, until the blood has drained out
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If indeed the vein has been severed, then let it go forth, and do not grasp it, until the swelling has subsided
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	When necessity compels to drain the blood in the second [attempt], and it is not excused, then either perform the phlebotomy above the place [of the wound] or in another vein in the arm or in the other vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The veins of the arm which are to be bled are those of Fusca and Basilica, which are not to be found, because they are composed of bones.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	The quality of the phlebotomy is that the sick person should immerse his hand in warm water, until the flesh turns red and the vein becomes visible
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then bind upon it with a bandage of moderate constriction.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then perform the phlebotomy in a transverse direction gradually, not longitudinally, and do it not too widely: and let the opening be wide, and let your phlebotomy be as close as possible to the edge of the wound
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If it is forbidden that blood should escape, then repeat the immersion of the hand in warm water, and let the blood run in the water until you have accomplished your purpose
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you are in the days of heat, then you are excused from the immersion of the hand in warm water
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	Many times, the flow of blood is put into warm water in wintertime.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	Phlebotomy of this limb is safer for all limbs, because there is no pulsation under this limb, neither nerve
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	Phlebotomy of the right hand is useful in treating liver diseases
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	The quality of this phlebotomy is that you must tie the wrist with a ligament or your hand, after you have inserted your thumb into the warm water, until the limb swells and the patient feels cold
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then the phlebotomy is transverse
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut the vein completely, it will not cause him harm in any way
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And be careful, do not touch your hand with the phlebotomy.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under that there are the nerves of the fingers stripped of flesh from the bone.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then put the hand back into the warm water, and let the blood flow out of it
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not put the hand back into the warm water, the blood clots in the opening of the vein, and is prohibited from flowing
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When you have taken out the necessary quantity of blood, then put oil and salt on the vein: so that it does not clot too quickly
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And in the same way it is necessary to do with all branches that are tight
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	The dressing for this phlebotomy is from the left hand: because it is useful for the treatment of spleen diseases: and do the same in this phlebotomy as you did in the second one equally
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The saphenous veins of phlebotomy are useful for treating diseases which are in the lower parts of the body, such as diseases of the uterus, and retention of menstruation, and weakness of the kidneys, and ulcers of the buttocks and thighs of old age, and similar diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is such that it makes the patient immerse his foot in warm water: and perform over it friction until bubbles appear: and ligate above the junction of the foot with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	The bubbles will appear at the heel, visible beyond the thumb: and they are driven out from it on the face of the foot in many places.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	The phlebotomy is therefore better in the broader branch of the vein, or at the heel in its collection: because it is better and safer
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If the phlebotomy is made on the face of the foot, then it causes damage to the nerves that are under it over the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy thus that the phlebotomy comes from the transverse vein, like the one you would make if you were to cut the vein: and let the phlebotomy be of Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If, however, the discharge of blood is prohibited, then repeat the foot in warm water: and prevent the blood from running in the vein until it is evacuated
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the vein of the phlebotomist is mistaken in the first attempt, then repeat with the phlebotomy to the upper parts, for the place is safe, and not to be feared, when you cause damage to the nerves, as we have said
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And in the same way as the other foot's saphenous vein is equal.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The veins of the sciatica are located, as we have said, at the heel from the side of the heel bone.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	The advantage of the phlebotomy is against the pain of the ankle, when it is due to warm blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is such that it makes the patient immerse his foot in a bath, and festinate: and bind the ankle from the side of the ankle up to the heel four fingers, with a fine tape: for without that it will not appear unless for that.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When the situation demands, a bloodletting is to be performed according to whatever faculty is possible, or according to the changing of the pulse. It is better either to cut with the knife or to perform an incision.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	The situation is in this place more beneficial, and it is hidden in many men
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and it does not appear to the senses in any way: then let a bloodletting be made of some part of it, as that which appears in the heel and near the ear: cause it to flow from the nerves, and let run out an amount of blood as much as you desire
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the tension, and place over the place of the bloodletting the skin, and bind the place.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It heals quickly in this way.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	On Ventosation and the quality of its supply.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter XCIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Ventsations arise from the bowels, and from the air, and from the outside
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And the ventilation is performed in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With incision and extraction of blood: and the other is ventilation without incision
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this ventilation which is without incision is done in two ways
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or with fire
Aut est absque igne.	Or without fire
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the ventilation which is administered with incision and extraction of blood is performed in fourteen places of the body
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is the Ventosatio Alnocrati, and it is behind the head: and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck: and the uentosae Alhagdahim, and they are two layers of the neck from two parts together: and the uentosae menti, and it is under the jaw in the lower part of the mouth: and the uentosae duarum spatularum: and the uentosae Alachosos over the end of the tail: and the uentosae duorum focilium, and they are in the middle of the two arms: and the uentosae duorum brachiorum: and the uentosae duorum crurium: and the uentosae duarum cauillarum.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	The wind of evacuation does not pull blood out of small pores scattered throughout the flesh, and because of this it does not cause a loss of vital force, just as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	Neither is it necessary to administer the evacuation with fire or without fire in any ailment that arises from congestion, until the whole body has been evacuated.</start_of_turn>
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If need compels evacuation from an ailment, or by custom, we administer it at every hour in the beginning of the month, at its end, and in the middle of it, and whenever necessary.</start_of_turn
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	For in men, when their blood has multiplied in them, until it necessitates its evacuation by evacuation, it finds its way into their head and causes them harm.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And from this is that it causes congestion and redness in their face, head, and neck.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from this is that it causes itching in their face, forehead, and eyebrows, and darkness and blurring in their eyes.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from this is that it makes the place of evacuation sore.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from this is that their laughter multiplies.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from this is that it causes a taste of blood in their mouth: either the tongue becomes dry and expels blood.</start_of_turn>
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from this is that their sleep multiplies.</start_of_turn
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And from this is that they urinate in their sleep blood and redness, and emissions, and swellings, which are like these.</start_of_turn
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see any of these things, and especially if it is in the middle of the month: we order that evacuation be performed immediately, after two or three hours have passed.</start_of_turn
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	The application of the Ventosation of the Neck is: because it itself contributes to the gravity of the head, and what flows down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	Moreover, it should be performed after the evacuation of the entire body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this is indeed a Ventosation of the Cephalic vein.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	It is not permitted to perform it on those who are of cold complexion or in whom there is congestion.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it brings about a great danger.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	Moreover, it must not be performed on the elderly, or in whom there is cold inflammation in the head
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	Whoever performs it frequently becomes prone to convulsions
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	Moreover, it is necessary to command the operator of the Ventosation to place his hand with the vein towards the lower parts, fearing the production of convulsions
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	The Ventosation or Alkehel is a place of phlebotomy of the Vein of the Fetus, and of the Vein of the Basilica, and by this it brings about swelling, constriction of the breath, spasm of the instruments of the breath, cough, and swelling.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	It is necessary to push the Alkehel Ventosation downwards, because if it is placed downwards, it generates stiffness in the heart and the stomach
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	The applied Ventosation brings about pain in the accidents of the head, and swelling, and headache, and perforation, and pain in the roots of the teeth: and it is a place of phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Moreover, it is necessary for the operator of the Ventosation to avoid premature placement of the hand with the knife: lest he puncture the artery and cause the flow of blood to be obstructed
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	The sneezing of the patient causes vomiting in the mouth, corruption of the gums, and similar ailments which exist in the mouth: and it is in the place of phlebotomy.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The sneezing of the patient causes vomiting in the mouth, which is caused by reflection and heat
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	The sneezing of the patient causes vomiting in the mouth, which is caused by the reflection and heat of the three humors, Basilica, Cephalic and Facial: since these all draw blood from all the small veins that are in the flesh: and they draw these small veins from other large veins until the attraction reaches the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary, in order to prevent the sneezing from causing too great a bleeding, that the operation should not go too deep: since the place is naked of flesh, and under it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The sneezing of the patient causes bleeding of the veins of the bowels, hemorrhoids of the rectum, and ulcers below.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary, in order to prevent the sneezing from causing great vomiting, that it should be done with the greatest of care: since the place requires strong suction, and perhaps the fine veins will be torn by the sneezing: and the operation should be performed with great care
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	The sneezing of the patient causes a decrease in the magnitude of the crises: since these draw blood from the whole body, and cause old pains in the limbs, and the uterus, and the testicles: they cause menstruation, and cause swelling, and madness: and they are in the place of phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins, and the ulnar veins
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	But they weaken the body greatly, and cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	The vomiting of the patient is proximate to the bleeding of the two large veins.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the veins is that you should put the swollen part in the first incision, and perform suction with a tempered degree: and do not prolong the position of the swollen part, but rather place it quickly, and move it quickly, so that the humors may reach the place in proportion to their advancement: and do not cease doing this until the place has become red and swollen, and the red blood appears; then indeed you should scarify, and repeat the suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the disposition of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For one who has soft flesh and few hairs, who is like a man from among men, you should scarify him once, not more: so as not to damage the place
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And command the surgeon to amplify the scarification, and deepen it slightly: and temper the suction with ease, and speed, and movement of the hand.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is thickness in the blood, then it is necessary that you should scarify it twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first instance, open a small opening under the thickness of the blood, and wash it out: and in the second instance make a precise incision for the extraction of the thick blood
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If indeed the blood is black and fetid, then make a third incision: so that the last thing will follow
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And finally, when we wish to extract the blood gradually, or little by little, sufficeth for us one scarification
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	When we wish to extract much blood, we must make several scarifications
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick: then it is necessary that it be scarified deeply: and the endpoint of equality in the scarification is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is that which must be managed from oils at the position of the Ventusarium, and what is the cause of its swelling?
